Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the "Code of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia" and may be so cited. Such ordinances may also be cited as the "Manassas Park Code." 
(Code 1971, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to codify and recodify its ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the interpretation and construction of this Code and of all ordinances of the city, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless they are inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council or the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    And; or. The word "and" may be read "or" and the word "or" may be read "and" when the sense requires it. 
    Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be sufficient. 
    Charter. The word "Charter" shall mean the Charter of the city, being Chapter 722 of the 1976 Acts of the General Assembly, as amended. 
    City. The word "city" shall mean the City of Manassas Park, in the County of Prince William and State of Virginia. 
    Code; this Code. Whenever the words "Code" or "this Code" are referred to in this Code without further qualification, they shall mean the "Code of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia," as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day. If the last day is a Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
    Council. The words "council," "the council" or "city council" shall mean the City Council of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
    County. The words "county" or "the county" shall mean the County of Prince William in the State of Virginia. 
    Fee schedule. The "fee schedule" is a list of charges adopted by the governing body and modified from time to time for permits, applications, and inspections related to the building code, property maintenance code, subdivision ordinance, zoning ordinance, and the public facilities manual. 
    Following. The word "following," when used by way of reference to any section or sections in the Code, shall be construed to mean next following that in which such reference is made. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only may extend and be applied to females and to corporations as well as to males. 
    Health department. The words "health department" shall mean the Health Department of Prince William County or the duly authorized agent of such department. 
    Health officer. The words "health officer" shall mean the Health Officer of the Prince William County Health Department, or his duly authorized agent. 
    In the city; within the city. The words "in the city" or "within the city" shall mean any territory, jurisdiction of which, for the exercise of its regulatory power, has been conferred on the city by public or private law. 
    Month. The word "month" shall be construed to mean a calendar month. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; and a word importing the plural number only may extend and be applied to one person or thing, as well as to several persons or things. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Occupant or tenant. The word "occupant" or "tenant," applied to a building or land, shall mean any person who holds a written or oral lease of, or who actually occupies the whole or a part of, such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Officers, boards, etc. Whenever reference is made to a particular officer, department, board, commission or other agency, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
    Official time standard. Whenever particular hours are referred to in this Code, the time applicable shall be official standard time or daylight saving time, whichever may be in current use in the city. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include a firm, partnership, association of persons, corporation, organization or any other group acting as a unit. 
    Preceding. The word "preceding," when used by way of reference to any section or sections in this Code, shall be construed to mean next preceding that in which such reference is made. 
    Property. The word "property" shall mean real, personal or mixed property. 
    Public grounds. The words "public grounds" shall mean the parks and all public lands owned by the city and those parts of public places which do not form travelled parts of streets, as defined in this section. 
    Shall; may. The word "shall" is mandatory. The word "may" is permissive. 
    Shoulder. The word "shoulder" shall mean that part of the highway or street between the portion regularly travelled by vehicular traffic and the lateral curb line or ditch. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline, or the lateral lines of a roadway where there is no curb, and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature, subscription. The words "signature" and "subscription" shall include a mark when the person cannot write, his name being written near it and being witnessed by a person who writes his own name as a witness. 
    State. The terms "state," "the state," and "this state" shall mean the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
    Street. The word "street" shall include avenues, boulevards, highways, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts, bridges and the approaches thereto and all other public thoroughfares in the city, and shall mean the entire width thereof between abutting property lines. It shall be construed to include a sidewalk or footpath, unless the contrary is expressed or unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the council. 
    Swear, sworn. The words "swear" or "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" or "affirmed" in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense may include the future, as well as the past and present. 
    Written; in writing. The words "written" and "in writing" shall include typewriting, printing on paper and any other mode of representing words and letters. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1971, § 1-2; Ord. No. 18-1700-1015, § 1, 6-19-18) 
State Law reference- Similar definitions and rules of construction applicable to state law, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.3 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
(a)  The catchlines of the sections of this Code, appearing in bold face type, are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of any section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any section, including its catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to chapter 31 of this Code, the catchlines to the sections of that chapter having been adopted by the council. 
(Code 1971, § 1-5) 
State Law reference- Provisions similar to subsection (a) above as to sections of state code, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.9. 
Sec. 1-4. - Common law as to misdemeanors. 
    The common law of England, with respect to misdemeanors, insofar as it is not repugnant to the principles of the Bill of Rights, the Constitution of the state and the Charter and ordinances of the city, shall continue in full force within the city and be the rule of decision, except as altered by the General Assembly of the state or by the council. 
State Law reference- Continuation in effect of common law of England within state, Code of Virginia, § 1-10. 
Sec. 1-5. - Provisions of Code considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as the provisions of prior codifications and ordinances of the city included herein, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1971, § 1-4) 
Sec. 1-6. - Miscellaneous ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money by or for the city or authorizing the issuance of any bonds or any evidence of indebtedness; 
(2)  Authorizing or otherwise relating to any contract; 
(3)  Granting any franchise or right; 
(4)  Appropriating funds, levying or imposing taxes or relating to an annual budget; 
(5)  Authorizing, providing for or otherwise relating to any public improvement; 
(6)  Making any assessment; 
(7)  Establishing, extending or contracting the corporate limits of the city; 
(8)  The purposes of which have been accomplished; 
(9)  Which is temporary, although general in effect; or 
(10)  Which is special, although permanent in effect 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, or any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered, on or before the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1-8. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia (or the Manassas Park Code) is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(b)  In the event a new section not herefore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia (or the Manassas Park Code) is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered ____________ , which said section reads as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
Sec. 1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the Council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been replaced shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
State Law reference- Authority to supplement Code, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3. 
Sec. 1-10. - Copies of Code and supplements to be available for public inspection. 
    At least three (3) copies of this Code and every supplement thereto shall be kept in the office of the city clerk and shall there be available for public inspection, during normal business hours. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-37.3. 
Sec. 1-11. - Personal recognizance and cash deposit, in lieu of recognizance with surety, by persons charged with Code violations. 
(a)  When a person charged with a violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city is admitted to bail by an officer authorized by law so to do for his appearance before a court having jurisdiction of the case for a hearing thereon, he may, instead of entering into a recognizance with surety, give his personal recognizance and deposit with such officer, or cause to be deposited for him, in cash, the amount of bail he is required to furnish. 
(b)  Upon the giving of personal recognizance and deposit, as provided in this section, the officer receiving the same shall give to the person whose funds are so deposited an official receipt therefor. In order that the officer in question may be able to give such official receipt, it shall be the duty of the city to provide all such officers with official prenumbered receipt books, in triplicate, consisting of an original and two (2) carbon copies. The original receipt shall go to the person whose funds are deposited. The first carbon copy shall go to the court before which the person recognized is to appear and the second shall remain in the receipt book. The officer with whom cash was so deposited shall deliver the same, along with the first carbon copy of the receipt, to the court before which the person recognized is to appear, or to the clerk of such court, if authorized by law to receive the same, who shall give him an official receipt therefor. 
(c)  If there is no default in the observation of the conditions of the recognizance given under this section, or if there is default and it is a case which may be tried in the absence of the defendant, and he is so tried, and if, upon the trial of the case, the defendant is found not guilty, the money deposited under this section shall be refunded to the person making such deposit, or upon his order. If, however, the defendant is found guilty, the court trying the case shall apply the money, or so much thereof as may be necessary, to the payment of such fine and costs as may be adjudged against the defendant and the residue thereof, if any, shall be paid over to the person making such deposit, or upon his order. If there is an appeal from the judgment of the court trying any such case, the money so deposited shall be paid over by such court to the clerk of the court to which such an appeal is taken. 
(d)  If there is default in any such recognizance, and if the case is not tried in the absence of the defendant, the forfeiture shall be noted of record and proceedings had thereon as provided by law, and the money so deposited shall be held subject to the order of the court upon the final disposition of such proceeding. 
Sec. 1-12. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any other ordinance or resolution of the city or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him or if any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, the violation of any such provision of such Code or other ordinance, resolution, rule, regulation or order shall, unless otherwise specifically provided, constitute a Class 1 misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine not exceeding two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding twelve (12) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Whenever it is provided that any violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance or resolution of the city or any rule, regulation or other referred to in subsection (a) above constitutes a Class 2, 3 or 4 misdemeanor, such violation shall be punishable as follows: 
(1)  For a Class 2 misdemeanor by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment in jail for not more than six (6) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(2)  For a Class 3 misdemeanor, by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(3)  For a Class 4 misdemeanor, by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(c)  Except where otherwise provided, every day any violation of such Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the city or such rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1971, § 6-1; Ord. No. 92-1700-480, 12-1-92) 
State Law reference- Classification of misdemeanors and punishment therefor, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-9, 18.2-11; authority of city to provide penalties for violation of ordinances, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-901; authority of court trying case, upon conviction, to require bond conditioned that the person convicted will not violate the ordinance for the breach of which he was convicted for a period of not more than one year, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-902; injunctive relief for continuing violations of ordinances, Code of Virginia § 15.1-905. 
Sec. 1-13. - Liability of corporations, etc., and agents for violations. 
(a)  Any violation of this Code by any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or unincorporated association or organization, while acting within the scope of his office or employment, shall in every case also be deemed to be a violation by such corporation, association or organization. 
(b)  Any officer, agent or other person acting for or employed by any corporation or unincorporated association or organization shall be subject and liable to punishment, as well as such corporation or unincorporated association or organization, for the violation by it of any provision of this Code, where such violation was the act or omission, or the result of the act, omission or order of any such person. 
(Code 1971, § 6-2) 
Sec. 1-14. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    If any part, section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code is for any reason declared to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the constitutionality or validity of the remainder of this Code. 
(Code 1971, § 1-3) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 9-16 et seq.; resisting, obstructing, etc. city officers or employees or work for city, § 17-5; falsification or destruction of public records, § 17-6; police, Ch. 18; taxation, Ch. 22; zoning administrator, § 31-44; board of zoning appeals, § 31-48 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Elections. 
    Elections to the offices of mayor and city council members shall occur in even years on the date set by the Commonwealth of Virginia for November general elections. 
(Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1c., 7-18-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 06-1700-809, §§ 1a.-1c., adopted July 18, 2006, reorganized Art. I as follows: subsection 1a. deleted § 2-10; subsection 1b. renumbered existing §§ 2-1-2-9 as 2-2-2-10 respectively; and 1c. added a new § 2-1. These actions are effective July 1, 2007, pending approval of the 2007 session of the General Assembly. 
Sec. 2-2. - Voting places. 
    The voting place for Precinct One in the city is the Manassas Park High School, located at 8200 Euclid Avenue. The voting place for Precinct Two in the city is the Manassas Park Community Center in Costello Park, located at 99 Adams Street. The voting place for Precinct Three in the city is the Manassas Park City Hall Building, located at One Park Center Court. 
    A central absentee voter precinct created for the purpose receiving, counting, and recording absentee ballots cast in the city is located in the Manassas Park City Hall Building. 
(Code 1971, § 2-1; Ord. No. 85-1700-272A, 3-5-85; Ord. No. 02-1700-695, 12-3-02; Ord. No. 05-1700-775, § 2, 2-15-05; Ord. No. 05-1700-777, §§ 1, 2, 3-8-05; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06; Ord. No. 15-1700-964, § 2, 2-24-15) 
Charter reference- Elections, § 4.1 et seq. 
Sec. 2-3. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall begin on the first day of July of each year and end on the following thirtieth day of June. 
(Code 1971, § 8-2; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
Cross reference- Tax year, § 22-1. 
State Law reference- Uniform fiscal year and fiscal year accounting procedures for cities, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2500 et seq. 
Sec. 2-4. - Annual audit. 
    There shall be an annual audit of the financial and administrative affairs of the city, by a qualified and competent certified public accountant. 
(Code 1971, § 8-3; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
Sec. 2-5. - Depositories of city monies to post bond. 
    The city treasurer shall require any depository of city monies to post bond to the maximum amount of any monies on deposit, less that secured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The approval of such bonds shall be vested in the council. 
(Code 1971, § 8-4; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
Sec. 2-6. - Execution of deeds and other instruments requiring use of seal. 
    All deeds for the conveyance or exchange of the property of the city, and all agreements or other instruments requiring the seal of the city to be affixed thereto shall, when authorized by the council, be executed in the name of the city by the mayor and the seal of the city shall be affixed thereto and attested by the clerk. 
(Code 1971, § 2-3; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
Charter reference- Authority of city clerk with respect to city seal, § 3.7. 
Sec. 2-7. - Signing of warrants or checks. 
    All warrants or checks for the disbursement of city funds shall be signed by the mayor, the city clerk or an authorized member of the city council and shall be countersigned by the city treasurer or deputy treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-91, § 13, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 03-1700-727, 10-7-03; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
Sec. 2-8. - Procedures for processing checks returned to city for insufficient funds. 
    The following procedures are hereby established for processing checks returned to the city for insufficient funds: 
(1)  If any check or other means of payment tendered to the city in the course of its duties is not paid by the financial institution on which it is drawn because (i) of insufficient funds in the account of the drawer, (ii) no account is in the name of the drawer, or (iii) the account of the drawer is closed, and the check or other means of payment is returned to the city unpaid, the amount thereof shall be charged to the person on whose account it was received, and his liability and that of his sureties shall be as if he had never offered any such payment. 
A fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) or the amount of any costs, whichever is greater, shall be charged to the person or firm that utters, publishes or passes any check, draft or order for payment of taxes or any other sums due to the city, which is subsequently returned to the city treasurer for insufficient funds or because there is no account or the account has been closed, or because such check, draft or order was returned because of a stop-payment order placed in bad faith on the check, draft or order by the drawer. This fee shall be in addition to any penalty provided by law, except the penalty imposed by section 58.1-12 of the Code of Virginia shall not apply. 
(2)  The service for which the unpaid check or other means of payment was rendered shall be discontinued immediately or other appropriate action taken, as applicable. The amount due pursuant to subsection 2-8(1) above shall be presented to the city treasurer in the form of cash, money order or certified check for prompt resumption of service; otherwise service will be resumed once payment of this amount has been received by the city from the financial institution on which the check or other means of payment has been drawn. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-88, 8-17-76; Ord. No. 78-1700-120, 6-6-78; Ord. No. 82-1700-202, 8-17-82; Ord. No. 03-1700-713, § 1, 5-20-03; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06; Ord. No. 11-1700-901, § 1, 4-19-11; Ord. No. 18-1700-1011, § 1, 2-20-18) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
Sec. 2-9. - Applicants for city employment subject to criminal history check. 
    All applicants for employment with the city may be subject to a criminal history check. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-90, 10-19-76; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
State Law reference- State to furnish criminal history record information for conduct of investigation of applicants for public employment, Code of Virginia, § 19.2-389. 
Sec. 2-10. - Holidays for employees. 
    The holiday schedule for full-time employees of the city shall be as follows: New Year's Day; Lee-Jackson-King Day; Presidents Day; Memorial Day; Independence Day; Labor Day; Columbus Day; Veteran's Day; Thanksgiving Day; the Friday after Thanksgiving; Christmas Day; and such other days as may be approved by the governing body. If a holiday falls on Sunday, the following day shall be observed as a holiday, and if it falls on Saturday, the preceding day shall be observed as a holiday. 
(Code 1971, § 20-1; Ord. No. 99-1700-612A, 9-21-99; Ord. No. 06-1700-809, § 1b., 7-18-06) 
Note- See the editor's note following § 2-1. 
Sec. 2-11. - Members of police department, fire department, volunteer fire company and rescue squad designated as part of official safety programs and entitled to benefits under Line of Duty Act. 
    The city hereby recognizes all members of the city police department, fire department and the members of the city volunteer fire company and rescue squad as an integral part of the official safety program of the city and they shall be recognized and entitled to receive benefits under the Line of Duty Act pursuant to Code of Virginia, §§ 9.1-400-9.1-406, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 75-1700-68, 1-7-75) 
Cross reference- Fire department, § 9-16 et seq.; police, Ch. 18. 
Sec. 2-12. - Assessment of additional court cost to support court-related facilities, construction, renovation and maintenance. 
(a)  There shall be assessed, in addition to any other fees prescribed by law, as a part of the cost incident to each criminal or traffic case filed in the courts which serve the city the sum of two dollars ($2.00). 
(b)  The assessment levied by subsection (a) above shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed and remitted monthly to the treasurer of the city. Such funds shall be held by the treasurer of the city subject to disbursements by city council for the construction, renovation or maintenance of courthouse or jail and court-related facilities and to defray increases in the cost of heating, cooling, electricity, and ordinary maintenance, pursuant to the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 17.1-281. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-427, § 19-4-90) 
Sec. 2-13. - Assessment of courthouse security fee. 
(a)  There shall be assessed, in addition to any other fees prescribed by law, as part of the cost incident to each criminal or traffic case filed in the district or Circuit Courts which serve the city, in which the defendant is convicted of a violation of any statute or ordinance, the sum of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(b)  The assessment levied by subsection (a) above shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the case is heard and remitted monthly to the treasurer of the city subject to appropriation by the governing body to the sheriff's office for the funding of courthouse security personnel, pursuant to the provisions of section 53.1-120, Code of Virginia (1950). 
(Ord. No. 02-1700-269, 7-2-02; Ord. No. 03-1700-721, § 1, 8-19-03; Ord. No. 07-1700-829, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 2-14. - Assessment of processing fee on individuals admitted to the Prince William-Manassas Regional Adult Detention Center following conviction of a crime. 
(a)  There shall be assessed, in addition to any other fees prescribed by law, and as part of the cost incident to processing arrested persons into the Prince William-Manassas Regional Adult Detention Center following conviction, a processing fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(b)  The assessment levied by subsection (a) above shall be ordered as part of court costs collected by the clerk of court, deposited into the account of the city treasurer, and used by the Prince William-Manassas Regional Adult Detention Center to defray the costs of processing arrested persons. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-723, § 1, 8-19-03) 
Sec. 2-15. - Assessment for law library as part of costs in civil actions. 
(a)  There shall be assessed, in addition to any other fees prescribed by law, as part of the cost incident to each civil action case filed in the district or circuit courts which serve the city, in which the defendant is convicted of a violation of any statute or ordinance, the sum of two dollars ($2.00). 
(b)  The assessment levied by subsection (a) above shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed, and remitted to the treasurer of such county, city or town, and held by such treasurer subject to disbursement by the governing body for the acquisition of (i) law books, law periodicals and computer legal research services, computer terminals for off-site placement to maximize access to the law library by the public, and (ii) equipment for the establishment, use and maintenance of a law library which shall be open for the use of the public at hours convenient to the public. In addition the disbursement may include compensation to be paid to librarians and other necessary staff for the maintenance of such library and acquisitions of suitable quarters for such library. Pursuant to the provisions of Section 42.1-70, Code of Virginia (2002). 
(Ord. No. 09-1700-880, § 1, 10-20-09) 
Sec. 2-16. - Assessment of $5.00 on each criminal and traffic case to fund costs of electronic summons system. 
(a)  The sum of five dollars ($5.00) is hereby assessed by the city as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case filed in the courts of the 31st Judicial District or the 31st Judicial Circuit in which the defendant is charged with a violation of any statute or ordinance. 
(b)  The assessment levied by subsection (a) above shall be collected by the clerk of the court in which the action is filed, remitted to the city treasurer, and held by the city treasurer subject to disbursements by the governing body to the city's police department solely to fund software, hardware, and associated equipment costs for the implementation and maintenance of an electronic summons system. 
(Ord. No. 15-1700-965, § 1, 3-3-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-1700-965, § 1, adopted March 3, 2015, set out provisions intended for use as § 2-14. At the editor's discretion, to prevent duplication of section numbers, these provisions have been included as § 2-16. 
Secs. 2-17-2-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GOVERNING BODY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 03-1700-707, adopted April 1, 2003, changed the title of art. II, previously titled City Council. 
Charter reference- City council generally, § 3.1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-23. - When regular meetings held. 
    The governing body shall hold its regular meetings on the third Tuesday of each month, except when such date falls upon a holiday, in which event the meeting shall be held on the next business day. Regular meetings will begin at 7:00 p.m. and will follow the order of proceedings established pursuant to section 2-39 of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 2-4; Ord. No. 00-1700-616, § 1, 1-18-00; Ord. No. 04-1700-753, § 1, 7-20-04) 
Charter reference- Council to meet at least once each month, § 3.6. 
Cross reference- Disrupting meetings of city council, § 17-14. 
Sec. 2-24. - Notice of special meetings. 
    Notice of special meetings of the council shall be given by the city clerk or his designee to each member of the council. Such notice shall state the purpose for which the meeting is being called. 
(Code 1971, § 2-6) 
Charter reference- Call and notice of special council meetings, § 3.6. 
Sec. 2-25. - Where meetings held. 
    All meetings of the council shall be held in the council chambers or at such place as may be provided by the council. 
(Code 1971, § 2-5) 
Sec. 2-26. - Meetings open to public. 
    All regularly constituted meetings of the council shall be open to the public, except that executive sessions and closed meetings may be held pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 2.2-3711. 
(Code 1971, § 2-7) 
Charter reference- Ordinances, resolutions, etc., to be adopted at meeting open to the public, § 3.6(d). 
Sec. 2-27. - Agenda for meetings. 
    The council may prescribe the procedure for the establishment of an agenda for its meetings. 
(Code 1971, § 2-8) 
Secs. 2-28-2-35. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES OF PROCEDURE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Council to establish its own rules of procedure, § 3.6. 

Sec. 2-36. - Quorum. 
    A majority of the members of the governing body in office shall constitute a quorum and have the power to transact all business which shall come before the council. 
(Code 1971, § 2-9; Ord. No. 03-1700-707, 4-1-03) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 3.6(c). 
Sec. 2-37. - Procedure in absence of quorum. 
    In the event a majority of the members of the governing body fail to attend within fifteen (15) minutes after the time appointed for a meeting, the city clerk shall enter the names of those present upon the record and they shall adjourn for want of a quorum. 
(Code 1971, § 2-10; Ord. No. 03-1700-707, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 2-38. - Member absenting self from meeting. 
    At any meeting of the governing body, after a member has been recorded as present, he shall not, without the permission of the presiding officer, absent himself from such meeting until its adjournment. 
(Code 1971, § 2-11; Ord. No. 03-1700-707, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 2-39. - Order of proceedings at regular meetings. 
    The order of proceedings at regular meetings of the governing body shall be established by resolution of the governing body. 
(Code 1971, § 2-12; Ord. No. 86-1700-327A, 3-18-86; Ord. No. 96-1700-547, 7-23-96; Ord. No. 00-1700-616, § 2, 1-18-00; Ord. No. 03-1700-707, 4-1-03; Ord. No. 04-1700-753, § 2, 7-20-04) 
Sec. 2-40. - Journal of proceedings. 
(a)  A journal shall be kept of the governing body's proceedings and, at the request of any member present, the yeas and nays shall be recorded on any question. At the next meeting the proceedings shall be read and signed by the person who was presiding when the previous meeting adjourned or, if he is not then present, by the person presiding when they were read. 
(b)  The journal of the proceedings of the governing body shall be open to inspection by the public. 
(Code 1971, § 2-13; Ord. No. 03-1700-707, 4-1-03) 
Charter reference- City clerk to keep journal of council proceedings, § 3.7. 
Sec. 2-41. - Form of petitions, etc., addressed to the governing body. 
    All petitions, resolutions and reports addressed to the governing body shall be in writing and shall be in respectful language. 
(Code 1971, § 2-14; Ord. No. 03-1700-707, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 2-42. - Requirements as to remarks and debates. 
    All remarks and debates in governing body meetings shall be regular, impersonal and pertinent to the issue. 
(Code 1971, § 2-15; Ord. No. 03-1700-707, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 2-43. - Limitation on nonmembers speaking to council. 
    No person not a member of the council shall speak to the council without first obtaining the permission of the council. 
(Code 1971, § 2-16) 
Sec. 2-44. - Listing and report of unfinished business. 
    All business unfinished at a meeting of the council shall be listed and reported at the next regular meeting by the city clerk. 
(Code 1971, § 2-17) 
Sec. 2-45. - Application of rules set out in Robert's Rules of Order Newly Revised. 
    The proceedings of the governing body, except as otherwise provided in this division, shall be conducted according to the rules set out in Robert's Rules of Order Newly Revised. 
(Code 1971, § 2-18; Ord. No. 00-1700-616, § 3, 1-18-00) 
Secs. 2-46-2-56. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ORDINANCES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- Required vote for passage of ordinances, § 3.6. 

Sec. 2-57. - Numbering. 
    All ordinances of the city shall be consecutively numbered in annual series, the number of a particular ordinance to consist of the year in which passed and the consecutive number of the ordinance. 
(Code 1971, § 2-33) 
Sec. 2-58. - Posting. 
    All ordinances passed by the council shall be posted, for a period of thirty (30) days after passage, on the bulletin board located in the lobby of the city hall. 
(Code 1971, § 2-19; Ord. No. 94-1700-519, 12-20-94) 
Sec. 2-59. - Effective date. 
    All ordinances passed by the council shall be in effect upon the date set forth therein or, if no date is specified, ten (10) days after enactment. 
(Code 1971, § 2-20) 
Sec. 2-60. - Ordinance book. 
(a)  The city clerk shall enter in a book copies of all ordinances passed by the council. The book in which ordinances are thus entered shall be known as the "Ordinances at Large of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia" and shall be indexed. 
(b)  The city clerk shall write an the first page of every ordinance entered in the book mentioned in this section, if the same has been amended or repealed, the words "amended" or "repealed," as the case may be, with a reference to the page of the ordinance book where the amending or repealing ordinance can be found. 
(Code 1971, §§ 2-31, 2-32) 
Secs. 2-61-2-71. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY MANAGER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- City manager designated as city officer, § 3.1; authority of council to appoint city manager, § 3-2(3); city manager generally, § 3.9 et seq. 

Sec. 2-72. - General powers and duties. 
    The city manager shall exercise administrative supervision and control over all departments of the city government and have general supervision over all improvements, works and services. He shall also perform such duties as may be required by the provisions of this Code, the Charter, and the Code of Virginia or by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-91, § 10, 12-21-76) 
Sec. 2-73. - Duties with respect to city property. 
    The city manager shall be the custodian of all property belonging to the city, such as buildings, lands, equipment, machinery and personal property of any kind whatsoever, except property the custody of which is vested in some other officer by the Charter or other provisions of this Code. It shall be his duty to maintain an inventory of such properties and to report to the council, at least once a year, as to the condition of same. The use, rental, loan or lease of municipal property shall be the sole responsibility of the city manager and the responsibility for collection of rent or a service charge or fee for employment of any item of city property shall be the manager's. The manager shall keep all city properties adequately insured for such amounts as shall be approved by the council. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-91, § 11, 12-21-76) 
Sec. 2-74. - Attendance at council meetings; recommendations to council. 
    The city manager shall attend all meetings of the council, unless excused by the mayor, and recommend to the council, for adoption, such measures as may be deemed necessary or expedient. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-91, § 12, 12-21-76) 
Sec. 2-75. - Authority with respect to purchases. 
    The city manager shall be authorized to approve purchase orders or construction change orders up to the sum of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00), without approval of the governing body. This shall not be construed to include payrolls, utility bills, debt service or other legal obligations of the city. In cases of emergency, the ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) limit shall not apply, but the governing body shall be apprised of the emergency as soon as possible. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-91, § 14, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 86-1700-327A, 3-18-86; Ord. No. 97-1700-558, 3-4-97; Ord. No. 02-1700-685, § 1, 5-21-02) 
Sec. 2-76. - Termination of employment. 
(a)  The city council shall render at least two (2) weeks notice of termination of employment to the city manager. 
(b)  The city manager shall submit at least two (2) weeks notice prior to leaving the position. 
(c)  For the purposes of computing compensation for annual leave due and any unused sick leave, the city manager shall, upon termination of his employment, be considered a city employee and shall be subject to the relevant provisions of the then-current personnel policy for city employees. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-91, § 3, 12-21-76; Ord. No. 04-1700-737, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 2-77. - Deputy city manager. 
    [The governing body of the City of Manassas Park hereby:] 
(1)  Designates the deputy city manager as the acting city manager, fully qualified to perform the duties of the office of city manager, in cases of the long-term absence (for periods exceeding ten (10) days), disability, death or resignation of the city manager; 
(2)  Ratifies any and all actions taken by the deputy city manager while serving as the acting city manager; 
(3)  Establishes a stipend to be paid to the deputy city manager while serving as the acting city manager in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per week in addition to his regular salary as deputy city manager, which regular salary shall reflect any and all adjustments for cost-of-living allowances and/or merit raises for the position of deputy city manager; and 
(4)  Agrees that at any time when the deputy city manager is not serving as the acting city manager, for whatever reason, he shall revert back to his status as deputy city manager and shall continue to receive his regular salary as such, which regular salary shall reflect any and all adjustments for cost-of-living allowances and/or merit raises for the position of deputy city manager. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-771, 11-23-04; Ord. No. 04-1700-773, 12-21-04) 
Secs. 2-78-2-88. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-106. - General duties.
