ARTICLE VII. - CITY TREASURER[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- City treasurer designated as city officer, § 3.1. 

Sec. 2-121. - General duties. 
    The city treasurer shall, collect and receive all moneys due the city for taxes, whether current or delinquent, assessments and fees or charges of every kind. He shall enforce the provisions of the ordinances of the city with regard to licenses and license taxes and shall check any or all of the records of the commissioner of the revenue and examine and audit the books of all persons whom he has reasonable cause to believe to be liable to pay a license tax. He shall have custody of all funds belonging to the city and the school board and deposit all funds coming into his hands to the account of the city or the school board, as the case may be, in such banks or shares or certificates of deposit in any building or savings and loan association lawfully authorized to do business in this state whose accounts are insured by the federal savings and loan insurance corporation; provided, however, the investment in such shares or certificates of deposit in any one such association shall not exceed such amount as shall be fully insured by the federal savings and loan insurance corporation and provided that such banks or associations be designated for the purpose by the council and the school board, respectively, subject to the laws of the commonwealth applicable to the city and the school board relative to the deposit of public funds. He shall perform such other duties, including the validating of school board warrants or checks, have such powers and be liable to such penalties as are now or may hereafter be prescribed by law or ordinance. He shall have custody of all investments and invested funds of the city or in its possession in a fiduciary capacity, unless otherwise provided by the Charter or by law, ordinance or the terms of any trust, and shall be responsible for the safekeeping of all bonds and notes of the city and the receipt and delivery of city bonds and notes for transfer, registration and exchange. 
Sec. 2-122. - Deputy. 
    The deputy city treasurer shall be appointed by the city treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-759, § 1, 8-17-04) 
Sec. 2-123. - Bond. 
    The city treasurer shall furnish a bond payable to the city in such amount as the council may prescribe. Such bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful and true performance of all the duties placed upon the treasurer by the provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35) 
Charter reference- Official bonds, §§ 3.2(5), 5.1. 
Sec. 2-124. - Reports and budget request. 
    The city treasurer shall report to the council as requested and shall submit his annual budget request to the council before its submission to the state. 
Sec. 2-125. - Investment of idle funds. 
(a)  The city treasurer is authorized to invest idle funds whenever such funds are available subject to the approvals contained herein. 
(b)  The investments authorized herein are to be made with the written authorization of the city manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 78-1700-121, 6-6-78; Ord. No. 82-1700-200, 8-16-82; Ord. No. 01-1700-676, § 1, 7-17-01) 
Sec. 2-126. - Preparation of investment plan; reports. 
    The city treasurer shall: 
(1)  Prepare a formal investment plan, to be submitted annually to the governing body on or before July 1 of each year. The investment plan shall provide projected cash flow, the level of anticipated investments, and projected earnings during the ensuing fiscal year. 
(2)  Prepare an investment report, to be presented to the governing body by the fifteenth of each month, which report shall detail the amount of funds invested on behalf of the city and the school board, the location of such investment, the return expected on the investment, the date on which the deposit or investment was made, the date on which the deposit or investment is expected to mature, the name of the financial institution in which the funds have been deposited, and the extent to which those funds are insured or guaranteed. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-421, §§ 1-3, 5-15-90; Ord. No. 01-1700-676, § 2, 7-17-01) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-1700-421, §§ 1-3, adopted May 15, 1990, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, its inclusion herein as § 2-126 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-127. - Authority to accept payment by commercially acceptable means; service charge. 
(a)  In accordance with section 2.2-614.1 of the Code of Virginia, as amended, the treasurer is authorized to accept payment of local taxes and other fees, penalties and interest by use of any commercially acceptable means, including but not limited to checks, credit cards, debit cards, and electronic fund transfers; and 
(b)  The treasurer shall add to any amount due to the city a sum not to exceed the amount charged to the city for acceptance of any payment by a means that incurs a charge to the city or the amount negotiated and agreed to in a contract with the city, whichever is less. The treasurer is authorized to investigate credit card entities and determine those that are responsible, efficient and capable of cooperating with the city for the collection of local taxes and other fees, and to establish a list of credit cards so determined that may be accepted for payment of local taxes and other fees, penalties and interest. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-454, 3-3-92; Ord. No. 18-1700-1011, § 2, 2-20-18) 
Secs. 2-128-2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PLANNING COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Cross reference- Subdivision of land, Ch. 21; zoning, Ch. 31. 
State Law reference- Local planning, Code of Virginia, Title 15.1, Chapter 11 (§ 15.1-427 et seq.). 

Sec. 2-141. - Created. 
    A city planning commission is hereby created. 
(Code 1971, § 2-44) 
Cross reference- Subdivision of land, ch. 21; zoning, ch. 31. 
State Law reference- Local planning; duty to create local planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2210. 
Sec. 2-142. - Composition; appointment, qualifications and terms of members. 
    A local planning commission shall consist of not less than five (5) nor more than fifteen (15) members, appointed by the governing body, all of whom shall be residents of the locality, qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development; provided, that at least one-half (1/2) of the members so appointed shall be owners of real property. The local governing body may require each member of the commission to take an oath of office. One (1) member of the commission may be a member of the governing body of the locality; and one (1) member may be a member of the administrative branch of government of the locality. The term of each of these two (2) members shall be coextensive with the term of office to which he has been elected or appointed, unless the governing body, at the first regular meeting each year, appoints others to serve as its representative. The remaining members of the commission first appointed shall serve respectively for terms of one (1) year, two (2) years, three (3) years and four (4) years divided equally or as nearly equal as possible between the membership. Subsequent appointments shall be for terms of four (4) years each. Vacancies shall be filled by appointment for the unexpired term only. Members may be removed for malfeasance in office. 
(Code 1971, § 2-45; Ord. No. 79-1700-130, 2-6-79; Ord. No. 96-1700-547a, 8-6-96; Ord. No. 02-1700-691, § 1, 9-3-02) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 2-143. - Functions, powers, duties and limitations. 
    The planning commission shall have the functions, powers and duties, and be subject to the limitations, which are prescribed by law, particularly those provided for in Code of Virginia, Title 15.2, Chapter 22, Articles 2 and 3. 
(Code 1971, § 2-46; Ord. No. 02-1700-691, § 1, 9-3-02) 
Sec. 2-144. - Where records kept. 
    All records of the planning commission shall be kept at the city office. 
(Code 1971, § 2-47) 
Secs. 2-145-2-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-1700-830, § 1, adopted May 15, 2007, amended the title of art. IX to read as herein set out. The former title was "Industrial Development Authority." 

Sec. 2-156. - Created; name. 
    There is hereby created a political subdivision of the commonwealth, the name of which shall be the "Economic Development Authority of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia". 
(Ord. No. 75-1700-70, §§ 1, 2, 2-18-75; Ord. No. 80-1700-156, 5-20-80; Ord. No. 07-1700-830, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 2-157. - Powers. 
    The authority created by section 2-156 above shall have such public and corporate powers as set forth in the Industrial Development and Revenue Bond Act, constituting Code of Virginia, § 15.2-4900 et seq., as amended, including, but not limited to, the following powers together with all powers incidental thereto or necessary for the performance of those hereinafter stated: 
(a)  To sue and be sued and to prosecute and defend, at law or in equity, in any court having jurisdiction of the subject matter and of the parties. 
(b)  To adopt and use a corporate seal and to alter the same at pleasure. 
(c)  To enter into contracts; however, any written contract of the authority shall contain provisions addressing the issue of whether attorney's fees shall be recoverable by the prevailing party in the event the contract is subject to litigation. 
(d)  To acquire, whether by purchase, exchange, gift, lease or otherwise, and to improve, maintain, equip and furnish one or more authority facilities including all real and personal properties which the board of directors of the authority may deem necessary in connection therewith and regardless of whether any such facilities shall then be in existence. 
(e)  To lease to others any or all of its facilities and to charge and collect rent therefor and to terminate any such lease upon the failure of the lessee to comply with any of the obligations thereof; and to include in any such lease, if desired, a provision that the lessee thereof shall have options to renew such lease or to purchase any or all of the leased facilities, or that upon payment of all of the indebtedness of the authority it may lease or convey any or all of its facilities to the lessee thereof with or without consideration. 
(f)  To sell, exchange, donate, and convey any or all of its facilities or properties whenever its board of directors shall find any such action to be in furtherance of the purposes for which the authority was organized. 
(g)  To issue its bonds for the purpose of carrying out any of its powers including specifically, but without intending to limit any power conferred by this section or this article, the issuance of bonds to provide long-term financing of any pollution control facility, whether any such facility was constructed prior to or after the enactment hereof or the receipt of a commitment from an authority to undertake financing pursuant hereto, unless the major part of the proceeds of such bonds will be used to redeem any prior long-term financing of such facility other than financings pursuant to this chapter or any similar law. 
(h)  As security for the payment of the principal of and interest on any bonds so issued and any agreements made in connection therewith, to mortgage and pledge any or all of its facilities or any part or parts thereof, whether then owned or thereafter acquired, and to pledge the revenues therefrom or from any part thereof or from any loans made by the authority. 
(i)  To employ and pay compensation to such employees and agents, including attorneys, and real estate brokers whether engaged by the authority or otherwise, as the board of directors shall deem necessary in carrying on the business of the authority. 
(j)  To exercise all powers expressly given the authority by the governing body and to establish bylaws and make all rules and regulations, not inconsistent with the provisions of this article, deemed expedient for the management of the authority's affairs. 
(k)  To appoint an industrial advisory committee or similar committee or committees to advise the authority, consisting of such number of persons as it may deem advisable. Such persons may be compensated such amount per regular, special, or committee meeting as may be approved by the appointing authority, not to exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) per meeting day, and may be reimbursed for necessary traveling and other expenses incurred while on the business of the authority. 
(l)  To borrow money and to accept contributions, grants and other financial assistance from the United States of America and agencies or instrumentalities thereof, the commonwealth, or any political subdivision, agency, or public instrumentality of the commonwealth, for or in aid of the construction, acquisition, ownership, maintenance or repair of the authority facilities, for the payment of principal of any bond of the authority, interest thereon, or other cost incident thereto, or in order to make loans in furtherance of the purposes of this article of such money, contributions, grants, and other financial assistance, and to this end the authority shall have the power to comply with such conditions and to execute such agreements, trust indentures, and other legal instruments as may be necessary, convenient or desirable and to agree to such terms and conditions as may be imposed. 
(m)  To make loans or grants to any person, partnership, association, corporation, business, or governmental entity in furtherance of the purposes of this article including for the purposes of promoting economic development, provided that such loans or grants shall be made only from revenues of the authority which have not been pledged or assigned for the payment of any of the authority's bonds, and to enter into such contracts, instruments, and agreements as may be expedient to provide for such loans and any security therefor. The authority may also be permitted to forgive loans or other obligations if it is deemed to further economic development. The word "revenues" as used in this subsection includes contributions, grants and other financial assistance, as set out in subsection (l) above. 
    The authority shall not have power to operate any facility as a business other than as lessor and shall not have the power to operate any single- or multifamily housing facilities. However, the authority shall have the power to apply for, establish, operate and maintain a foreign-trade zone in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 62.1-159 et seq., as amended. Any meeting held by the board of directors at which formal action is taken shall be open to the public. 
    No industrial development authority or economic development authority that has not been created by the governing body shall finance facilities, except pollution-control facilities, within the boundaries of the city, unless the governing body concurs with the inducement resolution adopted by the authority, and shows such concurrence in a duly adopted resolution. Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing contained herein shall be deemed to invalidate or otherwise impair any existing financing by an authority or the financing of any facilities for which application has been made to an authority prior to July 1, 1981. 
(Ord. No. 75-1700-70, § 1, 2-18-75; Ord. No. 89-1700-401, 6-20-89; Ord. No. 07-1700-830, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 2-158. - Where records to be kept. 
    All records of the economic development authority shall be kept at the city office. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-1700-830, § 1, adopted May 15, 2007, retitled Art. IX and amended §§ 2-156 and 2-157 to reflect the change from industrial development authority to economic development authority. At the editor's discretion and with the approval of the city, § 2-158 also was amended to eliminate conflict with the previous provisions. 
ARTICLE X. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS PROJECTS PROGRAM 

Sec. 2-159. - Planning commission to prepare and revise annually. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the planning commission, in cooperation with the planning division of the city manager's office, to prepare and revise annually a program of capital improvement projects for the ensuing five-year period, and to submit the program to the city manager annually, at such time as he shall direct. 
(b)  The program of capital improvement projects shall be based upon the city's comprehensive plan. 
(c)  In the preparation of each program of capital improvement projects, the planning commission shall consult with the city manager, the school board and superintendent of schools, the heads of departments and interested citizens and organizations, and shall hold such public hearings as it shall deem necessary, or as otherwise required by law. 
(d)  The program of capital improvement projects shall include, as the basis of the capital budget for the city, the planning commission's recommendations, estimates of costs of each project, and the method or methods of financing each project to be undertaken. 
(Ord. No. 82-1700-201, 8-17-82) 
Sec. 2-160. - Submission of capital improvement needs by each department, commission or board. 
    All capital improvement program material will be distributed by the city manager to each department, board or commission, including the school board, on the first working day of September. Each department, board or commission shall submit to the planning and zoning administrator, no later than the first working day of November, a detailed list of all immediate and long-range capital improvement needs or projects of its own department, commission or board; cost estimates of each need or project listed; the potential sources of funding for each need or project listed; and its recommendation as to the priority and timing of each need or project listed. 
(Ord. No. 82-1700-201, 8-17-82; Ord. No. 86-1700-329, 4-1-86) 
Sec. 2-161. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 86-1700-329, adopted April 1, 1986, deleted § 2-161, which pertained to the treasurer's report on the city's financial condition and derived from Ord. No. 82-1700-201, adopted Aug. 17, 1982. 
Sec. 2-162. - Submittal to city council. 
(a)  At the same time that the city manager submits the annual operating budget, the city manager shall submit to the council a program of proposed capital improvement projects including schools, previously acted upon by the planning commission, as provided in section 2-159 of this Code, for the ensuing fiscal year and for the four (4) fiscal years thereafter, with the city manager's recommendations as to the means of financing the improvements proposed for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(b)  The city manager shall submit with the program of proposed capital improvement projects a proposed ordinance which, if enacted, would make appropriations for the capital improvement projects proposed for the ensuing fiscal year, including the capital improvement projects proposed by the school board, and any ordinance or ordinances necessary to provide the revenue required to finance the proposed projects, unless such appropriations and revenues have been included in the revenue and appropriation ordinances for the general fund or for the water and sewer enterprise fund. 
(c)  Whenever the revenue for financing any capital improvement project or projects is to be derived from the sale of bonds, the bond ordinances need not be introduced at the time of submission of the program of proposed capital improvement project, but any appropriations for any project or projects to be so financed shall be contingent upon the issuance of such bonds being authorized in accordance with 2.5 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 82-1700-201, 8-17-82) 
Sec. 2-163. - Approval of city council. 
(a)  The council shall have power to accept with or without amendments, or reject, the proposed program of capital improvement projects and proposed means of financing for the ensuing fiscal year but, except in the case of emergency and except to meet needs for capital improvements arising out of annexation of additional territory taking effect during the current or preceding fiscal year and except to meet the needs for capital improvements which could not reasonably have been foreseen at the time of adoption of the capital budget, the council shall not authorize any capital improvement project or make any appropriation therefor unless the appropriation for such project is included in the capital budget as adopted by it. 
(b)  The council shall take final action on the program of capital improvement projects and on any revenue or appropriation ordinance submitted therewith, not later than the twenty-eight (28) days after the adoption of the general fund budget. Upon approval and adoption of the program of capital improvement projects, the first year's proposals of the five-year program shall constitute the capital budget of the city of the year it is enacted. 
(c)  The council shall in no event adopt a capital budget in which the total amount of expenditures for the ensuing fiscal year exceeds the estimated receipts unless at the same time council adopts measures for providing additional revenue in the ensuing fiscal year sufficient to make up the difference. 
(d)  No appropriation for a capital improvement project contained in the capital budget shall lapse until the purpose for which the appropriation was made shall have been accomplished or abandoned; provided that, a project shall be deemed to have been abandoned if after three (3) fiscal years from the appropriation, no expenditures from or encumbrances of the appropriation for the project have been made or incurred. Any such lapsed appropriation shall be applied to the payment of any indebtedness incurred in financing the project concerned, and if there be no such indebtedness shall be available for appropriation for another project in the next year's capital budget. 
(Ord. No. 82-1700-201, 8-17-82; Ord. No. 10-1000-892, 6-15-10) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 10-1000-892 approved June 15, 2010 stated "...that the Governing Body meeting in regular session on June 15, 2010 accepts the recommendation of the Planning Commission of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia and approves the FY2011-2016 Capital Improvements Program." 
Secs. 2-164-2-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PROCUREMENT PROCEDURES[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Article XI, §§ 2-171-2-175, is derived from Ord. of Jan. 18, 1983, which ordinance did not expressly amend this Code. 

Sec. 2-171. - Policy regarding competition in procurement. 
    It is the policy of the City of Manassas Park, in conformance with the Virginia Public Procurement Act, Virginia Code Annotated, section 11-35, et seq. (the act), in order to obtain high-quality goods and services at reasonable cost, that all procurement procedures be conducted in a fair and impartial manner with avoidance of any impropriety or appearance of impropriety; that all qualified vendors have access to public business and that no offeror be arbitrarily or capriciously excluded; that competition shall be sought to the maximum feasible degree and that rules relating to any contract award are to be made clear in advance of competition for the award and that specifications shall at all times reflect the procurement needs of the city and the same shall not be drawn on to favor a particular vendor. There shall be a free exchange of information with vendors and prospective contractors concerning what is sought to be procured and what is offered. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-213, § 1, 1-18-83) 
Sec. 2-172. - Procedure. 
    In furtherance of the foregoing policy, the City of Manassas Park shall follow the procedure for procurement of goods and services as set forth in and as defined by the Virginia Public Procurement Act, Virginia Code Annotated, section 11-35, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-213, § 2, 1-18-83) 
Sec. 2-173. - Responsibility for procurement. 
    The purchasing system for the City of Manassas Park shall be administered by and shall be under the direction and supervision of the city manager. Nothing contained in this article shall prevent the city manager from designating a responsible person or persons to perform the duties of purchasing agent, said agent to be subject at all times to the direction of the city manager. The city manager hereby is declared to be the official of the City of Manassas Park to receive the protest of any bidder or offeror regarding any award or decision to award a contract, as specified in the act. Prior to rendering any decision regarding any protest or any contractual claim, the city manager shall first consult and obtain the advice of the city attorney regarding conformance of such protest or dispute procedure and its disposition in accordance with the terms of the act. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-213, § 3, 1-18-83) 
Sec. 2-174. - Procedure for consideration of contractual claims. 
    Any contractual claims made against the city as provided in the act shall be submitted to the city manager in writing as provided by the act. In any event, all contracts which are the subject of any contractual claim shall require, and any claimant shall submit as a condition precedent to consideration of any claim, an invoice for final payment within forty-five (45) days after completion and acceptance of the work or acceptance of the goods which are the subject of the claim. Upon receipt of any claim, the city manager shall promptly arrange to hold a hearing with the claimant in order to permit the claimant fully to present the factual and legal basis for the claim. In any event, the city manager shall render his decision regarding the claim within forty-five (45) days from the date of submission of the claim and such decision shall be in writing and shall be deemed the final decision of the city for purposes of any condition precedent to invocation of administrative procedures or institution of legal action, all as provided by the act. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-213, § 4, 1-18-83) 
Sec. 2-175. - Small purchases. 
    Competitive sealed bids and/or competitive negotiation shall not be required for single or term contracts for goods and services other than professional services if the aggregate or the sum of all phases is not expected to exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00); provided, however, that competition must be used wherever practicable. Competitive negotiation shall not be required for single or term contracts for professional services if the aggregate or the sum of all phases is not expected to exceed sixty thousand dollars ($60,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-213, § 5, 1-18-83; Ord. No. 90-1700-429, 12-4-90; Ord. No. 83-1700-430, 12-18-90; Ord. No. 01-1700-665, § 1, 5-15-01; Ord. No. 14-1700-956, § 1, 6-3-14) 
Secs. 2-176-2-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - CITY ASSESSOR 

Sec. 2-181. - Office created. 
    In accordance with Virginia Code 58.1-3251 (1984 Repl. Vol.), this article creates the office of the city assessor for the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. The office of the city assessor shall consist of the city assessor and such other assessors and support personnel as the city council may direct. The city assessor shall be appointed by the city council and shall enjoy such terms and conditions of employment by contract as the city council or its designated representative may direct. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-425, 8-7-90; Ord. No. 90-1700-426, 8-21-90) 
Sec. 2-182. - General duties. 
(a)  The city assessor shall be responsible for the annual assessment and reassessment and equalization of assessment of real estate in the city, and shall value all real property and shall assess all taxes and related fees on all nonexempt real estate property within the city, in accordance with applicable law. 
(b)  The city assessor shall be responsible for the supervision, training and performance of all subordinate assessors and shall bear ultimate responsibility for their official actions. 
(c)  The city assessor shall be responsible for the administration and supervision of the office of the city assessor. 
(d)  The city assessor shall be responsible to maintain full and accurate records of assessments and valuation, including, but not limited to property appraisal cards or sheets required by Virginia Code 58-1332 (1984 Repl. Vol.). These records shall be subject to review by the city council, or its representative, during regular business hours. 
(e)  In order to effect a change to a July 1 effective date for real estate assessments and a fiscal year real estate tax, the reassessment for the fiscal year 2009-2010 real estate assessments shall take place on July 1, 2009 instead of January 1, 2009. Beginning on July 1, 2009, and thereafter, the annual assessment and reassessment and equalization of assessment for real estate in the city shall have an effective date of July 1. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-425, 8-7-90; Ord. No. 90-1700-426, 8-21-90; Ord. No. 08-1700-860, § 1, 11-18-08) 
Sec. 2-183. - Attendance at council meetings. 
    The city assessor shall attend the meetings of the city council and other public bodies as directed by the city council or the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-425, 8-7-90; Ord. No. 90-1700-426, 8-21-90) 
Sec. 2-184. - Article not to affect section 2-121. 
    This article does not affect the operation of section 2-121 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-425, 8-7-90; Ord. No. 90-1700-426, 8-21-90) 
Secs. 2-185-2-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - BOARD OF EQUALIZATION 

Sec. 2-201. - Board of equalization established. 
    In accordance with Virginia Code, § 58.1-3373, the governing body created a permanent board of equalization for the City of Manassas Park, Virginia on April 21, 1994. The board of equalization initially consisted of three (3) members appointed by the Circuit Court of Prince William County, Virginia as follows: one member was appointed for a term of one (1) year, one (1) member was appointed for a term of two (2) years, and one (1) member was appointed for a term of three (3) years, with each term expiring on June 30 of the appropriate year. Thereafter, upon expiration of each term, their successors have been and shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years. Effective July 1, 2008, however, the board of equalization shall be increased to five (5) members, with the two additional members to be appointed by the Circuit Court of Prince William County as follows: one (1) member shall be appointed for a term to expire on June 30, 2010, and one (1) member shall be appointed for a term to expire on June 30, 2011. Thereafter, upon expiration of each additional term, their successors shall be appointed for terms of three (3) years. The members of the board of equalization shall be freeholders in the city and citizens of the city. In order to be eligible for appointment, each prospective member of the board of equalization shall attend and participate in the basic course of instruction given by the department of taxation under Virginia Code § 58.1-206. Any vacancy occurring on the board of equalization shall be filled for the unexpired term by the Circuit Court of Prince William County, Virginia. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-463, § 1, 4-21-92; Ord. No. 08-1700-844, § 1, 2-19-08) 
Sec. 2-202. - General duties. 
    All duties imposed and all powers conferred by law at the review for equalization for assessments of real estate in the city shall be exercised by a board of equalization, which shall also have the power to review all assessments and changes of assessments previously made by the city assessor, the general reassessment board or any other assessing officer, board or authority in the city in accordance with Code of Virginia § 58.1-3250 et seq. The board of equalization shall have authority, on its own motion or upon protest as provided in this article, to change any assessment of real estate in the city, to add to the tax rolls any real estate erroneously omitted, to remove properties from tax rolls when acquired by owners not subject to taxation, and to correct errors in tax assessment records, in accordance with the policies and procedures described in this article. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-463, § 1, 4-21-92) 
Sec. 2-203. - Compensation. 
    Members of the board of equalization shall receive as compensation the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per day for each full day of service. In no event shall the members of the board of equalization receive compensation for more than fifteen (15) days per assessment, which should be sufficient time for the completion of the work of the board. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-463, § 1, 4-21-92; Ord. No. 14-1700-952, 5-20-14) 
Sec. 2-204. - Organization and assistance. 
    The board of equalization shall elect one (1) of its members as chairman and another member as secretary, and may employ necessary clerical and other assistance and call in advisors and fix their compensation, subject to the approval of the Manassas Park City Council. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-463, § 1, 4-21-92) 
Sec. 2-205. - Hearing. 
    The board of equalization shall establish the dates and times of hearings, as may be necessary to discharge the duties imposed and to exercise the powers conferred by this article. Of each hearing, public notice shall be given at least ten (10) days before by publication in a newspaper having general circulation in the city. 
(a)  Such notice shall inform the public that the board shall sit at the place or places and on the days named in the notice, for the purpose of equalizing real estate assessments in the city and for the purpose of hearing complaints of inequalities, when the property owners allege a lack of uniformity in assessment, or errors in acreage in such real estate assessments. 
(b)  Any owner of real property or affected taxpayer, any person with a substantial legal or equitable interest in the property involved, or any authorized representative of the city council may file a protest of any assessment affecting such property by June 1 of the calendar year for which the board was appointed, or within sixty (60) days from the date of assessment when an assessment has been made after May 1 of any year. Such protest shall be filed with the city assessor. The protest shall be transmitted within ten (10) days to the board of equalization, which shall grant appeal of the assessment or change of assessment as a matter of right, and shall accord the protestant an opportunity for hearing in person, with witnesses, by counsel, or by submission of memoranda verified under oath. The board of equalization may, in its discretion, grant an appeal and opportunity for hearing for just cause shown and on any protest filed after such date. Effective November 18, 2008, any owner of real property or affected taxpayer, any person with a substantial legal or equitable interest in the property involved, or any authorized representative of the governing body may file a protest of any assessment affecting such property by August 1 of the calendar year for which the board was appointed, or within sixty (60) days from the date of assessment when an assessment has been made after May 1 of any year. 
(c)  The board shall hear and give consideration to such complaints and equalize such assessments and shall, moreover, be charged with the especial duty of increasing as well as decreasing assessments, whether specific complaint be laid or not, if in its judgment, such a change is necessary to equalize and accomplish the end that the burden of taxation shall rest equally upon all citizens of the city. 
(d)  Hearing shall be scheduled by the board of equalization with due regard for the convenience of the protestant and with due regard for the time required by the city assessor to investigate the protest and to prepare justification of the protested assessment. 
(e)  In making the assessments or changes of assessments, the board of equalization and the city assessor shall be governed by the Constitution of Virginia, the provisions of the Code of Virginia, titles 15.2 and 58.1, the applicable provisions of other laws, and the provisions of this article. 
(f)  The board shall keep minutes of its meetings and enter in its minutes all orders made. 
(g)  The board shall have authority to summon taxpayers or their agents, or any person: (1) to furnish information relating to the real estate of any and all taxpayers; (2) to answer, under oath, all questions touching the ownership and value of real estate of any and all taxpayers, and (3) to bring before it their books of account or other papers and records containing information with respect to the valuation of real estate of the taxpayer or any other real estate subject to taxation within the city. Such summons may be served in person or by registered mail. 
(h)  Any person refusing to answer the summons of the board of equalization, to furnish information or to produce his books of account, papers or other records, as required by this article, shall be deemed guilty of a class 4 misdemeanor, and each day's failure to answer such summons, to furnish such information or produce such books of account, papers and other records shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-463, § 1, 4-21-92; Ord. No. 94-1700-510, 7-19-94; Ord. No. 07-1700-822, 2-20-07; Ord. No. 08-1700-860, § 2, 11-18-08) 
Sec. 2-206. - Decisions. 
(a)  The board of equalization shall determine and rule upon all protested assessments and all proposed reduced assessments within ninety (90) days from the date of hearing. All actions of the board affecting assessments of real estate in the city shall be certified by the board to the city assessor on forms prepared by and prescribed by the city assessor and shall cease as of December 31 of each year. Notice of the decision of the board of equalization shall be prepared in triplicate, and a copy shall be given to the protestant and to the affected taxpayer by the city assessor through the mails, within ten days after the decision is certified. 
(b)  The board shall hear and determine any and all such petitions and, by order, may increase, decrease or affirm the assessment of which complaint is made; and, by order, it may increase or decrease any assessment, upon its own motion. No assessment shall be increased until after the owner of the property has been notified and given an opportunity to show cause against such increase, unless such owner has already been heard. 
(c)  The board may direct the city assessor to enter upon the land book and property appraisal cards real estate which is found to have been omitted, and to cancel duplicate assessments of real estate. 
(d)  The city assessor shall make in the land book and in the property appraisal cards or sheets the changes ordered by the board and, if such changes affect the land book and the property appraisal cards or sheets for the then-current year, the city assessor may for that year make a supplemental assessment in case of an increase in valuation. In case of a decrease in valuation, the order of the board shall entitle the taxpayer to an exoneration from so much of the assessment as exceeds the proper amount, if the taxes have been paid by him and, in case the taxes have been paid, to a refund of so much of the taxes found erroneous. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-463, § 1, 4-21-92) 
Sec. 2-207. - Appeal. 
    The city attorney or any taxpayer, aggrieved by any such order of the board, may apply to the Circuit Court for Prince William County, Virginia, for the correction and revision of such order, in the same manner and within the same time as is provided by law for the correction of erroneous assessments of real estate by any person who is aggrieved. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-463, § 1, 4-21-92) 
ARTICLE XIV. - RESERVED[12]

ARTICLE XV. - SALE OF SURPLUS EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 2-216. - Designation of surplus equipment. 
    After a department of the city notifies the city manager that the department no longer can use properly in its operation any piece of equipment or other publicly-owned personal property ("equipment"), the equipment shall be deemed to be surplus and in accordance with the authority granted in section 2-73, the city manager may dispose of the equipment in accordance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-1700-518, 12-6-94) 
Sec. 2-217. - Procedure for sale. 
(a)  Other use. After any equipment has been declared as surplus by any department, the city manager shall first determine whether there exists within the city any other use of the equipment or any other department of the city which may use the equipment. 
(b)  Approval. After approval of the city council, the city manager may proceed to sell the equipment. Under normal circumstances, the sale shall be either at public auction or by securing sealed bids. In exceptional circumstances, however, for reasons which shall be fully documented by the city manager, the city manager has the sole discretion to decide that certain equipment shall be sold without the requirement for public auction or sealed bids. Before publishing notice of the proposed sale of any surplus equipment, the city manager shall attempt to establish the reasonable market value of the equipment, by appraisal or otherwise. 
(c)  Notice. Notice of the time and place of sale, if by public auction, and notice of sale, if sealed bids are to be sought, shall be given by advertisement in a newspaper having general circulation in the city. The city manager shall designate the time and place of any such public auction or shall designate the time, place and manner for receipt and opening of any such sealed bids. At least thirty (30) days shall elapse between publication of such notice and the auction or the date on which sealed bids will be opened. The notice shall set forth the conditions required for the sale of the equipment, which conditions may include any of those set forth in paragraph (d) below. 
(d)  Conditions for sale. The city manager may designate any conditions to apply to the sale of any surplus equipment, including but not limited to the following conditions: 
(1)  The city manager shall have the right to establish a minimum bid requirement and shall publish such minimum bid requirement in the public notice of sale. 
(2)  City officials and city employees shall not be permitted to purchase equipment sold pursuant to this article. 
(3)  The city manager shall have the right to withdraw any piece of equipment from the sale, at any time, before the city treasurer receives full and complete consideration for the purchase of such equipment. 
(4)  Unless otherwise required, all surplus equipment shall be advertised for sale in an "as is" condition. 
(5)  The city manager shall be responsible to insure that any equipment advertised for sale under this article, which equipment was originally purchased through bond proceeds, shall first be deemed to be subject to sale by these procedures. 
(6)  In the event any of the equipment noticed for sale pursuant to this article is not sold by the designated procedure, for whatever reason, the city manager shall have the authority to dispose of the equipment as he deems appropriate, in his sole discretion. 
(e)  Transfer. 
(1)  In the event the equipment is sold at public auction, the purchaser shall pay for such equipment at the time of the auction and shall remove the equipment from the premises at the time of sale. 
(2)  In the event the equipment is sold by sealed bids, the city manager shall notify the highest bidder in writing within three (3) business days following the opening of the bids. The purchaser shall be notified to purchase the equipment and remove the equipment from the premises within ten (10) business days following the opening of the bids. 
(3)  The city manager shall be responsible to insure that the transfer of all ownership documents, is complete. 
(Ord. No. 94-1700-518, 12-6-94) 
Secs. 2-218-2-224. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - PARK CENTER COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-225. - Creation of authority. 
    The Park Center Community Development Authority is hereby created as a body corporate and politic and political subdivision of the commonwealth in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Act [Code of Virginia, ch. 51, tit. 15.2]. The CDA shall have the powers set forth in the Act. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-820, § 1, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 2-226. - Boundaries of CDA. 
    The CDA boundaries shall initially include the property identified as tax map parcels 24-A-7, 24-A-B, 25-1-2, 25-1-3, 25-1-4 and 25-3-1B, all as more particularly depicted on the map attached as exhibit A (the "CDA district"). In accordance with § 15.2-5157 of the Act [Code of Virginia, § 15.2-5157], a copy of the ordinance creating this article shall be recorded in the land records of the Circuit Court of Prince William County for each tax map parcel in the CDA district as such CDA district exists at the time of issuance of the CDA's bonds (the "bonds") and the CDA district shall be noted on the land records of the city. The CDA board may release or exclude from the CDA district at any time before or after the issuance of the bonds certain de minimis portions of land not to exceed approximately one acre. In addition, the CDA board may release and exclude from the CDA district parcels of land with respect to which all special assessments have been paid or prepaid. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-820, § 2, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 2-227. - Facilities and services. 
    The CDA is created for the purpose of exercising the powers set forth in the Act, including financing, acquiring, constructing and developing, operating and maintaining, if necessary, certain improvements in connection with the development of the property as described in the petition and the articles of incorporation. The CDA shall have all the powers provided by the Act. The CDA shall not provide services which are provided by, or obligated to be provided by, any authority already in existence pursuant to the Act unless such authority provides the certification required by § 15.2-5155 of the Act [Code of Virginia, § 15.2-5155]. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-820, § 3, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 2-228. - Articles of incorporation. 
    Attached hereto as exhibit B are the proposed articles of incorporation of the CDA. The city manager is authorized and directed to execute and file such articles of incorporation on behalf of the governing body with the State Corporation Commission in substantially the form attached as exhibit B with such changes, including insubstantial changes to the boundary description of the CDA district described therein, as the city manager may approve. The city manager is authorized to approve such changes or corrections to the articles of incorporation prior to filing with the State Corporation Commission as do not change the purpose or function of the CDA as set forth in this article and in the petition. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-820, § 4, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 2-229. - Capital cost estimates. 
    The governing body hereby finds, in accordance with § 15.2-5103(B) of the Act [Code of Virginia, § 15.2-5103(B)], that it is impracticable to include capital cost estimates, project proposals and project service rates, except as summarized in the petition. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-820, § 5, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 2-230. - Membership of the authority. 
(a)  The powers of the CDA shall be exercised by an authority board consisting of five (5) members. 
(b)  All members of the CDA board shall be appointed by the governing body in accordance with the provisions of § 15.2-5113 of the Act [Code of Virginia, § 15.2-5113]. 
(c)  The initial members of the CDA board shall be as set forth in the articles of incorporation for the terms set forth herein. 
(d)  Each CDA board member shall receive such compensation for his or her services as a CDA board member as may be authorized from time to time by resolution of the CDA board, provided that no member shall receive compensation in excess of three hundred dollars ($300.00) per meeting attended unless authorized by resolution of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-820, § 6, 1-9-07) 
Sec. 2-231. - Plan of finance; issuance of bonds. 
(a)  The improvements, services and operations to be undertaken by the CDA as described herein and in the petition shall be funded from all or some of the following sources: 
(i)  Bonds to be issued by the CDA; 
(ii)  Special assessments to be levied pursuant to § 15.2-5158(A)(5) of the Act [Code of Virginia, § 15.2-5158(A)(5)]; and 
(iii)  Any other source of funding available to the CDA including rates, fees and charges to be levied by the CDA for the services and facilities provided or funded by the CDA. 
(b)  The bonds to be issued by the CDA will be in the maximum aggregate principal amount of twenty-three million dollars ($23,000,000.00), will have no more than a forty-year debt schedule, and will be used to pay the costs of certain infrastructure and services as described herein and in the petition, the costs of issuing the bonds and any required reserves, and interest on the bonds prior to and during construction and for a period up to one (1) year after completion. 
(c)  Any bonds issued by the CDA or any other financing arrangements entered into by the CDA will be debt of the CDA, will not be a debt or other obligation of the city and will not constitute a pledge of the faith and credit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-820, § 7, 1-9-07)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 3-1-3-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OUTDOOR ADVERTISING SIGNS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 89-1700-394, enacted March 7, 1989, repealed former §§ 13-16 and 13-18-13-21, and further specified that § 13-17 remain as codified. Former §§ 13-16 and 13-18-13-20, definitions, article violations, permit requirements and bond, derived from Ord. No. 77-1000-93, adopted Jan. 4, 1977, and former § 13-21, erection over city owned property, derived from Ord. No. 78-1700-117, adopted April 11, 1978. 

Sec. 3-16. - Reserved. 
Sec. 3-17. - Exemptions from article. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  Signs having an area of not more than two (2) square feet, the message of which is limited to conveying street numbers, the name of the premises, the name of the owner of the premises and the name of the occupant of the premises. 
(2)  Signs having an area of not more than six (6) square feet, the message of which is limited to warning of any danger, prohibition or regulation of the use of property or traffic or parking thereon, or advertising the premises for sale or rent. 
(3)  The flag of any state or nation respectfully displayed. 
(4)  Signs located on the rolling stock of common carriers or on motor vehicles or trailers bearing current license plates which are travelling or lawfully parked upon public highways, or lawfully parked upon any other premises for a period not exceeding four (4) hours, or for a longer period where the primary purpose of such parking is not the display of any sign and where the number of vehicles bearing a sign or signs of any one advertiser does not exceed one plus one more for each twenty-five thousand (25,000) square feet of area of the premises. 
(5)  Church or institutional bulletin boards without interior illumination having an area not exceeding thirty-two (32) square feet. 
(6)  On-premises signs located inside an enclosed building and visible through a window or windows thereof where the area of such signs does not exceed twenty (20) per cent of the area of the window or windows. 
(7)  Any and all signs advocating or opposing a candidate for public office or a position on an issue. 
(8)  Signs visible only from the premises on which located or visible off the premises only through a window or windows from which they are set back at least ten (10) feet. 
(9)  Labels identifying the source, brand name or manufacturer of merchandise exhibited for sale. 
(10)  Signs indicating only the date of erection of a building and having an area not exceeding six (6) square feet. 
(11)  Signs posted by duly constituted public authorities in pursuance of their public duties. 
(Ord. No. 77-1000-93, 1-4-77; Ord. No. 77-1700-109, 10-4-77; Ord. No. 89-1700-394, 3-7-89) 
Chapter 4 - AMUSEMENTS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 4-1-4-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC DANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- License tax for dance halls, § 14-59. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate public dance halls, § 18.2-433. 

Sec. 4-16. - Definition. 
    For the purpose of this article, the word "adult" means a person eighteen (18) years of age or older. 
(Code 1971, § 7-2) 
Sec. 4-17. - Application of article. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to individual public dances. 
(Code 1971, § 7-3) 
Sec. 4-18. - Violations of article. 
    Any violation of any provision of this article shall constitute a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
Sec. 4-19. - Permit. 
(a)  Any person proposing to hold a public dance shall obtain a permit therefor from the city manager. Application for such permit shall be filed with the city manager in such form and shall give such information as the manager may require. 
(b)  Upon the filing of an application under this section, and upon payment of a fee of two dollars ($2.00) to the city treasurer, the city manager shall issue the permit applied for, if he is satisfied that the provisions of this article will be complied with. 
(Code 1971, §§ 7-12-7-14) 
Sec. 4-20. - Applicability of rules and regulations of alcoholic beverage control board. 
    All applicable rules and regulations of the state alcoholic beverage control board shall be in full force and effect during the conduct of a public dance. 
(Code 1971, § 7-4) 
Sec. 4-21. - Rules and regulations of city manager. 
    The city manager may make and promulgate such rules and regulations, in addition to the provisions of this article, as he may deem requisite for the proper conduct of a public dance. When such rules and regulations are approved by the council and filed with the city clerk, it shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations so made and promulgated. 
(Code 1971, § 7-11) 
Sec. 4-22. - Permitted days. 
    Public dances may be held only on Friday night and Saturday night; provided, however, a public dance may be held on the evening before and the evening of any national holiday, but no public dance may be held on such holiday when such holiday falls on a Sunday. 
(Code 1971, § 7-9) 
Sec. 4-23. - Permitted hours. 
    The hours for public dances shall be between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 1:00 a.m., except on December 31 when the permitted hours shall be between 7:30 p.m. and 2:00 a.m. 
(Code 1971, § 7-8; Ord. No. 81-1700-184, 12-1-81) 
Sec. 4-24. - Attendance at adult dances by minors. 
(a)  No person who is not an adult may attend an adult public dance, unless such person is the spouse of an adult patron attending the dance. 
(b)  At any adult public dance, the manager or holder of the permit issued pursuant to section 7-14, pursuant to which the public dance in question is conducted, may require of any patron that he produce evidence of his age prior to his admission to the dance. 
(Code 1971, §§ 7-6, 7-7) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate frequenting of public places of amusement by minors, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-432. 
Sec. 4-25. - Conduct of patrons generally. 
    Patrons at public dances shall conduct themselves in a reasonable and orderly manner. 
(Code 1971, § 7-5) 
Sec. 4-26. - Observance of applicable state laws and ordinances. 
    In addition to the provisions of this article, all applicable state laws and provisions of this Code and other ordinances of the city shall be observed by patrons at public dances at all times. 
(Code 1971, § 7-10) 
Chapter 5 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, adopted March 7, 2000, amended former Ch. 5, Arts. I-V, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 5 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1971 and the following ordinances: 
Ord. No. Date 76-1700-80  1- 6-76 77-1700-108  9- 6-77 79-1700-131  2- 6-79 83-1700-212  1-18-83  
Ord. No. Date 92-1700-463a  5-19-92 92-1700-479 12- 1-92 93-1700-483  3- 2-93 93-1700-498  2- 1-94

State Law reference- Comprehensive Animal Laws, § 3.1-796.66 et seq.; offenses involving animals, § 18.2-403.1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 5-1. - Keeping of livestock. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any livestock; any animals of the genus llama, alpaca, horse, mule, any other equines; cow, sheep, goat, pig, swine, chickens, duck, and other poultry and fowl; and similar utilitarian animals or any other livestock animal within the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-2. - Reserved. 
Sec. 5-3. - Misrepresentation of animal's conditions; penalties. 
    No person shall misrepresent the physical condition of any animal at the animal's sale, trade, delivery, or other method of transfer. For the purpose of this section, misrepresentation shall include selling, trading, delivering or otherwise transferring an animal to another person with the knowledge that the animal has an infection, communicable disease, parasitic infestation, abnormality or other physical defect that is not made known to the person receiving the animal. Violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
State Law reference- Misrepresentation of animal's conditions; penalties; § 3.1-796.72. 
Sec. 5-4. - Fowl at large. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to permit fowl kept by him or under his control to stray or escape from his premises on the streets or sidewalks or upon the property of others. Violation of this section will be a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-5. - Keeping diseased animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly own, keep or harbor in the city any animal suffering or afflicted with any infectious or contagious disease. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-6. - Cruelty to animals; trapping and/or poisoning prohibited. 
(a)  No person shall: 
(1)  Override, overdrive, overload, torture, ill-treat, abandon, willfully inflict inhumane injury or pain not connected with bona fide scientific or medical experimentation, or cruelly or unnecessarily beat, maim, mutilate, or kill any animal, whether belonging to himself or another; or deprive any animal of necessary sustenance, food, drink, shelter or emergency veterinary treatment; 
(2)  Willfully set on foot, instigate, engage in, or in any way further any act of cruelty to an animal; 
(3)  Carry or cause to be carried in or upon any vehicle, vessel, or otherwise any animal in a cruel, brutal, or inhumane manner, so as to produce torture or unnecessary suffering; or cause any of the above things, or being the owner or custodian of such animal permit such acts to be done by another. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the dehorning of cattle. Violation of this section shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  Any person who (i) tortures, willfully inflicts inhumane injury or pain not connected with bona fide scientific or medical experimentation, or cruelly and unnecessarily beats, maims, mutilates or kills any animal whether belonging to himself or another; or (ii) instigates, engages in, or in any way furthers any act or cruelty to any animal set forth in clause (i) of this subsection; or (iii) causes any of the actions described in subdivisions (i) and (ii) of this subsection, or being the owner of such animal permits such acts to be done by another; and has been within five years convicted of a violation of this subsection or subsection (a), shall be guilty of a Class 6 felony if the current violation or any previous violation of this subsection or subsection (a) resulted in the death of an animal or the euthanasia of an animal based on the recommendation of a licensed veterinarian upon determination that such euthanasia was necessary due to the condition of the animal, and such condition was a direct result of a violation of this subsection or subsection (a). 
(c)  Any person who abandons any dog, cat or other domesticated animal in any public place including the right-of-way of any public highway, road or street or on the property of another shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(d)  For the purposes of this section, the word animal shall be construed to include birds and fowl. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to set or bait any trap or other contrivance for the catching of game or tame animals, or to knowingly permit any such trap to be set or baited on his premises or property or to set out any poisoned bait with the intent of poisoning any game or tame animal except by the consent of the city animal control officer or state game warden. 
(f)  This section shall not prohibit authorized wildlife management activities of hunting, fishing or trapping as otherwise regulated under the Code of Virginia, including, but not limited to Title 20.1 of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended, or to farming activities as provided under this title or regulations promulgated thereto. 
(g)  In addition to the penalties provided in subparagraph (a) above, the court may, in its discretion, require any person convicted of a violation of subparagraph (a) above to attend an anger management or other appropriate treatment program or obtain psychiatric or psychological counseling. The court may impose the costs of such a program or counseling upon the person convicted. 
(h)  It is unlawful for any person to kill a domestic dog or cat for the purpose of obtaining the hide, fur or pelt of the dog or cat. A violation of this subsection shall constitute a Class 1 misdemeanor. A second or subsequent violation of this subsection shall constitute a Class 6 felony. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
State Law reference- Cruelty to animals, § 3.1-796.122 
Sec. 5-7. - Disposition of dead animals. 
(a)  If any animal dies in the city, the owner or custodian of such animal shall at once dispose of the same in a manner satisfactory to the health officer. It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of a dead animal to fail to dispose of or knowingly permit any dead animal to remain unburied upon his property when offensive to the public or, having in custody any maimed, diseased, disabled or infirm animal, to leave it to lie or be in a street, road or public place. A violation of this section shall constitute a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  When the owner or custodian of a dead animal is unknown, the dead animal shall be disposed of by the city, and if its owner or custodian is subsequently ascertained, he shall be charged a fee of ten ($10.00) dollars for an animal under thirty (30) pounds, and for an animal over thirty (30) pounds, he shall be charged a fee of twenty ($20.00) dollars, in addition to the penalty imposed for violating this section. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
State Law reference- Leaving disabled or dead animals in road, or allowing dead animals to remain unburied, § 18.2-323; disposal of dead or companion animals, § 3.1-796.121. 
Sec. 5-8. - Fee for boarding animals at city impoundment facility. 
    When an animal is voluntarily taken to the city's impoundment facility by the owner or if the animal control officer or police officer is called to impound an animal or an animal is picked up for being at large in the city, a fee will be charged for each animal. Administrative/first day fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) and a ten-dollar ($10.00) boarding fee for each additional day will be charged until the animal is adopted or is disposed of by the animal control officer in a humane way. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-9. - Noisy animal generally. 
(a)  No person shall, on his own property or on any property in which he has any interest or over which he exercised any control, keep, maintain or allow to remain any animal which sets up, causes, emits or gives vent to noise or commotion of such a character or kind as to disturb any citizen of the city in the reasonable use and enjoyment of his property or to cause any person of ordinary sensibilities any actual physical discomfort. Each day that any person maintains or keeps or permits anyone else to maintain or keep on his premises or on any property in which he has any interest, or over which he has any control any such animal or fowl, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person convicted of violating this section shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and no more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or may have the animal removed from the premises or both. 
(c)  The keeping by any person of any animal or fowl in violation of this section shall constitute a nuisance and may be abated by law. Such remedy shall be in addition to and not in lieu of the penalty provided for the violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-10. - Bee keeping. 
(a)  No person owning, leasing, occupying or having charge of any premise within the residential area of the city as established by the zoning ordinance shall maintain an apiary or keep any bees or hive of bees thereon. 
(b)  A fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall punish any person convicted of a violation of this section. Each day any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
State Law reference- State code for definition, § 3.1-610.1 
Secs. 5-11-5-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DEFINITIONS AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 5-19. - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different intention, the following words and terms shall, for the purpose of this article, have the following meanings: 
    Abandon : To desert, forsake, or absolutely give up an animal without having secured another owner or custodian for the animal or by failing to provide the elements of basic care for a period of five (5) consecutive days. 
    Adequate care: "Care," the responsible practice of good animal husbandry, handling, production, management, confinement, feeding, watering, protection, shelter, transportation, treatment, and when necessary, euthanasia, appropriate for the age, species, condition, size and type of the animal and the provision of veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering or impairment of health. 
    Adoption: The transfer of ownership of a dog or cat from a releasing agency to an individual. 
    Animal shelter: A facility which is used to house or contain animals and which is owned, operated, or maintained by a duly incorporated humane society, animal welfare society, society for the prevention of cruelty to animals, or other nonprofit organization devoted to the welfare, protection and humane treatment of animals. 
    Animal control officer: Any person authorized to enforce the provisions of this article or his/ her duly authorized agent. 
    At large: To run at large or running at large or to go at large or going at large shall mean to roam, loiter, walk, run or be off the premises of the owner or custodian without being caged, physically carried or held by a leash, cord or chain by a person thoroughly capable, both physically and mentally, of controlling the animal. 
    Collar: A well-fitted device, appropriate to the age and size of the animal, attached to the animals neck in such a way as to prevent trauma or injury to the animal. 
    Custodian: Any person who has the responsibility to guard, protect or maintain another persons dog or cat or pet. 
    Destructive animal: Any animal that has frequently or habitually injured or destroyed property or performed an act, which might reasonably lead to the destruction or injury of property of any person other than the owner or custodian thereof, or any animal that has frequently or habitually turned over or torn open garbage containers. 
    Direct and immediate threat: Means any clear and imminent danger to an animal's health, safety or life. 
    Enclosure: A structure used to house or restrict animals from running at large. 
    Humane: Any action taken in consideration of and with the intent to provide for the animal's health and well-being. 
    Kennel: Any building, enclosure, or premises used, designed or arranged for the boarding, breeding, or care of, or wherein more than three (3) canines, or four (4) felines, or a combination of more than four (4) pets or domestic animals are kept, that have attained the age of four (4) months. 
    Livestock: Any animals of the genus llama, alpaca, horse, mule, and other equines; cow, sheep, goat, pig, swine, chicken, duck, and other poultry and fowl; and similar utilitarian animals or hare raised for human food or fiber; or any other individual animals specifically raised for food or fiber. 
    New owner: An individual who is legally competent to enter into a binding agreement pursuant to subdivision B-2 of the state code 3.1-796.126:1, and who adopts or receives a dog or cat from releasing agency. 
    To neuter means: For a male animal, to castrate, and for a female animal, to spay. 
    Noisy animal: Any animal that has, by loud, frequent barking, howling or crying, or other noises, caused annoyance or disturbed the peace and quiet of any person or persons in the neighborhood, as witnessed by a duly registered complaint. 
    Owner: Any person, who has a right of property in an animal, keeps or harbors an animal, has an animal in his care, or acts as custodian of an animal. 
    Unlicensed dog or cat: Any dog or cat without a valid license tag attached. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 02-1700-686, § 1, 5-21-02) 
Sec. 5-20. - Enforcement of article. 
    The animal control officers, or his/her authorized agent, police officers, or health officers shall enforce the provisions of these articles. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-20.1. - Violations of article. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, a violation of any provisions of these articles shall constitute a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-21. - Kennels not to be located in residential area. 
    No person shall locate, operate or maintain any kennel in the residential area of the city. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS, CATS AND OTHER ANIMALS 

Sec. 5-22. - Run at large prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or the custodian of any dog to allow such dog, whether licensed or unlicensed, to run at large in the city at any time. 
(b)  Upon a person being charged for a third time in a twelve (12) month period with the offense of allowing dog to run at large, the fine shall not be prepayable, and the animal control officer shall provide written notice to the owner (if known to the animal control officer) that the dog must be neutered, if it has not already been. The owner must arrange for a veterinarian to have the dog neutered or provide the animal control officer with a notarized statement of a veterinarian identifying the dog and stating that it has been neutered. 
The animal control officer shall keep the dog in his/her custody until the neutering or proof of neutering occurs unless, in the animal control officer's reasonable opinion, the dog owner can adequately confine the dog and will neuter it or provide proof of neutering. If the owner does not arrange for neutering, provide proof of neutering, or demand trial on the charge of running at large within five (5) days after receiving the written notice, the dog shall be deemed abandoned and the animal control officer may dispose of the animal in any lawful manner. The written notice to the owner shall include this section and shall state the penalty for its violation. 
(c)  If the owner is acquitted of the running at large offense, the dog shall be released to him without being neutered. If the owner is convicted and does not provide proof of neutering, the court shall order him or her to pay the cost of the dog's neutering, and the animal control officer shall deliver the dog to a veterinarian for neutering. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-23. - Impoundment of animal running at large; adoption of unclaimed animals; destruction of unclaimed animals. 
(a)  Any animal running at large in the city shall be impounded and kept at the city impounding facility for a period of five (5) days, during which time the animal control officer shall make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner, if known. Licensed, or collared, or tattooed animals shall be kept at the city impounding facility for a period of ten (10) days, during which time the animal control officer shall make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner. The animal may be released to the owner upon payment of a boarding fee at the animal shelter. In the case of an unlicensed dog or cat, the owner shall purchase a license. In no case shall an animal be released until all requirements for licensing are met. 
(b)  To adopt an unclaimed dog or cat, the prospective owner shall pay an administration fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) for the animal, in addition to paying any required licensing fee. The prospective owner shall sign a statement that the owner will have the animal spayed/neutered within thirty (30) days of adoption or, in the event the animal is younger than six (6) months old, that the owner will have the animal spayed/neutered within thirty (30) days after the animal has reached six (6) months of age. Within six (6) months from the date of adoption, the animal control officer shall have a signed certificate from a licensed veterinarian that the animal has been spayed/neutered in accordance with this section. The new owner shall sign an agreement permitting the animal control officer to reclaim the animal in the event the new owner fails to comply with the requirements, as required by this section. 
(c)  If an unlicensed animal remains unclaimed after required holding time, it shall be the duty of the animal control officer to authorize the disposal of the animal in a humane way. 
(d)  Any person who violates subsection (b) of this section shall be subject to a civil penalty not to exceed one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-24. - Killing certain dogs and cats at large which cannot safely be impounded. 
    If any vicious or dangerous dog or cat or any dog or cat suspected of having rabies, which is found at large, cannot be safely taken and impounded, such dog or cat may be humanely destroyed by any police officer or animal control officer without recourse. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00) 
Sec. 5-25. - Allowing animals to urinate or defecate on public property and property of another. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or willingly allow any animal belonging to or under the supervision or care of such person to defecate on any public property or the property of another, or to knowingly or willingly allow any such animal to urinate on any public property or the property of another if such urination causes property damage, without the consent of the owner of the property or his agent, provided that it shall not be unlawful to allow urination or defecation by such animal within the curb or gutter area of a public street or roadway if the owner of the animal removes all the animal's excrement promptly and disposes of it in a public trash receptacle, in a public sanitary sewer, or on the owner's own property in a lawful manner. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 14-1700-954, § 1, 6-3-14) 
Sec. 5-26. - Animals causing unsanitary conditions or offensive odors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person who owns, keeps or controls any animal to keep that animal in such a manner as to cause unsanitary conditions or to cause offensive odors beyond the confines of the owner's own property. 
(Ord. No. 00-1700-620, § 1, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 14-1700-954, § 1, 6-3-14) 
Sec. 5-27. - Vicious or dangerous dogs. 
(a)  As used in this section, "Dangerous dogs" means a canine or canine crossbreed which has bitten, attacked, or inflicted injury on a person or companion animal, other than a dog, or killed a companion animal, and "Vicious dog" means a canine or canine crossbreed which has (i) killed a person; (ii) inflicted serious injury to a person, including multiple bites, serious disfigurement, serious impairment of health, or serious impairment of a bodily function; or (iii) continued to exhibit the behavior which resulted in a previous finding by a court that it is a dangerous dog, provided that its owner has been given notice of that finding. 
(1)  Any animal control officer who has reason to believe that a canine or canine crossbreed within the city is a dangerous dog or vicious dog shall apply to a magistrate for the issuance of a summons requiring the owner or custodian, if known, to appear before a general district court at a specified time. The summons shall advise the owner of the nature of the proceeding and the matters at issue. If the animal poses a substantial risk to humans or other animals, the animal control officer or owner or custodian shall confine the animal until such time as evidence shall be heard and a verdict rendered. If the animal does not pose such a risk or the owner or custodian can adequately confine the animal without risk of its escape, the animal control officer or police officer shall order the owner or custodian to keep the animal confined inside a dwelling until such time as evidence may be heard and a verdict rendered. If the animal control officer or police officer orders such confinement, the animal may not be removed from the owner's or custodian's immediate property and shall be secured on a leash no longer than six (6) feet when not confined indoors or locked within an adequate structure. Failure to comply with such an order shall be a violation of this section. The court, through its contempt powers, may compel the owner, custodian or harborer of the animal to produce the animal. If, after hearing the evidence, the court finds that the animal is a dangerous dog, the court shall order the animal's owner to comply with the provisions of the ordinance. If, after hearing the evidence, the court finds that the animal is a vicious dog, the court shall order the animal euthanized in accordance with the provisions of section 3.1-796.119 of the Code of Virginia. 
(2)  No canine or canine crossbreed shall be found to be a dangerous dog or vicious dog solely because it is a particular breed, nor shall the local governing body prohibit the ownership of a particular breed of canine or canine crossbreed.
