    Any fireworks that remain unfired after a display pursuant to a permit issued under this division is concluded shall be immediately disposed of in a way safe for the particular type of fireworks remaining. 
(a)  Operators shall comply with N.F.P.A. 1123 Aerial Fireworks Display. 
(b)  Operators shall comply with N.F.P.A. 1126. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Secs. 9-70, 9-71. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - RESERVED. 

Secs. 9-72-9-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SMOKE DETECTORS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Smoke detectors in certain buildings, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-29.9. 

Sec. 9-80. - Definitions. 
    As used in this section, the following words shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them: 
    Dwelling unit shall mean a single unit providing complete independent living facilities for one (1) or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking, and sanitation. 
    Owner shall mean one (1) or more persons, jointly or severally, in whom is vested: 
(1)  All or part of the legal title to the property; or 
(2)  All or part of the beneficial ownership and a right to present use and enjoyment of the premises, and the term includes a mortgagee in possession. 
    Smoke detectors shall mean mechanical devices, powered by batteries or alternating current, capable of sensing visible or invisible products of combustion, that sound an audible alarm, and are approved by a nationally recognized testing laboratory. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-81. - Where required. 
    Smoke detectors shall be installed where required by applicable provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code or the applicable provisions of the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-82. - Enforcement. 
    The fire marshal or his duly authorized representative is authorized to administer and enforce this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-85. - Article not deemed exemption from compliance with building code. 
    Nothing in this article shall excuse any owner of the required buildings from compliance with all other applicable provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-86. - Penalty for violations. 
    A violation of this article shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Secs. 9-87-9-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 9-100. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to regulate the use and operation of security and fire alarm systems in premises to which the fire department is expected to respond in order to reduce the number of false alarms and to protect the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-101. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions apply: 
(a)  Alarm board. The facility, located in the communications section of the fire department, which is designed to receive direct signals from authorized alarm systems. 
(b)  Automatic dialing device. A device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and to transmit, by prerecorded voice message or code signal, the existence of criminal activity or a fire at the protected premises. 
(c)  Bank. A financial institution which is required by regulations, issued pursuant to the Bank Protection Act of 1968, to maintain an alarm system or other appropriate device for promptly notifying a local police department that a robbery or burglary has occurred or is in progress. 
(d)  False alarm. Any communication generated by or as a result of a security or fire alarm system, which communication results in an investigation by the fire department, when the investigation reveals no evidence or indication of criminal activity or other actual hazard. False alarms include negligently or accidentally activated signals; signals, which are the result of faulty, malfunctioning, or improperly installed or maintained equipment; signals, which are purposely activated to summon the fire department in nonemergency situations; and signals for which the actual cause is not determined. False alarms shall not include signals activated by unusually severe weather conditions or by other causes, which are identified and determined by fire department to be beyond the control of the user. 
(e)  Hazard. An event requiring urgent attention and to which the fire department is expected to respond. 
(f)  Person. Any individual, firm, partnership, association, company, corporation or organization of any kind. 
(g)  Protected premises. The premises upon which a security or fire alarm system is located. 
(h)  Security or fire alarm system. Any assembly of equipment or a device designated to detect and signal the unauthorized intrusion into premises or to signal an attempted burglary, robbery, other criminal activity, or to signal a fire at the protected premises, to which the fire department is expected to respond. Such term, however, shall not include security alarm systems maintained by governmental agencies or departments. 
(i)  User. Any person using a security or fire alarm, regardless of whether the person owns the security or fire system or the premises on which it is located. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-102. - Intentional false alarms-Prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, knowingly and without just cause, to activate a security or fire alarm to summon the fire department in situations where there is no actual or threatened criminal or fire safety requiring immediate police or fire response. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall constitute a class I misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or not more than twelve (12) months in jail, or both. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-103. - False alarm-Deactivation. 
    The police officer or fire and rescue official responding to a false alarm shall have the authority to deactivate an alarm system without liability when the alarm system is disturbing the peace and quiet of the community, if the user fails to deactivate the alarm system within a reasonable time. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-104. - Systems not connected to alarm board. 
(a)  After the effective date of this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to install, operate or maintain an automatic dialing device which is programmed to transmit a prerecorded message or code signal directly from a residence or dwelling to a telephone number assigned to the fire department, or to install, operate or maintain an automatic dialing device or other security or fire alarm system in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Users of automatic dialing devices, which connect to the alarm board of the fire department, shall notify the fire department of the possession of such systems within thirty (30) days of the enactment of this article. 
(c)  Nonresidential users may connect or operate automatic dialing devices upon the following conditions: 
(1)  Notification of installation on forms to be provided by the fire marshal containing the following information: 
a.  Name and address of protected premises. 
b.  Name, address and telephone number of person installing, maintaining and/or owning the automatic dialing device. 
c.  Name, address and telephone number of personnel to be contacted in case of alarm or malfunction. 
d.  Any additional relevant information required by the fire marshal. 
(2)  Installation by a licensed alarm business or licensed electrician certified to do business in the commonwealth, with the cost to be paid by the user. 
(3)  Monthly inspections and testing of the system by the user and reporting of the monthly inspection results to the fire marshal. 
(4)  Residential and nonresidential users may connect or operate security or fire alarm systems other than automatic dialing devices pursuant to the conditions set forth in subsections (c)(1) through (c)(3) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-105. - False alarm charges. 
(a)  No fee shall be charged for a false alarm if the fire department is notified of the false alarm, by the user's authorized agent/employee, prior to the dispatch of vehicles or personnel to the scene of the alarm. 
(b)  After three (3) false alarms at a single protected premises within the same one-month period, users shall be charged a service charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the fourth false alarm which results in a police department response and shall be charged a service charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each tactical unit which is dispatched for a fire and rescue response to the protected premises. 
(c)  After the occurrence of four (4) false alarms at a single protected premises within the same one-month period, the charge for responding to false alarms at the protected premises shall be increased by fifty dollars ($50.00) for each successive false alarm (e.g., one hundred dollars ($100.00) one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for the fifth alarm, two hundred dollars ($200.00) and two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for the sixth alarm, etc.) 
(d)  In the event a user fails to pay the assessed service charge within thirty (30) days of billing, the user shall be charged interest at the judgment rate of interest from the date the charge was assessed. 
(e)  Charges shall be paid to the city treasurer. 
(f)  The city treasurer may obtain authorization from the governing body for the city attorney to institute appropriate legal proceeding against any bank or other user, to collect any delinquent service charge, including interest, which has been assessed. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-106. - Suspension of responses to alarms. 
    In the event of the occurrence of three (3) or more false alarms within a single one-month protected premises in any single one-month period or in the event the user fails to pay the assessed service charge for false alarms within thirty (30) days of billing the fire marshal may, by giving the user five (5) days' written notice, advise the user that after a specified date, the fire department shall not respond to alarms at the protected premises until all delinquent service charges, including interest have been paid and the user demonstrates to the fire marshal or his designated agent, that corrective action has been taken to prevent additional false alarms and that the system is functioning properly. 
    Unless otherwise required by law, a user who desires to suspend for a temporary period of time, fire department responses to alarms, due to malfunctions in the system or for any other reason, may so advise the fire marshal in writing, specifying the effective date of the suspension. Resumption of responses shall be effective after the user provides written notice to the fire marshal. Any charges assessed prior to the effective date of any suspension shall remain due and owing. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-107. - Appeal proceedings. 
    Any user may appeal an action by the fire marshal to assess a service charge for a false alarm. The appeal shall be made in writing to the city manager within ten (10) days after such action has been taken. A decision by the city manager is final. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
ARTICLE VII. - FIRE MARSHAL[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Local fire marshals, Code of Virginia, § 27-30 et seq. 

Sec. 9-108. - Office created; deputies; appointments; compensation; term. 
    The office of the city fire marshal is hereby created. 
(a)  The governing body shall appoint a city fire marshal, deputy fire marshal(s) and assistant fire marshals, whose powers and duties shall be as set forth in this chapter and as authorized by the Code of Virginia. 
(b)  The fire marshal shall receive such annual salary as the governing body may allow. 
(c)  The city fire marshal shall not be appointed for a definite tenure, but shall continue contingent upon and subject to the personnel rules of the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-109. - Oaths of office. 
    The city fire marshal, deputy fire marshal and members of the fire marshal's staff, before entering upon their duties, shall, respectively, take an oath, before any officer authorized to administer oaths, faithfully to discharge the duties of their offices. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-110. - General powers and duties. 
    The fire marshal and his deputies or assistants shall have such powers and duties, as are prescribed by state law and by this chapter and other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-111. - Fire marshal to be summoned to scene of fire, explosion, etc. 
    The fire department officer in charge of any fire, explosion or incident to which fire apparatus or equipment responds shall immediately summons the fire marshal to the scene to investigate the circumstances involved, where such circumstances require investigation pursuant to § F-102.3 of the fire prevention code adopted by article III of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-112. - Reports to fire marshal as to fires, explosions, etc. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the fire department officer-in-charge or his designee to file with the fire marshal, in such form as he shall prescribe, a report if pursuant to § F-102.3 of the fire prevention code adopted by article III of this chapter, if there is sufficient evidence to warrant charges for arson, bombing or other offenses involving fire or the calling or summoning of fire or rescue equipment without just cause, in violation of the Code of Virginia or this Code. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Cross reference- Calling firefighting apparatus without cause, § 16-7. 
Sec. 9-113. - Impersonation. 
    It shall be unlawful and a class 1 misdemeanor for any unauthorized person to use a badge, uniform or any other credentials, so as to gain access to any building, marine vessel, vehicle or premises, or to otherwise falsely identify himself as the fire marshal or his designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
ARTICLE VIII. - OPEN AIR BURNING[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt ordinances governing open air burning, Code of Virginia, § 10-17.30(b). 

Sec. 9-114. - General. 
    A person shall not cause or allow open burning unless approved in accordance with this code and the Commonwealth of Virginia State Air Pollution Control Board's Regulations Concerning Emissions Standards for Open Burning, and Virginia Forestry Laws. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-115. - Definitions. 
    The following words and terms shall, for the purpose of this section and as stated elsewhere in the Virginia Statewide Fire Prevention Code, have the meanings shown herein. 
    Bonfire means an outdoor fire utilized for ceremonial purposes. 
    Land clearing refuse means brush, stumps, and other vegetation and similar matter generated from site clearing, and shall not include demolition material or refuse products from other sites. 
    Open burning means the burning of any material wherein products of combustion are emitted directly into the ambient air without passing through a stack or chimney from an enclosed chamber. For the purpose of this definition, a chamber shall be regarded as enclosed when, during the time combustion occurs, only apertures, ducts, stacks, flues or chimneys necessary to provide combustion air and permit the escape of exhaust gas are open. 
    Recreational fire means an outdoor fire utilized to cook food for human consumption. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-116. - Allowable burning. 
    Open burning shall be allowed without prior notification to the fire marshal only for recreational fires, campfires, highway safety flares, smudge pots and small warming fires for outside workers during winter months. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-117. - Permit required; applications; authorization; burning of land clearing refuse; open burning prohibited. 
(a)  Open burning shall be allowed after obtaining a permit or other proper authorization from the fire marshal for recognized agricultural, silvicultural or range, or wildlife management practices, prevention or control of disease or pests, a bonfire, and for land clearing refuse. 
(b)  Applications for open burning shall be submitted in writing at least seventy-two (72) hours before the fire is set and shall be in such form and contain such information as required by the fire marshal. Such application shall contain, as a minimum, information regarding: the purpose of the proposed burning, the nature and quantities of material to be burned, the date when such burning will take place, the location of the burning site, and the on-site fire extinguishing equipment to be provided. 
(c)  Open burning shall be permitted with prior notification to the fire marshal and in compliance with the Commonwealth of Virginia State Air Pollution Control Board regulations, provided that any conditions specified in the permission are followed for: 
(1)  Disposal of hazardous or toxic materials where the fire marshal and the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality determine that there is no practical alternative method of disposal. 
(2)  Instruction in the methods of fire fighting or for research in the control of fire, in emergency or other extraordinary circumstances for any purpose determined to be necessary by the fire marshal and as authorized by the Virginia Department of Environmental Quality. 
(3)  Disposal of debris or to remedy an emergency resulting from a disaster situation and when operating under an emergency declaration of the federal, state, or local government. 
(d)  Burning of land clearing refuse, other than agricultural, shall be conducted utilizing "special incineration devices" as defined in the State Air Pollution Control Board Regulations Concerning Emission Standards for Open Burning. A separate permit is required for each separate or new special incineration device on a site. 
(e)  The fire marshal shall prohibit open burning that will be offensive or objectionable due to smoke or odor emissions when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous. The fire marshal shall order the extinguishment, by the permit holder or the fire department, of any open burning, which creates or adds to a hazardous or objectionable situation. Burning of land clearing refuse is prohibited in the months of June, July and August in accordance with Virginia Emissions Standards for Open Burning. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-118. - Location. 
    The location for any open burning shall not be less than fifty (50) feet from any structure, and provisions shall be made to preventing the fire from spreading to within fifty (50) feet of any structure. Fires in approved containers shall be permitted, provided that such fires are not less than fifteen (15) feet from any structure. The burning of land clearing refuse shall not be less than one thousand (1,000) feet from an occupied structure. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-119. - Materials. 
    Open burning shall not be utilized for waste disposal purposes, shall be of the minimum size for the intended purpose, and the fuel shall be chosen to minimize the generation and emission of air contaminants. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-120. - Attendance; safety fence. 
(a)  Any open burning shall be constantly attended until the fire is extinguished. At least one (1) portable fire extinguisher with a minimum 4-A rating, two (2) portable fire extinguishers with a minimum 2-A rating each, or other approved on site fire extinguishing equipment, such as dirt, sand, water barrel, garden hose or water truck, shall be available for immediate utilization. 
(b)  Temporary fencing must be installed around any pit when not in use. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-121. - Bonfire size and duration; material; permits. 
(a)  A bonfire shall not be more than five (5) feet by five (5) feet by five (5) feet in dimension and shall not burn longer than three (3) hours. The maximum size and duration of a bonfire shall not be increased by the fire marshal unless it is determined that safety requirements of the situation and the desirable duration of the burn warrant the increase. 
(b)  Fuel for a bonfire shall consist only of seasoned dry firewood and shall be ignited with a small quantity of paper. The fire shall not be utilized for waste disposal purposes, and the fuel shall be chosen to minimize the generation of air contaminants. 
(c)  All permits shall be requested by and issued to the owner of the land upon which the bonfire is to be kindled. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-122. - Recreational fires prohibited; management responsibility. 
(a)  No charcoal cooker, smoker, grill, or any flammable liquid or liquefied petroleum gas-fired stove or similar devices shall be ignited or used on the balconies or spaces under balconies of multifamily dwellings, nor in a similar manner in any occupancy unless approved by the fire marshal. These devices can be used at ground level if greater than fifteen (15) feet from any structure. Exception: electric grills and other devices approved by the fire marshal. 
(b)  The management of apartment buildings which have balconies and patios shall notify their tenants in writing of this requirement at the time the tenant initially occupies the area, and from time to time thereafter as may be necessary to reasonably ensure conformity. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-123. - Penalties, other remedies. 
(a)  Any person who conducts open air burning or other act in violation of any requirement of this article shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor. Each day upon which any such violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  Nothing contained herein shall preclude the city from seeking such other relief at law or equity for violations of the provisions of this article, as may be deemed expedient, whether or not criminal charges have been or may be made. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 9-124. - Other permits still required. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall relieve any person of any requirement to obtain other permits relating to the conduct of open air burning, which may be established by law. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-743, 3-16-04) 
ARTICLE IX. - SERVICE FEE FOR TRANSPORT BY EMS VEHICLE 

Sec. 9-125. - Service charge. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by section 9-129, service fees for basic life support (BLS), advanced life support level 1 (ALS1) and advanced life support level 2 (ALS2) and a ground transport mileage fee are imposed on each person being transported by any emergency medical services vehicle that is operated or maintained by the city fire and rescue department or for which a permit has been issued to the city by the Virginia Office of Emergency Medical Services. The term "emergency medical services vehicle" has the definition specified in Code of Virginia, § 32.1-111.1. 
(b)  The fee rates shall be established by resolution of the governing body. The rates shall be reviewed on a periodic basis as determined by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-832, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 9-126. - Disbursement of funds. 
    The funds received from the payment of fees established by this article shall be paid into the general fund of the city to aid in defraying the cost of providing such services. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-832, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 9-127. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply to the fees established by this article: 
(a)  Basic life support (BLS) : medical treatment or procedures provided to a patient by an emergency medical technician-basic ("EMT-basic") as defined by the national emergency medicine services (EMS) education and practice blueprint. 
(b)  Advanced life support, level 1 (ALS1) : medical treatment or procedures provided to a patient beyond the scope of an EMT-basic. 
(c)  Advanced life support, level 2 (ALS2) : advanced life support (ALS) services provided to a patient including one (1) or more of the following medical procedures: 
(i)  Defibrillation/cardioversion; 
(ii)  Endotracheal intubation; 
(iii)  Cardiac pacing; 
(iv)  Chest decompression; 
(v)  Intraosseous line, and/or 
(vi)  The administration of three (3) or more medications. 
(d)  Ground transport mileage (GTM) : number of statute miles from the location of the incident to a hospital or other facility where a patient is transported. Only miles traveled with the patient on board shall be considered billable miles. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-832, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 9-128. - Authority. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized and directed to establish rules and regulations for the administration of the fees established by this article, including, but not limited to, payment standards for those persons who demonstrate economic hardship. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-832, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 9-129. - Exemptions. 
    No fee shall be imposed on persons in the following circumstances: 
(a)  Persons determined to be medically indigent by the city in accordance with administrative policies established by the city manager; or 
(b)  Persons transported pursuant to any no-charge mutual aid agreement with another jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 07-1700-832, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Chapter 10 - FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- License tax for restaurants, § 14-86. 
State Law reference- Food and drink generally, Code of Virginia, § 3.1-361 et seq.; restaurants and public eating places, Code of Virginia, § 35-25 et seq. 

Sec. 10-1. - Street or itinerant vendors of ice cream limited to certain hours of operation. 
    Street or itinerant vendors of ice cream shall not operate within the city, except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
(Code 1971, § 17-39) 
Cross reference- Limitation on stopping vehicles used for sale of ice cream on streets, § 20-6. 
Sec. 10-2. - Annual examination of food handlers in restaurants. 
    Each person engaged in the preparation, serving or handling of food or utensils used in the preparation, serving or handling of food in an establishment subject to a license tax as a restaurant, as provided in section 14-86 of this Code, shall be examined by a qualified physician, for contagious disease, annually. The record of such examination shall be available for inspection. The examination will be at the expense of the holder of the license pursuant to which the restaurant in question is operated. 
(Code 1971, § 11-1) 
Sec. 10-3. - Sale of food in Costello Park. 
(a)  No person shall enter Costello Park for the purpose of selling ice cream, lemonade, fruit, sandwiches or like products, unless authorized by the city council. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall constitute a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 79-1700-137, 1-5-79) 
Cross reference- License tax for sale of food on streets or other public places, § 14-94. 
Chapter 11 - FOR-HIRE VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, adopted Feb. 3, 2004, amended Ch. 11 in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former Ch. 11 derived from Ord. No. 87-1700-365, adopted Nov. 4, 1987. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 11-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to regulate the operation of taxicabs for hire within the city (the "city") in order to provide the citizens of the city with safe, economical, adequate and efficient taxicab service. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-2. - Violations. 
    Unless otherwise specifically provided, any person convicted of violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-3. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them by this section: 
    Agreement: A multijurisdictional agreement entered into by two (2) or more jurisdictions for the purpose of jointly regulating the operation of taxicabs within the boundaries of such jurisdictions. 
    Chief of police: The police chief for the city. 
    Driver: The individual who drives or physically operates a taxicab. 
    Governing body: The governing body for the city. 
    Independent: A person who owns a taxicab and operates under authority of another person's operator's certificate. 
    In service: Operating a taxicab upon the highways, roads, streets or other public ways and places in the city in search of, soliciting, or transporting prospective passengers for hire or responding to requests for transport. 
    Operator's certificate or certificate: The certificate of public convenience and necessity required by the provisions of this chapter to be obtained by any person to engage in the taxicab business upon the highways, roads, streets or public ways and places in the city. 
    Operator or certificate holder: One who holds a certificate. 
    Out of service: The period during which a driver is not in service. 
    Owner: Any person, association, company, corporation, partnership or organization holding title to, or having the right to possession of, any taxicab. 
    Passenger: A person carried or transported in consideration of a fare. 
    Permit: A driver's permit issued pursuant to this chapter. 
    Police department: The city police department. 
    Regional review board: The taxicab board of review established pursuant to this chapter. 
    Service technician: A person, certified by the Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services, who adjusts, installs, places in service, recommends for use, reconditions, repairs, or services a taximeter. 
    Taxicab: A vehicle for passenger conveyance held for public hire and carrying passengers to destinations without following fixed routes. 
    Taxicab inspector: The police officer, or officers, or other department personnel designated by the chief of police to administer and enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
    Taximeter: A mechanical or electronic instrument by which the fare for hire of a taxicab is computed for mileage and for waiting time and upon which such fare is plainly visible to the passenger. 
(b)  Pursuant to the Code of Virginia, the city may enter into one (1) or more agreements. In the event the city enters into any such agreement the meaning of the aforementioned words and phrases may be amended therein to allow for joint regulation of taxicabs within the boundaries of the city and such neighboring jurisdictions. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-4. - Unlawful use of certificate or permit issued under chapter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to lend or knowingly permit the use of his permit or his operator's certificate by another. It shall be unlawful for any person to display or represent as his own any permit or operator's certificate not issued to or for the person or the vehicle displaying the same. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-5. - False statements or entries on records required by chapter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and intentionally make any false statement or entry on the records required to be kept by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-6. - General operating requirements. 
    Every taxicab shall be operated in accordance with the laws of Virginia and the provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the city, with due regard to the safety, comfort and convenience of passengers and the general public. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-7. - Information to be kept on file with taxicab inspector. 
    Every certificate holder shall maintain on file with the taxicab inspector his name, his company's name, his business address and garage address, all business telephone numbers listed in his and his company's name and the names of all drivers driving under his certificate. He shall, within forty-eight (48) hours after he becomes aware of any change in the information required in this section, report same to the taxicab inspector. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-8. - Place of business or office with telephone service required. 
    All persons engaged in the taxicab business in the city shall maintain a place of business or office with telephone service within the city. Any person engaged in the taxicab business in the city and maintaining a place of business or office with telephone service within the geographic boundaries of Prince William County (the "county") or the City of Manassas shall be deemed to be in compliance with this section, provided such person complies with all provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-9. - Twenty-four-hour service required. 
(a)  It is not necessary for the operator of a taxicab business in the city to have his place of business or office open twenty-four (24) hours per day, but the certificate holder or his employees must be on duty in the office and available by telephone to respond to requests for service twenty-four (24) hours per day. 
(b)  The taxicab inspector may, when a request is made in writing to the taxicab inspector by a certificate holder, allow the certificate holder to conduct dispatch operations (receiving telephone calls for requests for service and dispatching taxicabs in response to such calls) from another location other than the business office. Such written request shall be made at least five (5) working days prior to the requested date, unless there are emergency circumstances, and will be for a defined temporary time frame, as established and approved by the taxicab inspector. Such temporary dispatching services shall be in accordance with all zoning regulations. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-10. - Duty to respond to requests for service. 
    The operator of a taxicab business shall cause response to be made to all calls and requests for service within the boundaries of Manassas Park. The operator shall have the option of responding to the call for service or of referring the caller to another taxicab operator whose place of business is at a shorter distance in the city from the caller. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-11. - Use for unlawful purposes. 
    No owner or driver shall knowingly permit such vehicle to be used for unlawful purposes or to transport persons therein to places for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-12. - Transportation of animals. 
    While in service, only an animal in the company of a paying passenger shall be allowed in a taxicab. Transportation of a passenger's animal is at the discretion of the driver and only if the passenger agrees to keep the animal under control. This section shall not apply to animals assisting bona fide handicapped persons. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-13. - Maximum length of driver's working day. 
    No driver shall drive a taxicab, nor shall any certificate holder or his employees require or permit drivers to drive a taxicab, more than thirteen (13) hours in any consecutive twenty-four-hour period. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-14. - Driver to be clean and neat. 
    Every driver of a taxicab shall, while on duty, be hygienically clean, neat in appearance and suitably dressed. The term "suitably dressed" shall mean the wearing of trousers, slacks, shoes, and appropriate outer garments. In warm weather, the driver may wear, as an outer garment, a shirt with collar, with or without a tie, a blouse, or a sweater. In warm weather shorts are permitted, if tailored in appearance. Cutoffs are not suitable. Drivers shall not wear underwear, tank tops, body shirts, swimwear, jogging suits, or similar types of attire when worn as outer garments. Nor shall drivers wear any clothing with open tears, rents or other holes. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-15. - Use of tobacco and radio by driver/passenger. 
    No driver, while his taxicab is occupied by a passenger, shall smoke or play a radio, other than the one used for communications with his dispatcher, if his passenger requests that he not do so. passengers may not smoke in a taxicab if a "no smoking" sign is posted in such taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-16. - Use of drugs and alcohol by driver. 
(a)  At no time shall a driver use alcoholic beverages, narcotics or other scheduled drugs while in service or while otherwise operating a taxicab. 
(b)  The transportation of alcoholic beverages, other than alcoholic beverages carried in the possession of a paying passenger, is prohibited in taxicabs while the driver is in service. 
(c)  At no time shall any driver, independent or owner, or any employee or agent of the same, use any alcoholic beverages, narcotics, or other scheduled drugs within the business office while on duty. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-17. - Restrictions on loading and unloading. 
    No driver shall stop to load or unload passengers or their belongings on the traveled portion of any street, highway or other public way or any intersection or crosswalk thereof. No driver shall stop to load or unload in any manner that would in any way impede or interfere with the orderly flow of traffic or pedestrians or endanger the safety of his passenger. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-18. - General limitation on number of passengers. 
    No driver shall permit more persons to be carried in a taxicab in the city at any one (1) time than the seating capacity of the taxicab, as rated by the automobile manufacturer, including the driver, but excluding children in arms. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-19. - Limitation on number of passengers on front seat. 
    At no time shall more than two (2) persons, in addition to the driver, ride on the front seat of any taxicab. A child in arms shall not be permitted to ride in the front seat of any taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-20. - Refusal of passengers. 
(a)  No driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon request, unless previously engaged or forbidden by the provisions of this chapter to do so. 
(b)  A driver may refuse to convey an unaccompanied child less than five (5) years old. 
(c)  A driver, owner, independent or certificate holder may refuse to convey any person who has threatened, assaulted, robbed, or failed to pay the legal fare for any previous trip or service provided to such person by (i) such driver, or (ii) the owner, independent or certificate holder for whom such driver works. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-21. - Deception of passengers. 
    No driver shall deceive or attempt to deceive any passenger who may ride in his taxicab or who may desire to ride in such taxicab, as to his destination or the rate or fare to be charged, or convey any passenger or cause him to be conveyed to a place other than directed by the passenger. In no event, shall any driver take a longer route than necessary, unless so requested by the passenger. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-22. - Compliance with request of passenger as to speed and route. 
    Every driver shall comply with all reasonable and lawful requests of his passengers as to the speed of travel and the route to be taken. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-23. - Accident reports. 
    Every accident involving a taxicab governed by the provisions of this chapter shall be immediately reported to the police department by the driver involved. In addition, the taxicab inspector shall be notified, in writing, of such accident within five (5) business days of its occurrence by the driver involved. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-24. - Drivers' manifests. 
(a)  Every driver shall maintain a daily manifest, which shall be approved by the taxicab inspector, upon which shall be clearly and legibly recorded the following: 
(1)  The date and time the driver went in service and went out of service and the number of hours on duty. 
(2)  The taxicab number, the driver's name and his permit number. 
(3)  The odometer reading of the taxicab at the beginning and end of each working day. 
(4)  All trips made each day, showing the time and place of origin and destination, the number of passengers, the fare and any extra charges. This information shall be recorded at the beginning and end of each trip. 
(b)  No manifest required by this section shall be transferred from one (1) taxicab to another. If the driver changes taxicabs during a working day, a separate manifest shall be maintained for each such taxicab. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any driver to maintain an incomplete manifest. 
(d)  All completed manifests shall be returned to the operator by the driver as soon as is practicable after the end of the driver's working day, and in no event less frequently than once a week. 
(e)  All operators shall retain and preserve all manifests for a period of no less than three (3) months. Manifests shall be stored and preserved at the operator's place of business or office and shall be subject to inspection by the taxicab inspector or other police department personnel at all reasonable times. Moreover, operators shall provide specified manifests no later than eight (8) hours after such manifests have been requested by the taxicab inspector or other police department personnel. The taxicab inspector or any sworn police officer shall have the authority to remove any of the manifests from the operator's office for inspection purposes. The manifests shall be returned within two (2) weeks after such removal and the operator shall be given a receipt stating exactly which of such manifests have been removed. 
(f)  The certificate holder shall maintain an electronic database of all requests for service dispatched for a period of at least six (6) months. This electronic database should be capable of cross-referencing the driver's name, taxicab number, and time and date of a specified pick up request. This information shall be subject to inspection by the taxicab inspector or other police department personnel at all reasonable times. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-25. - Disposition of articles left in vehicle. 
    Any article found in a taxicab shall be returned, with reasonable promptness, to its owner, if he is known, or such owner shall be promptly notified of the whereabouts of the article so that he may claim it. If the owner is not known, the driver shall note the article on the manifest referred to in section 11-24 and notify the certificate holder of the found article. The article shall be turned over to the certificate holder at the end of the driver's tour of duty. The operator shall maintain the lost article in a safe place for at least seven (7) days. If the article is not claimed by its owner within seven (7) days, the article shall be turned over to the taxicab inspector. The taxicab inspector shall hold the article until claimed by its owner. If no claim is received within ninety (90) days, the article shall be disposed of according to law. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-26. - Severability. 
    In the event any part or provision of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person or circumstance, is held to be illegal or invalid, such holdings shall not have the effect of making illegal or invalid any of the other parts or provisions thereof, or the application of such provision to other persons or circumstances. It shall be presumed that this chapter would have been adopted without such illegal or invalid part or provision, or application, if the determination of invalidity had been known at the time of adoption. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Secs. 11-27-11-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICAB REVIEW BOARD 

Sec. 11-36. - Created; composition. 
(a)  A taxicab review board has been created and established by the county. The county's review board consists of eight (8) members who are residents of the county and appointed by the board of county supervisors. In addition, during any period in which the county participates in an agreement with the cities of Manassas and Manassas Park for the enforcement of the county's and the cities' taxicab ordinances, the county's review board will also consist of one (1) member each from the City of Manassas and the City of Manassas Park, to be appointed by the cities' respective governing bodies, and will function as the regional review board for all three jurisdictions. 
(b)  During any period in which the City of Manassas Park does not participate in an agreement with Prince William County and the City of Manassas the governing body will serve as the city's taxicab review board, and any reference to the regional review board contained in this chapter shall, with the exception of those references found in sections 11-37 and 11-39, refer instead to the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-37. - Qualifications, appointment and terms of members. 
    The city's member of the regional review board shall be a city resident and shall be appointed by and shall serve at the pleasure of the governing body. No appointee shall be an owner, employee, member of a board of directors or a stockholder of a taxicab or taxicab company. Appointments shall be for terms not to exceed four (4) years. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-38. - General duties. 
    The regional review board created pursuant to this chapter shall, in addition to the performance of such other duties and responsibilities as may be imposed upon it, consider and act upon applications for certificates and appeals from actions of the taxicab inspector's office, in the manner more specifically set forth in other sections of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-39. - Quorum; required vote for action. 
    Five (5) members of the regional review board shall constitute a quorum. When a quorum is established, actions of the regional review board shall be effective only upon a majority vote of the members thereof present; provided, however, that modification or reversal of an action of the taxicab inspector, on appeal, shall be effective only upon a concurring vote of at least four (4) members of the regional review board. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-40. - Hearings and decisions generally. 
    All hearings of the regional review board shall be open to the public and shall be, insofar as is reasonably practicable, informal and free of technical rules of law or evidence. Applicants and appellants shall be entitled to be heard in person and by counsel and shall be entitled to provide for the recording of the proceedings, in any manner which will not impede the orderly conduct of the hearing. Decisions of the regional review board shall be reduced to writing and a copy thereof shall be furnished to the taxicab inspector and to any applicant or appellant affected thereby. The regional review board may establish such rules of procedure for the conduct of its hearings as may be consistent with the provisions and intent of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-41. - Appeals to regional review board. 
(a)  If the taxicab inspector denies, suspends, or revokes or denies renewal of any previously issued permit or revokes or suspends any certificate, any person affected thereby may appeal such decision to the regional review board. Upon making such appeal, any driver must submit a copy of its department of motor vehicles traffic record for consideration by the regional review board. Such appeal shall be filed by the appellant or his attorney with the secretary of the regional review board, or the secretary's designee. The appellant or his attorney shall file a written notice of appeal, signed by the appellant or his attorney, requesting a hearing and setting forth a brief statement of the reasons thereof. Such appeal shall be filed within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice of denial, suspension or revocation. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a notice of appeal, the regional review board shall set a time and place for a hearing and shall give the appellant, or his attorney, and the taxicab inspector reasonable notice thereof. All hearings on appeals shall be scheduled and determined as promptly as practicable and in no event more than thirty (30) days from the date the notice of appeal is filed. 
(c)  Upon the hearing of an appeal under this section, the regional review board shall consider the case record as well as any statement offered by any interested party and shall determine the matter de novo and shall, upon the basis of the record and evidence presented before it, affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the taxicab inspector. 
(d)  If the regional review board affirms the decision of the taxicab inspector to deny, suspend or revoke a permit or to suspend or revoke a certificate, the suspension or revocation shall be effective from the date of the board's order, or at such time as directed by majority vote of the regional review board, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. If the regional review board reverses the decision of the taxicab inspector, it shall direct the taxicab inspector to issue or restore the permit or certificate in accordance with its order. 
(e)  The appeal of the decision of the taxicab inspector to suspend or revoke a permit or to suspend or revoke or deny renewal of a certificate shall stay the effective date of the suspension, revocation or denial; provided, however, any suspension or revocation of any such certificate for the reasons listed in subsection 11-69(a)(4) shall take effect as provided in such section and shall remain in full force and effect until the regional review board has rendered its decision on the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Secs. 11-42-11-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OPERATOR'S CERTIFICATE 

Sec. 11-56. - Required; exceptions. 
    No person shall operate or permit to be operated a taxicab upon the highways, roads, streets or other public ways and places in the city without having first obtained an operator's certificate from the taxicab inspector's office; provided, however, an independent may operate a taxicab under another operator's certificate, so long as he operates only under one certificate at a particular time. A taxicab which is duly licensed as a taxicab in any other jurisdiction may be used to convey passengers into the city from its jurisdiction and to discharge them at their destinations, but the drivers of such taxicabs shall not otherwise convey, pick up or solicit a passenger or passengers within the city. An operator may hold only one (1) valid operator's certificate, with only the most recently issued certificate considered valid. Any previously issued certificate shall automatically become void upon the issuance of a new certificate. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-56.1. - Reciprocity. 
    If the governing body has entered into a reciprocal agreement with another entity responsible for regulating taxicabs, taxicabs licensed by such entity and covered by such agreement may operate in the city pursuant to the terms of such agreement, notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-57. - Application generally. 
(a)  Application for a certificate shall be made by the proposed operator or his duly authorized agent upon forms provided by the taxicab inspector's office and approved by the chief of police. Upon such forms, the applicant shall supply the following information, under oath: 
(1)  The full name, residence and business address of the applicant and any partners. If the applicant is a corporation, the name, residence and business address of every officer of the corporation and any stockholder holding ten (10) per cent or more of the outstanding shares of the corporation. 
(2)  The trade name and phone number under which the applicant does or proposes to do business. 
(3)  A financial statement of the applicant and any partners. If the applicant is a corporation, each stockholder holding ten (10) per cent or more of the outstanding shares of the corporation shall file a financial statement. 
(4)  The number of vehicles to be operated and the make; serial number, type, year of manufacture, manufacturer's rated seating capacity and the color scheme, insignia and cruising light design of each vehicle. A description of any vehicle replacement or vehicle addition shall be provided to the taxicab inspector and, upon written approval of such replacement or addition by the taxicab inspector, the operator's application shall be amended to reflect the same. Any new applicant will need a minimum of ten (10) vehicles that have been approved pursuant to section 11-117 hereof to obtain and maintain a certificate. 
(5)  The location and description of any depots and terminals used or to be used by the applicant. 
(6)  Each conviction of, or plea of guilty to, the violation of any criminal or traffic law, whether such violation be of a local ordinance, state law or federal law, by the applicant and his partners, and every officer or shareholder holding ten (10) per cent or more of the outstanding shares of the partnership or corporate applicant as the case may be. 
(7)  A resume of the experience, if any, of the applicant in the transportation of passengers for hire. 
(8)  All facts and circumstances upon which the applicant bases his belief that the public convenience and necessity of the city residents require the granting of his application. The chief of police or the regional review board may request such additional information from the applicant as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter. 
(9)  The applicant's proposed color scheme and insignia which shall be unique and readily distinguishable from color schemes and insignia of operators already certificated by the city. For purposes of this section, the regional review board will have the sole discretion to determine whether proposed schemes and insignias are unique and distinguishable. 
(10)  A description of the communications system to be used with specific reference to the applicant's plan to provide twenty-four-hour dispatch service to the public. If such dispatch is not to be furnished by the applicant, the name and address of the provider and the manner of providing such service shall be provided. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and intentionally make or cause to be made any false statement in an application filed pursuant to this section or to otherwise make any such statement for the purpose of procuring a certificate under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-58. - Fee for processing application. 
    The fee for the processing of each application for a certificate under the provisions of this chapter shall be three hundred fifty dollars ($350.00) and shall be paid to the city treasurer at the time of application. Such fee shall not be refundable. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-59. - Fingerprinting and photographing of applicant. 
    Each applicant for a certificate shall be fingerprinted and photographed by the police department at the time the application is filed. If the applicant is a partnership, all partners therein shall comply with this section. If the applicant is a corporation, all officers thereof and all persons holding ten (10) per cent or more of the outstanding shares of stock therein shall comply with this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-60. - Applicant's bond or insurance. 
(a)  No certificate shall be issued or continued in effect unless there is in full force and effect a public liability indemnity bond by an approved corporate surety or a public liability automobile insurance policy for each vehicle authorized in the amount required by the Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles for bodily injury or death to any person, for injuries or death to more than one (1) person sustained in the same accident, and for property damage resulting from any one (1) accident. Such bond or insurance policy shall inure to the benefit of any person who shall be injured or to the estate of any person killed or to any person sustaining damage to property for which the driver of the taxicab or the certificate holder is liable. Such bond or evidence of such insurance shall be filed with the taxicab inspector prior to the issuance of any operator's certificate. 
(b)  Each bond or insurance policy required by this section must contain an endorsement by the surety or carrier providing for a thirty-day notice to the chief of police in the event of any change in coverage or cancellation of the policy or bond. 
(c)  In lieu of an indemnity bond or insurance policy, an applicant may satisfy the requirements of this section by qualifying as a self-insurer pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 56-299, in the amounts set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-61. - Investigation of applicant. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a certificate, the taxicab inspector's office shall make or cause to be made a thorough investigation of the character and traffic and criminal record of the applicant, including a review of any information on file with the Virginia Central Criminal Records Exchange. Upon completion of the investigation, the information obtained as a result thereof, together with all pertinent documents, shall be submitted to the regional review board. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-62. - Hearing on application; determination of public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  The taxicab inspector's office shall forthwith furnish the regional review board with a copy of each application for a certificate. Upon receipt of such copy, the regional review board shall hold a hearing as promptly as practical. In no event shall the hearing be held more than forty-five (45) days after the taxicab inspector's office has submitted to the regional review board all the information obtained as a result of the investigation provided for in section 11-61. The regional review board shall give the applicant notice of the hearing at least ten (10) days prior to the hearing date and shall cause such notice to be published once a week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper published and of general circulation in the city. 
(b)  The regional review board shall, upon holding the hearing provided for in this section and after such further investigation as it may deem advisable, determine whether the public convenience and necessity require the operation of the taxicabs for which application has been made pursuant to this article. In making this determination, the board shall consider the following: 
(1)  The adequacy of existing public vehicle service and other forms of passenger transportation. 
(2)  The kind, class and character of vehicles to be used and the adequacy and location of proposed depots and terminals. 
(3)  The probable permanence and quality of service offered by the applicant. 
(4)  The investigation report of the taxicab inspector's office and the character and responsibility of the applicant. 
(5)  Such other matters as may affect the public safety and welfare. 
(c)  The burden shall be upon the applicant in each case to establish the existence of public convenience and necessity for the operation of the taxicabs designated in his application and to establish all other facts required for granting a certificate under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-63. - Issuance. 
    Upon the granting of a certificate, the taxicab inspector's office shall issue the same in accordance with the action taken by the regional review board; provided, however, that no such certificate shall be issued nor be continued in effect until all fees and taxes imposed by this chapter or any other chapter of this Code are paid. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-64. - Contents. 
    A certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name of the company or individual and trade name, if any, and the business address and phone number of the operator. 
(2)  The total number of vehicles and the lettering, marks and color scheme to be used on each vehicle authorized to be operated by the certificate. 
(3)  The date of issuance. 
(4)  Such other information as, in the opinion of the taxicab inspector's office, may assist in the carrying out of the purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-65. - Term. 
    A certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be valid from the date of issuance until relinquished, suspended or revoked as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-66. - Not transferable. 
    A certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-67. - New certificate required upon change of ownership of stock in corporate holder. 
    In the event there is a transfer in the ownership of a majority of the outstanding shares of stock in a corporation holding a certificate, the corporation shall be required to submit a new application for a certificate and shall comply with all of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-68. - Amendment to reflect new vehicles or change of business address. 
    The certificate holder shall obtain the approval of the taxicab inspector prior to the replacement of any of the vehicles which are authorized on his certificate, or the addition of any vehicles not provided for on the certificate, and the certificate shall be amended to reflect the same. Any change in the business address and/or business phone number from that shown on the certificate shall be reported within five (5) business days to the taxicab inspector and the certificate shall be amended to reflect the same. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-69. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  A certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter may be suspended by the taxicab inspector, upon finding that the public safety and welfare so demands, for a period of one (1) to thirty (30) days for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Operation of a taxicab for passenger conveyance which is not in good order and repair in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Failure to pay any fee lawfully assessed upon the ownership or operation of any vehicle under this chapter or failure to pay any fee and tax imposed by this chapter or any other chapter of this Code. 
(3)  Failure to supply information required under this chapter. 
(4)  Failure to maintain proper insurance or bond on any vehicle as required by this chapter. The operator's right to operate such vehicle shall be suspended for so long as the required amount of insurance or bond is not in effect and such suspension shall not be limited to thirty (30) days as provided above. 
(5)  The operator knows, or should have known, that one (1) or more of its drivers has solicited fares in an area which is governed by an entity with which the governing body has entered into a reciprocal agreement, in violation of the terms of such reciprocal agreement, and the operator fails to act in a reasonable manner to prevent or stop said offense from reoccurring. 
(b)  A certificate issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the taxicab inspector, upon a finding that the public safety and welfare so demands, for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  The operator knowingly and intentionally makes or causes or allows to be made any false statement in writing for the purpose of procuring such certificate, or knowingly and intentionally makes or causes or allows to be made any false statement or entry on the records required to be kept by this chapter. 
(2)  Discontinuance of service for more than three (3) consecutive calendar days of the entire business of the certificate holder, except for discontinuance caused by severe weather, natural disaster or other circumstances beyond the control of a certificate holder. 
(3)  Two (2) or more violations by the operator of any of the provisions of this chapter within a twelve-month period. 
(4)  Failure to maintain a fleet of at least ten (10) taxicabs in accordance with subsection 11-57(4). 
(5)  Conviction for violating any law concerning solicitation for prostitution, the sale or use of narcotics, or the sale or transportation of alcohol. 
(c)  Written notice of any suspension or revocation pursuant to subsection (a) or (b) above shall be given to the operator by registered mail, at the operator's business address, as shown on the certificate, by the taxicab inspector. Such suspension or revocation shall be effective ten (10) days after deposit of the notice of such action in the mail; except that no delayed effective date shall be required for a suspension pursuant to subsection (a)(4) above. 
(d)  The taxicab inspector shall notify the regional review board within five (5) working days, of any revocation or suspension of a certificate under the provisions of this section. The regional review board, upon a determination that an operator is not operating the authorized taxicabs in such a manner as to serve the public adequately, may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the taxicab inspector in suspending or revoking the certificate. Such affirmation, modification or reversal shall only be taken upon a vote of the majority of the whole board and only after such operator has been notified of such proposed action and given an opportunity for a hearing. If an operator requests a hearing within ten (10) days of the notice provided for in subsection (c) above, except for action pursuant to subsection (a)(4) above, the action of the taxicab inspector shall be suspended until after such hearing has been held. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for a person to operate or permit to be operated a taxicab upon the highways, roads, streets or other public ways in the city when the certificate under which the taxicab was placed in service has been suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-70. - Limitation on reapplication following denial or revocation. 
    Upon action of the regional review board in denying or revoking a certificate applied for or issued under this article, no new application for such a certificate shall be filed by the same person or his agent within one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Secs. 11-71-11-81. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - TAXICAB DRIVER PERMITS 

Sec. 11-82. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to physically operate or drive a taxicab for hire upon the streets or highways of the city, unless he has obtained and has in his possession a valid permit issued in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the driver of a taxicab licensed in another jurisdiction while driving such taxicab in accordance with the provisions of section 11-56 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-83. - Application. 
(a)  Application for a permit, and for renewals thereof, shall be made in person on forms provided by the taxicab inspector and the applicant shall provide the following information under oath: 
(1)  His name, age, address, phone number and other pertinent personal data. 
(2)  A physical description. 
(3)  His traffic and criminal record. 
(4)  His experience in operating motor vehicles. 
(5)  His experience in operating taxicabs for hire, if any. 
(6)  The name of the operator for whom he will drive. 
(b)  The applicant will be required to pass a written examination 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly and intentionally make or cause to be made any false statement in an application filed under this section or to otherwise make any such statement for the purpose of procuring a permit. 
(d)  A driver shall report any change of address or phone number within forty-eight (48) hours after such change. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-84. - Applicant's qualifications. 
    Each applicant for a permit shall be at least eighteen (18) years of age and shall have held a valid motor vehicle operator's license issued by any state in the United States for at least one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-85. - Applicant to be fingerprinted or photographed. 
    Each applicant for a permit shall be required to be fingerprinted and photographed by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-86. - Investigation of applicant. 
    The taxicab inspector's office shall make or cause to be made a thorough investigation of the character and traffic and criminal record of the applicant, including a review of any information on file with the Virginia Central Criminal Records Exchange. The taxicab inspector shall have an investigation made of each applicant for a permit. A confidential record of the investigation shall be kept on file by the taxicab inspector. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-87. - Fee. 
    A fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid to the city treasurer at the time of making such application for a permit and at the time of each renewal for such permit. Duplicate permits may be issued at a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for lost, stolen, or disfigured permits. Such fee will in no event be refunded. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-88. - Denial of applications and renewals. 
(a)  The taxicab inspector, on his finding that the public safety and welfare so demand, may refuse to issue a permit to any applicant for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Three (3) or more convictions, in the immediately preceding twenty-four-month period, of moving violations of the motor vehicle laws of this or any other state or similar ordinances of counties, cities or towns. 
(2)  Conviction; or completion of sentence imposed under such conviction, within the preceding five (5) years, of a felony, or of any law regulating the possession or use of narcotics or other controlled substances, as defined and referred to in Code of Virginia, § 18.2-247, or three (3) or more convictions, or completion of sentence imposed under such convictions, within the previous five (5) years, of any law regulating the possession or use of alcohol, except as provided in (6) below. 
(3)  Applicant does not meet the requirements of section 11-84. 
(4)  Applicant has had his state operator's license revoked or suspended in any jurisdiction within the preceding three (3) years; provided, however, that a financial responsibility revocation shall not be grounds for denial, if the applicant has present proof of financial responsibility in accordance with the motor vehicle laws of this state. 
(5)  Applicant has made a false statement of material and relevant facts on an application for a permit. 
(6)  Conviction, or completion of sentence imposed under such conviction, within the preceding five (5) years, of any of the offenses listed below: 
a.  One (1) conviction of hit and run. 
b.  One (1) conviction as a habitual offender. 
c.  Two (2) convictions of reckless driving in twelve (12) months. 
d.  One (1) conviction of driving while operator's license is revoked or suspended. 
e.  One (1) conviction of driving while intoxicated. 
f.  Any combination of the above offenses suggestive of unsafe vehicle operation. 
(7)  Applicant is suffering from mental illness or physical condition which may pose a substantial threat to the safety of the public. 
(8)  Conviction of soliciting for prostitution; any sex offense, including, without limitation those offenses identified in Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-61, 18.2-63, 18.2-67.1-67.5, 18.2-346, 18.2-348, 18.2-349, 18.2-370, 18.2-370.1, 18.2-371 and 18.2-371.1; or any crime of moral turpitude. 
(b)  In the event the taxicab inspector denies a permit application, the inspector shall notify the applicant, in writing, within five (5) working days, of the action taken. The regional review board shall receive a copy of such notice. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-89. - Issuance and contents. 
(a)  If the taxicab inspector determines that the applicant for a permit has complied with all applicable provisions of this chapter and, based upon the information supplied in the permit application and information obtained from the investigation provided for in section 11-86, the taxicab inspector further determines that there will be no danger to the public, the inspector shall issue a permit containing such information thereon as the inspector deems pertinent. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally disfigure or alter any information contained on the permit. 
(c)  The taxicab inspector, if he finds the application therefor to be in good order and that there will be no danger to the public, may issue an applicant a temporary permit, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, pending investigation and processing of the application. Each permit, temporary or otherwise, belongs to the city and not to the driver to whom it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-90. - Term. 
    A permit shall be valid until the last day of the month which is two (2) years from the date of issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-91. - Change of company after issuance. 
    A permit shall only be valid while the holder thereof is driving for the taxicab company indicated on the front of the permit. Any driver who wishes to transfer from one company to another shall be required to pay a five-dollar transfer fee. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-92. - Posting. 
    Every person who obtains a permit under this article shall post his permit in such a place and manner as to be in full view of any passenger while within the taxicab he is driving for hire, whether or not occupied by a passenger. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-93. - Suspension or revocation. 
(a)  A permit issued under the provisions of this chapter may be suspended by the taxicab inspector, upon finding that the public safety and welfare so demands, until the reason for the suspension is resolved. In addition, the taxicab inspector may revoke a permit for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Driving a taxicab known to the driver not to be in a safe condition. 
(2)  One (1) or more violations of this chapter. 
(3)  Occurrence of any of the grounds listed in section 11-88 for refusal to issue a permit. 
(4)  One (1) conviction of reckless driving. 
(5)  A permit will automatically be revoked if a driver leaves a certificate holder, voluntarily or involuntarily, unless such driver applies to transfer the permit to another certificate holder within fourteen (14) days of such departure; such permit should be surrendered to the taxicab inspector's office within five (5) working days. 
(6)  If a driver is penalized for soliciting or loitering, in an area which is governed by an entity with which the governing body has entered into a reciprocal agreement, in violation of the terms of such reciprocal agreement. 
(b)  Written notice of any suspension or revocation under the provisions of this section shall be given by the taxicab inspector to the driver in person, or by certified mail at the driver's address as shown on the application for his permit. Such suspension or revocation shall be effective immediately, if given in person, or ten (10) days after the deposit of such notice in the mail; provided, however, that such permit shall immediately be suspended upon the effective date of any event described in subsections (2), (4), (5), (6), (7) and (8) of subsection 11-88(a). 
(c)  Upon suspension or revocation of the operator's license issued by the state division of motor vehicles to the holder of a permit issued under this article, such permit shall be automatically suspended or revoked. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to physically operate a taxicab upon the highways, roads, streets, or other public ways of the city when his permit is under suspension or revocation. 
(e)  Every permit suspended or revoked under the provisions of this section shall be surrendered to the taxicab inspector. 
(f)  Every driver shall report to the taxicab inspector each arrest or summons issued for a traffic offense while operating a motor vehicle or any offense identified in section 11-88. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-94. - Limitation on reapplication following denial or revocation. 
    No application for a permit may be filed by an individual whose application for a permit has been denied for a period of six (6) months; no application for a permit may be filed by an individual whose permit has been revoked for a period of two (2) years after the effective date of such denial or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-95. - Requirement for reporting traffic and criminal convictions. 
    Every driver shall notify the taxicab inspector, in writing, of any traffic or criminal convictions or suspensions or revocations within ten (10) days of such convictions. Any driver who has been arrested or charged with a felony offense, shall notify the taxicab inspector within ten (10) days of arrest. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Secs. 11-96-11-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - GENERAL VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 11-106. - Vehicle type. 
    Every taxicab operated in the city shall be built for use as a taxicab or shall be of an approved type by the taxicab inspector. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-107. - General construction and maintenance requirements. 
(a)  Every taxicab shall be so constructed and maintained as to provide for the safety of the public and for continuous and satisfactory operation and to reduce noise and vibration caused by operation. Every taxicab shall be structurally sound as to all of its parts and shall not have broken or cracked fenders or glass or be in need of body repair. 
(b)  Every taxicab shall be kept in such clean and sanitary condition as is reasonably possible considering existing weather conditions. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-108. - Doors.
