    Every taxicab shall be equipped with at least two (2) doors for the entrance and exit of passengers, in addition to the doors which give access to the driver's seat. All passenger doors shall be so constructed that they will remain securely fastened during normal operation, but may be easily opened by a passenger in an emergency. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-109. - Tires. 
    Every taxicab shall be equipped with tires having at least two thirty-seconds ( 2/32 ) of an inch of tread and no taxicab shall be operated with unsafe tires. Every taxicab shall be equipped with a properly inflated spare tire, with the same tread as required above, mounted on an appropriate rim. Snow tires or tire chains shall be used when emergency snow plans are put into effect. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-110. - Speedometer. 
    Every taxicab shall be equipped with a standard speedometer, properly installed, maintained in good working order and exposed to view. No taxicab shall be operated in a taxicab service while such speedometer is out of repair or disconnected. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-111. - Heater /air conditioner 
    Every taxicab shall be equipped with a heater sufficient to heat the interior of the taxicab adequately in cold weather. Every taxicab shall be equipped with an air conditioner sufficient to cool the interior of the taxicab adequately in hot weather. Heat or air conditioning shall be used or adjusted at the request of the passenger. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-112. - Cruising lights. 
    Every taxicab shall have cruising lights mounted on the top of the taxicab in the forward portion thereof. Such lights shall be of such design as to identify the vehicle as a taxicab. Driver, when holding forth their cab for hire, shall have the cruising lights on from sundown to sunup. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-113. - Interior light. 
    Every taxicab shall be equipped with a light capable of illuminating the interior of the taxicab and controlled by the operation of the doors or manually controlled by the driver. Such light shall be in use while passengers are entering or leaving the taxicab during hours of darkness. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-114. - Shades or curtains. 
    No taxicab shall be equipped with shades or curtains which can be manipulated in such a way as to shield the occupants or driver from observation from without the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-115. - Paint. 
    Every taxicab shall be painted in accordance with the operator's certificate color scheme and in such manner as to give a good appearance and reasonable protection, from all elements, to all exposed surfaces. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-116. - Identifying markings. 
    All identifying markings on taxicabs shall be plainly distinguishable in letters at least three (3) inches high permanently painted or otherwise permanently affixed to each of the two (2) sides of the taxicab and to the rear of the taxicab. The lettering shall show the vehicle number assigned to it by its owner or operator and the name of the company, individual or association by whom the taxicab is owned or operated. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-117. - Inspection and approval or condemnation. 
(a)  Prior to the use and operation of any taxicab under the provisions of this chapter, the taxicab shall be inspected by the taxicab inspector and found to comply with the provisions of this chapter and the current motor vehicle laws of the state. Every taxicab operating under this chapter shall be inspected semiannually (every six (6) months) by a licensed state inspection station and proof of such inspection shall be furnished to the taxicab inspector within ten (10) days of completion of inspection and at any other reasonable time requested by the taxicab inspector. Such inspections shall be at the time and place designated by the taxicab inspector. 
(b)  If the taxicab is found by the taxicab inspector not to be in compliance with the provisions of this chapter, it shall be condemned and a red tag stating "condemned" shall be affixed on the taximeter in clear view of the public. It shall be unlawful for any person to remove such tag or operate such taxicab for hire until the deficiencies have been corrected and the taxicab has been reinspected and approved by the taxicab inspector. 
(c)  If a vehicle cannot be made available for the designated inspection time, either the certificate holder or the driver shall be required to notify the taxicab inspector's office. Failure to notify may result in an imposed suspension to the driver and/or vehicle until such vehicle is inspected and approved by the taxicab inspector. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Secs. 11-118-11-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TAXIMETERS 

Sec. 11-131. - Required; exception. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab, or to cause a taxicab to be operated, for hire, or to accept any passenger for hire, or to carry any paying passenger within the city, unless such vehicle is equipped with a taximeter, which shall be in proper operation at all times while any person other than the operator is riding therein. This section shall not apply to taxicabs which are not on duty and in operation for hire and on which is posted a visible sign clearly marked "off-duty." Such sign shall be displayed on the right-hand sun visor, so it can be seen by the public. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-132. - Type to be used. 
    Taximeters required by this article shall be of a type approved, in writing, by the taxicab inspector. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-133. - Specifications. 
(a)  Taximeters required by this article shall be capable of computing fares on the basis of mileage and time. 
(b)  Every taximeter shall be equipped with a fare recording device, plainly visible to the passenger, and with a signal device, which shall be exhibited at all times while the taxicab is in operation. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-134. - Testing and approval. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to use any taximeter, until the same has been inspected and found to be accurate by a service technician and approved by him. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-135. - Sealing. 
(a)  When a taximeter is inspected and approved by a service technician it shall be sealed by the taxicab inspector. Every taximeter shall be capable of being completely sealed. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a taxicab, unless the taximeter therein is sealed in accordance with this section. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-136. - Cover and gear to be intact. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any taxicab, if the taximeter therein does not have its cover and gear intact. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-137. - Altering or tampering with meter or vehicle parts to which meter attached. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any changes or alterations in any taximeter without the approval of the taxicab inspector. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with any taximeter required by this article, or to in any manner change or cause to be changed any part of any taximeter or any part of any vehicle to which such taximeter is attached, directly or indirectly, which may alter the accuracy of such meter. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make any change in the mechanical condition of the wheels, tires or gears of any taxicab, with intent to cause false registration by the taximeter of the fare to be charged any passenger. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-138. - Removal from vehicle to which assigned; transfer to another vehicle. 
    No taximeter shall be removed from the taxicab to which it is assigned and reinstalled or transferred to another taxicab, without inspection by a service technician or the taxicab inspector. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-139. - Repair of meter by approved repairman. 
(a)  Notwithstanding the provisions contained elsewhere in this article, it shall be lawful for a service technician, approved pursuant to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section, to perform repairs on a taximeter without prior notification having been given to the taxicab inspector, provided that notification of such repairs is given to the taxicab inspector in accordance with the policy in effect at the time of the repairs. A taximeter so repaired may be used without further inspection by the taxicab inspector, provided that the service technician tests the vehicle on an approved course if the taximeter seal is broken during any such repairs. 
(b)  The taxicab inspector shall maintain a list of all persons authorized to perform repairs on taximeters as set out in subsection (a), above, which list shall be available for inspection and copying in the office of the taxicab inspector during all normal business hours. The taxicab inspector shall place on the list all persons and businesses having demonstrated a capability to perform repairs on taximeters, who have made application to be included on the list, in accordance with regulations to be promulgated by the taxicab inspector. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Secs. 11-140-11-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - FARES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 11-151. - Rates generally. 
(a)  The rates for the transportation of passengers in the city by taxicabs shall be as follows: 
(1)  For the initial hiring or activation of the meter for service, and to include the first one-tenth ( 1/10 ) of a mile or fraction thereof, the sum of three dollars ($3.00). For each additional one-tenth ( 1/10 ) of a mile or fraction thereof, the sum of fifteen cents ($0.15). 
(2)  For each passenger carried in excess of one (1), except for an infant in arms up to and including two (2) years of age, the sum of one dollar ($1.00), regardless of distance traveled. 
(3)  For each twenty-seven (27) seconds waiting time, the sum of fifteen cents ($0.15). 
(b)  For the purposes of subsection (a)(3) above, waiting time shall be deemed to include: 
(1)  Time consumed while the taxicab is waiting and unavailable to other passengers for hire, beginning five (5) minutes after the later of (i) time of arrival at the place to which it has been called, or (ii) the agreed pick-up time. 
(2)  Time consumed while the taxicab is stopped, or slowed for traffic to a speed less than fifteen (15) miles per hour. While such time is charged, there shall be no charges for mileage under subsection (a)(1)-(3) of this section. 
(3)  Time consumed for delays or stopovers en route at the direction of the passenger or customer. Waiting time shall not include time lost on account of inefficiency of the taxicab, police traffic stop, vehicle accident involving the taxicab or any delay caused by the driver. 
(c)  When a driver has taken into a taxicab a passenger for transportation and has actually begun the transportation of such passenger, no other person shall be received by the driver into such taxicab until the original passenger's destination is reached, except with the consent of such original passenger. No charge shall be made for the additional passenger, except when the additional passenger rides beyond the original passenger's destination. Where the meter shall be reset to compute the additional passenger's fare to his destination. This subsection shall not apply to the exceptions listed in section 11-159. 
(d)  In cases where more than one (1) passenger enters a taxicab at the same time and bound for different destinations, the fare shall be charged as follows: Whenever a passenger gets out and pays the fare, then the meter shall be reset upon such passenger's departure; however, when such passenger does not pay the fare then the total fare shall be paid by the last passenger delivered. This subsection shall not apply to the exceptions listed in section 11-159. 
(e)  Drivers may give discounted fares of up to twenty-five (25) per cent to passengers carrying a driver's license or other written proof that they are at least sixty-five (65) years old. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-152. - Service charge for pickups beyond three-mile radius of operation. 
    In addition to the rates prescribed by section 11-151, a service charge of one dollar ($1.00) per mile may be charged from the operator's base of operation or closest taxicab stand to the point of pickup, when a request for service is from beyond the operator's three-mile radius of operation; provided that, this charge shall not be allowed unless the prospective passenger is advised of the service charge at the time the service is requested, or if the passenger's destination is within three (3) miles of the operator's base of operation or closest taxicab stand. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-153. - Charge for transporting baggage, groceries, etc. 
(a)  In addition to the rates prescribed in section 11-151, the operator of a taxicab may impose and collect the following charges: 
(1)  A transportation charge, not to exceed twenty-five cents ($0.25), for baggage or suitcases handled by the driver, in excess of two (2) per passenger. 
(2)  A transportation charge for trunks, large boxes or similar containers of three (3) cubic feet or more of one dollar ($1.00). 
(3)  A transportation charge, not to exceed ten cents ($0.10), for bags of groceries or other shopping bags handled by the driver, in excess of two (2) per passenger. 
(4)  A transportation charge of fifty cents ($0.50) for large boxes, bags or similar containers less than three (3) cubic feet. 
(5)  A cleanup charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) if a passenger vomits or expectorates or otherwise causes an odor, wets, or stains the interior on the upholstery or other surface of a taxicab or leaves any article in the taxicab that may cause a health risk so that it requires more than a reasonable effort to clean or remove before a driver can go back into service. 
(6)  A reimbursement charge equal to any road tolls, parking fees or other toll or fee incurred by a driver to provide the requested service to a passenger. 
(b)  None of the charges authorized by this section shall be allowed unless a list of such charges is available to the passenger at his/her request and the driver informs the passenger of such charges. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-154. - Charge for transporting animals. 
    In addition to the rates prescribed by section 11-151, the operator of a taxicab may charge one dollar ($1.00) for the transportation of any animal other than one held by the passenger or assisting a bona fide handicapped person. If any animal should litter a taxicab, an additional charge may be made of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-155. - Charge for personal services. 
(a)  In addition to the rates prescribed by sections 11-151 and 11-153, a personal-service charge, not to exceed two dollars ($2.00), may be charged by the operator of a taxicab, when a personal service is performed. A "personal service" is defined as any service, at the request of the passenger or customer, which requires the driver to leave the vicinity of the taxicab. Each request by the passenger or customer shall constitute a separate personal service, for which a separate charge may be made. 
(b)  No charge authorized by this section shall be allowed unless the passenger or customer is advised of the charge when he requests the service and before it is performed. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-156. - Procedure for changing fares or rates. 
    Any petition for increase or decrease of fares or rates prescribed by this article shall be presented in writing to the governing body. The board shall, after public notice and after a public hearing, make a determination whether the rate changes are just and reasonable. If found to be just and reasonable, such changes shall become effective sixty (60) days thereafter or at such other time as the board may ordain. This procedure shall constitute an automatic revision of the fares or rates prescribed in this article and each subsequent vote of the governing body to increase or decrease such fares or rates shall constitute an amendment to this article, and shall be recorded as such by the clerk to the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-157. - Posting of rates. 
    The rates prescribed by this article shall be posted in such a manner as to be easily visible to all passengers in a taxicab and passengers entering a taxicab. Rate posters shall be supplied by the taxicab inspector to all operators, who shall be charged the actual cost for production of the same. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-158. - Unlawful charges. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the certificate holder or driver of any taxicab to charge, or knowingly allow to be charged, any fare for the transportation of passengers, except as provided in this article. 
(b)  In no event may a person be charged for loading or unloading a wheelchair into or from a taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-158.1. - Taxicab services and fares for elderly or physically handicapped persons pursuant to a contract between a taxicab certificate holder and the city or a nonprofit private or public organization. 
(a)  The rates and fares provided for under this article shall not apply when any taxicab is operated pursuant to a contract entered into under paragraph (b) of this section. 
(b)  Upon approval of the regional review board, any certificate holder may enter into a contract, on an annual or semiannual basis, with the city or any nonprofit private or public organization to provide taxicab services for elderly, physically handicapped, or low income persons who are certified as eligible in accordance with standards set forth in the contract, under a fare schedule agreed upon in the contract. Such fare schedule may differ from the fares established in other sections of this article. 
(c)  Any certificate holder operating a taxicab pursuant to such a contract shall comply with all other provisions of this chapter, except where otherwise specified. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-159. - Nonpaying passengers. 
(a)  No nonpaying passenger shall be transported with a paying passenger, except bona fide officers or employees of the certificate holder, a police officer engaged in the performance of his duty and unable to obtain other adequate means of transportation, a taxicab inspector, or Medicaid patients and authorized attendants designated by the department of health to be transported under a providers agreement. 
(b)  This section shall not apply when any taxicab is operated pursuant to a contract provided for in section 11-158.1. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-160. - Payment in advance. 
    Any driver may, at his discretion, demand payment, in advance of the rendering of any service, of the estimated charges for such service. Adjustments shall be made at the passenger's destination in accordance with the rates and charges established by this article. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-161. - Refusal to pay; hiring taxicab with intent to defraud. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any taxicab passenger to refuse to pay the legal fare for transporting such passenger and/or any allowable charges under article VII. It shall be unlawful for any person to hire any taxicab with the intent to defraud the operator, owner, or driver of the value of such service. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Sec. 11-162. - Receipt for payment. 
    The driver of any taxicab shall, upon the request of a passenger, give a receipt to the passenger for the fare charged. This receipt shall contain the name of the taxicab company, the taxicab number, the driver's name and permit number, the date and time of the trip, the origin and destination and the amount of the fare. 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-736, § 1, 2-3-04) 
Chapter 12 - GAMBLING 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Gambling device. A "gambling device" includes: 
(1)  Any device, machine, paraphernalia, equipment or other thing, including books, records and other papers, which are actually used in an illegal gambling operation or activity, and 
(2)  Any machine, apparatus, implement, instrument, contrivance, board or other thing, including but not limited to those dependent upon the insertion of a coin or other object for their operation, which operates, either completely automatically or with the aid of some physical act by the player or operator, in such a manner that, depending upon elements of chance, it may eject something of value or determine the prize or other thing of value to which the player is entitled; provided, however, that the return to the user of nothing more than additional chances or the right to use such machine is not deemed something of value; and provided further, that machines that only sell, or entitle the user to, items of merchandise of equivalent value that may differ from each other in composition, size, shape or color, shall not be deemed gambling devices. 
Such devices are no less gambling devices if they indicate beforehand the definite result of one or more operations but not all the operations, nor are they any less gambling devices because, apart from their use or adaptability as such, they may also sell or deliver something of value on a basis other than chance. 
    Illegal gambling. The making, placing or receipt of any bet or wager in this city of money or other thing of value, made in exchange for a chance to win a prize, stake or other consideration or thing of value, dependent upon the result of any game, contest or any other event the outcome of which is uncertain or a matter of chance, whether such game, contest or event occurs or is to occur inside or outside the limits of this city, shall constitute illegal gambling. 
    Operator. An "operator" includes any person, firm or association of persons, who conducts, finances, manages, supervises, directs or owns all or part of an illegal gambling enterprise, activity or operation. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-325. 
Sec. 12-2. - Illegal gambling generally. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, any person who illegally gambles shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. If an association or pool of persons illegally gamble, each person therein shall be guilty of illegal gambling. 
(Code 1971, § 10-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-326. 
Sec. 12-3. - Winning by fraud. 
    If any person, while gambling, cheats or by fraudulent means wins or acquires for himself or another, money or any other valuable thing, he shall be fined not less than five (5) nor more than ten (10) times the value of such winnings. This penalty shall be in addition to any other penalty imposed under this chapter. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-327. 
Sec. 12-4. - Permitting gambling to continue on one's premises. 
    If the owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or other person in control of any place or conveyance knows, or reasonably should know, that it is being used for illegal gambling, and permits such gambling to continue without having notified a law-enforcement officer of the presence of such illegal gambling activity, he shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 10-3) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-329. 
Sec. 12-5. - Aiding or abetting operation of illegal gambling activity. 
    Any person, other than those persons specified in other sections of this chapter, who knowingly aids, abets or assists in the operation of an illegal gambling activity shall be guilty of a Class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 10-4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-330. 
Sec. 12-6. - Manufacture, sale, possession, etc., of gambling devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell, transport, rent, give away, place or possess any gambling device or conduct or negotiate any transaction affecting or designed to affect ownership, custody or use of any gambling device, believing or having reason to believe that the same is to be used in the advancement of any illegal gambling activity. A violation of this section shall constitute a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 10-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-331. 
Sec. 12-7. - Forfeiture of money, gambling devices, etc., seized from illegal gambling enterprise. 
    All money, gambling devices, office equipment and other personal property used in connection with an illegal gambling enterprise or activity, and all money, stakes and things of value received or proposed to be received by a winner in any illegal gambling transaction, which are lawfully seized by any city police officer or which shall lawfully come into his custody, shall be forfeited to the city by order of the court in which a conviction under this chapter is obtained. Such court shall order all money so forfeited to be paid over to the city and, by order, shall make such disposition of other property so forfeited as the court deems proper, including award of such property to any city or state agency or charitable organization for lawful purposes, or in case of the sale thereof, the proceeds therefrom to be paid over to the city. Such forfeiture shall not extinguish the rights of any person without knowledge of the illegal use of such property who is the lawful owner or who has a lien on the same which has been perfected in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1971, §§ 10-2, 10-14) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-336. 
Sec. 12-8. - Certain acts not deemed "consideration" in prosecution under chapter. 
    In any prosecution under this chapter, no consideration shall be deemed to have passed or been given because of any person's attendance upon the premises of another; his execution, mailing or delivery of an entry blank; his answering of questions, verbally or in writing; his witnessing of a demonstration or other proceeding; or any one or more thereof, where no charge is made to, paid by, or any purchase required of him in connection therewith. 
(Code 1971, § 10-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-332. 
Sec. 12-9. - Exceptions from chapter-Contests of speed or skill. 
(a)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent any contest of speed or skill between men, animals, fowl or vehicles, where participants may receive prizes or different percentages of a purse, stake or premium dependent upon whether they win or lose or dependent upon their position or score at the end of such contest. 
(b)  Any participant who, for the purpose of competing for any such purse, stake or premium offered in any such contest, knowingly and fraudulently enters any contestant other than the contestant purported to be entered or knowingly and fraudulently enters a contestant in a class in which he or it does not belong, shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-333. 
Sec. 12-10. - Same-Games of chance in private residences. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to make it illegal to participate in a game of chance conducted in a private residence, provided such private residence is not commonly used for such games of chance and there is no operator, as defined in section 12-1. 
(Code 1971, § 10-6) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-334. 
Sec. 12-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 96-1700-545, adopted June 18, 1996, repealed former section 12-11 in its entirety which pertained to the exemption of bingo games permitted by state law from the regulations of this chapter and which derived from this codification. 
Chapter 13 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Disposition of dead animals, § 5-7; unlawful accumulations of garbage and trash, § 17-48. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require property owners to remove garbage and refuse and city's right to operate a garbage and refuse disposal service, Code of Virginia, §§ 15.1-901, 15.1-927. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance 05-1700-784 of August 1, 2005, added the titles Article I, In General, §§ 13-1-13-6, Article II, Reserved, §§ 13-7-13-10, and Article III, Dumpsters, §§ 13-11-13-19. 

Sec. 13-1. - Containers required for city collection. 
    Trash or garbage will not be removed from any premises by the agents of the city, unless placed in a galvanized, aluminum or plastic container not larger than thirty (30) gallons in capacity. 
(Code 1971, § 22-3) 
Sec. 13-2. - Placement for collection. 
    Any person desiring the collection and disposition, by the agents of the city, of accumulated trash and garbage shall place the containers holding such trash and garbage at the curb in such location as to be convenient to the agents of the city; provided, however, that any such trash and/or garbage shall not be placed in front of or adjacent to a residential mailbox so as to obstruct or retard the passage of the United States mail or any carrier or vehicle carrying the mail. Any person so setting out trash and garbage for collection shall also be responsible for the removal of the emptied containers. 
(Code 1971, § 22-4; Ord. No. 07-1700-821, § 1, 2-20-07) 
Cross reference- Placing obstructions in or on streets, gutters and sidewalks, § 20-3; vehicles obstructing mailboxes, § 24-48. 
Sec. 13-3. - Collection schedule. 
    Trash and garbage accumulated by the people of the city will be collected and disposed of by the agents of the city in accordance with such schedule as may be established by the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 22-5) 
Sec. 13-4. - Unlawful disposal generally. 
    No person shall dump or deposit any garbage, rubbish or trash anywhere in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 22-1) 
Cross reference- Unlawful accumulations of garbage and trash, § 17-48. 
Sec. 13-5. - Littering. 
    No person shall place, throw or otherwise deposit, or cause to be deposited, any trash, refuse, litter or garbage in or on any public street, public property, parking lots, walks or alleys within the city, or upon any private property not his own. 
(Code 1971, § 22-2) 
Cross reference- Deposit of hazardous or injurious materials on, and removal thereof from, streets, § 20-8. 
State Law reference- Litter control and recycling, Code of Virginia, § 10.1-1414 et seq. 
Sec. 13-6. - Outdoor storage and use of indoor furniture prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection: 
    Indoor furniture. Furniture and similar objects that are not specifically designed by the manufacturer to withstand the elements or are otherwise not intended for outdoor use. Indoor furniture includes, but is not limited to, beds and upholstered chairs and couches. 
    Outdoor area. That portion of real property or the improvements located thereon that is not fully enclosed and/or fully roofed so as to provide effective protection from the elements. Outdoor areas include, but are not limited to, yards, driveways and unenclosed porches. Fully-screened and fully-roofed porches and lanais are specifically excluded from this definition. 
(b)  Unless otherwise permitted under the provisions of chapter 31 of this Code, no person who owns, or is in possession, in charge or in control of, any real property within Manassas Park shall store or keep in the outdoor area of said real property any indoor furniture. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-728, § 1, 10-21-03) 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED. 

Secs. 13-7-13-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DUMPSTERS 

Sec. 13-11. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall have the meaning ascribed to them herein: 
    Bulky waste . Stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, appliances, furnaces, plumbing equipment (e.g. toilets, sinks, tubs), furniture and other waste materials. 
    Construction debris . Conventional waste building materials resulting from building construction, remodeling, repair and/or demolition operations. 
    Dumpster . A device or container one (1) cubic yard or more in size used or intended for the storage of bulky waste, construction debris, refuse, and like materials. 
    Hazardous material . Material which is hazardous, volatile, highly inflammable, radioactive, or otherwise dangerous, including asbestos fibers, infectious waste, all petroleum-based distillates, liquids, gasses and suspensions, alcohol-based liquids, and any other material which, under any federal, state, or city law must be disposed of in any manner other than by being placed in a sanitary landfill. 
    Permit . A permit issued by the director of public works or designated representative authorizing the temporary placement of a dumpster, a portable storage facility, or trash in or upon a street or public grounds or upon private property. 
    Portable storage facility . A portable device or container one (1) cubic yard or more in size used or intended for the storage of personal property. 
    Refuse . Any and all waste wood, wood products, tree trimmings, grass cuttings, dead plants, weeds, leaves, dead trees or branches thereof, chips, shavings, sawdust, printed matter, paper, pasteboard, rags, straw, discarded mattresses, discarded clothing, shoes and boots, waste pulp and other products such as are used for packaging or wrapping ashes, cinders, floor sweepings, glass, mineral or metallic substances, and any and all other waste materials not otherwise included in the definitions herein. 
    Organic waste . Waste (animal, vegetable and/or other matter) that results from the use or consumption of meats, fish, fowl, birds, fruits, grains or other animal or vegetable matter (including, but not by way of limitation, discarded cans and other food containers and all putrescible or decomposable waste animal or vegetable matter which is likely to attract flies, rodents or other pest), manure and other waste matter normally accumulated in or about a stable, or any animal, livestock or poultry enclosure, and resulting from the keeping of animals, poultry or livestock 
    Trash . Bulky waste, construction debris, refuse and like materials placed within public right-of-way and not stored or placed in a dumpster or portable storage facility. The term "trash" specifically excludes hazardous material and organic waste. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-12. - Temporary placement of dumpsters, portable storage facilities and trash within public rights-of-way. 
    It shall be illegal for any person to place one (1) or more dumpsters, portable storage facilities or trash in or upon any street or public grounds or upon private property without first having obtained a permit. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-13. - Permit. 
(a)  Every person seeking to place one (1) or more dumpsters, portable storage facilities or trash in or upon a street or public grounds or upon private property shall apply to the director of public works or designated representative for a permit. No permit shall be issued for placement one (1) or more dumpsters, portable storage facilities or trash on a street or public grounds unless placement on private property is not reasonably feasible. 
(b)  The application fee for a permit allowing the temporary placement of dumpsters, portable storage facilities and/or trash on a street or public grounds shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). The application fee is waived for any permit allowing the temporary placement of dumpsters, portable storage facilities and/or trash upon private property. 
(c)  Every applicant for a permit to place of one or more dumpsters, portable storage facilities or trash in or upon a street or public grounds shall provide a refundable bond in the amount of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to cover the cost to repair any damage caused by the applicant's use of the street or public grounds for such purpose. No permit shall be issued until such bond has been provided to the city. If the cost to repair any damage caused by the applicant's use of the street or public grounds exceeds the value of such bond, such amount shall become a personal debt of the applicant, immediately due and owing to the city. 
(d)  Application for a permit must be submitted to the director of public works or designated representative at least seven (7) days prior to the proposed placement of one (1) or more dumpsters, portable storage facilities or trash. 
(e)  Each permit holder shall allow access to private property by the director of public works or designate representative, and the building official, during reasonable hours of the day to verify compliance with the applicable provisions of this article. 
(f)  By applying for a permit, each applicant agrees to allow access to private property to the extent necessary to verify compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-14. - Duration of permits. 
(a)  Permits issued for placement on streets and/or public grounds shall be limited in duration as follows: 
(1)  Dumpsters. Thirty (30) days; 
(2)  Portable storage facilities. Fourteen (14) days; 
(3)  Trash. Seven (7) days. 
(b)  Permits issued for placement on private property shall be limited in duration to ninety (90) days. 
(c)  The duration of permits may be extended for good cause shown at the discretion of the director of public works or designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-15. - General restrictions and requirements. 
(a)  No dumpster, portable storage facility or trash shall be transported, emptied or serviced between the hours of 9:00 P.M. and 7:00 A.M. on any day, nor shall any mechanical, hydraulic or electrical loader, compactor, packer or conveyor be utilized during such hours. 
(b)  No dumpster or portable storage facility shall be filled beyond the top of such dumpster or portable storage facility. Trash shall not be piled higher than three (3) feet and shall not interfere with the flow of traffic. Dumpsters and portable storage facilities shall be emptied as soon as practical when full; trash shall be hauled away as soon as it threatens to impede the flow of traffic or is three (3) feet high. 
(c)  No dumpster or portable storage facility shall be filled by means of a chute, conveyor, belt, or other device, located in, above, on or across a street, or by dropping or throwing items in, above, on or across a street, unless the permit authorizing placement of such dumpster or portable storage facility specifically authorizes such method. 
(d)  When not in use, all dumpsters and portable storage facilities shall be covered with a tarpaulin or otherwise secured, as approved by director of public works or designated representative, to prevent debris from blowing out of the container. Trash shall be secured to ensure it is properly contained. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-16. - General placement; visibility. 
(a)  Dumpsters, portable storage facilities and trash shall not be placed closer than thirty (30) feet from any intersection, or upon any one-way street. The director of public works or designated representative must approve the proposed location of any dumpster, portable storage facility or trash placed in or upon a street or public grounds. 
(b)  A placard or decal shall be affixed to each dumpster, portable storage facility and/or trash until such time as the dumpster, portable storage facility or trash is removed. Such placard or decal shall have one (1) or more warning signs of a contrasting color to identify that the container is dangerous, that children should be kept away, that that playing in, on or about the dumpster, portable storage facility or trash is forbidden. 
(c)  Dumpsters, portable storage facilities and trash placed in or upon a street or public grounds shall be visible at night from all angles of traffic flow. Means to provide nighttime visibility include but are not limited to the use of reflecting tape at least two (2) inches in width, reflectors, cones or other methods as approved by the director of public works or designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-17. - Emergency removal. 
    In the event of an emergency any dumpster, portable storage facility or trash be removed by the director of public works or designated representative, and/or police or fire personnel. The city shall not be liable for any loss or damage caused by such emergency removal. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-18. - Use restrictions. 
(a)  No hazardous material or organic waste shall be placed in a dumpster or portable storage facility. Any trash authorized for placement pursuant to this article shall not include hazardous material or organic waste. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the permit holder to maintain the dumpster or storage unit rodent, vermin or insects free. 
(c)  Any person who violates the restrictions set forth herein shall be personally liable for such actions. This liability is in addition to any criminal sanctions that may be imposed. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 13-19. - Penalty. 
    Violation of this article shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor and shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-784, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Chapter 13.1 - GRAFFITI PREVENTION AND REMOVAL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13.1-1. - Purpose and intent. 
    It is the purpose and intent of this chapter to prevent damage to and defacement of public and private buildings, walls, fences and other structures and to provide for a procedure to remove graffiti from public and private buildings, walls, fences and other structures. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-2. - Graffiti declared a nuisance. 
    The existence of graffiti within the jurisdictional limits of the City of Manassas Park in violation of this chapter is expressly declared by the governing body to be a public nuisance, which must be quickly removed and abated as provided herein to avoid the detrimental impact of such graffiti on the city and its residents and to prevent the further spread of graffiti. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-3. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meaning ascribed to them herein: 
    Application of graffiti means any form or act of drawing, painting, scrawling, writing, marking, inscribing, scratching, gluing, posting or otherwise affixing graffiti to public or private property. 
    Graffiti includes writings, drawings, inscriptions, etchings, figures or marks of paint, ink, chisel, chalk, dye, acid or other similar substances, or flyers, bills and similar materials, which have been placed on any public or private building, wall, fence or other structure without the permission of the owner, manager or occupant of the property or which is otherwise deemed by the city to be a public nuisance. 
    Jurisdictional limits of the city means the area within which the city's police powers may be used, including the area within the corporate limits of the City of Manassas Park and the city-owned properties known as Signal Hill Park and Generals Ridge Golf Course. 
    Person means any individual, firm, owner, sole proprietorship, corporation, unincorporated association, governmental body, municipal corporation, executor, administrator, trustee, guardian, agent, occupant or other legal entity. 
    Private property means any portion of a privately-owned building, wall, fence or other structure that is visible from any street, sidewalk or public grounds. 
    Public property means any publicly-owned building, wall, fence or other structure. 
    Removal of graffiti means removal, obscuration and/or abatement of graffiti and/or repair of the damage and/or defacement of any property resulting from the application of graffiti. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-4. - Graffiti prohibited; criminal penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to willfully or maliciously deface or damage by application of graffiti any public property or private property within the jurisdictional limits of the city. Any person convicted of a violation of this subsection shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. The punishment for any such violation in which the defacement is (i) more than twenty (20) feet off the ground, (ii) on a railroad or highway overpass, or (iii) committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with any criminal street gang, as that term is defined by Virginia Code § 18.2-46.1, shall include a mandatory minimum fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  Upon a finding of guilt in any case tried before the court without a jury, in the event the violation constitutes a first offense which results in property damage or loss, the court, without entering a judgment of guilt, upon motion of the defendant, may defer further proceedings and place the defendant on probation pending completion of a plan of community service work. If the defendant fails or refuses to complete the community service as ordered by the court, the court may make final disposition of the case and proceed as otherwise provided. If the community service work is completed as the court prescribes, the court may discharge the defendant and dismiss the proceedings against him. Discharge and dismissal under this section shall be without adjudication of guilt and is a conviction only for the purposes of applying this chapter in subsequent proceedings. 
(c)  Any community service ordered by the court shall, to the extent feasible, include the repair, restoration or replacement of any damage or defacement to property within the jurisdictional limits of the city, and may include clean-up, beautification, landscaping or other appropriate community service within the jurisdictional limits of the city. The chief of police, or his designee, shall supervise the performance of any community service work required and shall report thereon to the court imposing such requirement. At or before the time of sentencing under this chapter, the court shall receive and consider any plan for making restitution or performing community service submitted by the defendant. The court shall also receive and consider the recommendations of the city's supervisor of community services concerning the plan. 
(d)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no person convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be placed on probation or have his sentence suspended unless such person has made at least partial restitution for such property damage or is compelled to perform community services, or both in accordance with Virginia Code § 19.2-305.1. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-5. - Parental liability for cost of graffiti. 
    If the application of graffiti to any public property is made by a minor who is living with either or both parents or a legal guardian, the city may institute an action and recover from either or both of the parents of the minor or from the legal guardian, as applicable, the costs for damages suffered by reason of the willful or malicious destruction of, or damage to, public property by the minor. The action by the city shall be subject to any limitation of the amount of recovery set forth in Virginia Code § 8.01-43, or other applicable state law. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-6. - Removal of graffiti. 
(a)  The city manager is authorized to undertake or contract for removal of graffiti from any public property. 
(b)  The city manager is also authorized to undertake or contract for removal of graffiti from any private property, in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  Prior to such removal of graffiti, the city manager shall issue to the property owner, by certified mail, return receipt requested, sent to the last address listed for the owner in the city's property assessment records, a notice which states: (i) the street address and legal description of the property; (ii) that the property has been determined by the city to constitute a graffiti nuisance; (iii) that the owner must undertake and complete removal of graffiti from the property within ten (10) days of the date of the owner's receipt of the notice or refusal of the owner to receive the notice; and (iv) that if removal of graffiti is not undertaken and completed within the ten-day period, the city will either (1) begin removal of graffiti and charge the cost of such removal of graffiti to the property owner, or (2) institute legal action to require the property owner to undertake and complete removal of graffiti from the property. If the property owner has not completed the removal of graffiti from the subject property within fifteen (15) days after the property owner's receipt of the notice or refusal to receive the notice, the city manager will be authorized to promptly undertake removal of graffiti from the property. 
(2)  Before entering upon private property for the purposes set forth in this section, the city shall attempt to obtain the consent of the property owner, occupant or other responsible party. If no owner or occupant or other responsible person can be found to whom to direct the notice provided for in this subsection, the city, after giving five (5) days' notice in a newspaper having general circulation in the city, may proceed to remove the graffiti and/or repair the property and charge the property owner or other responsible party for costs therefor as provided for in section 13.1-8 below. 
(c)  When a structure that has been damaged or defaced by the application of graffiti is owned by a public entity other than the city, removal of graffiti by the city shall be authorized after securing the consent of an authorized representative of the public entity having jurisdiction over the structure or, if such consent cannot be obtained after a reasonable effort has been made, in accordance with the procedure for removal of graffiti from private property described in subsection 13.1-6(2) above. 
(d)  In addition to the foregoing, the city manager is authorized to institute appropriate legal action on behalf of the city, including but not limited to actions pursuant to Virginia Code, § 15.2-900, to compel the owner or owners of the subject property to remove any graffiti and/or repair the property at the owner's own cost. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-7. - Emergency removal of graffiti. 
    If the city manager determines that any graffiti is an immediate danger to the public health, safety or welfare, he may undertake or contract for emergency removal of graffiti from any private property forty-eight (48) hours after the later of (i) mailing to the subject property owner or other responsible person the notice described in paragraph 13.1-6(2)(a) above, and (ii) posting notice of the impending emergency removal of graffiti in a conspicuous place on the subject property. The city may bring an action against the property owner or other responsible party to recover the necessary costs reasonably required for removal of graffiti from the subject property as provided for in section 13.1-8 below. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-8. - Assessment of costs against property owner for removal of graffiti from private property. 
(a)  If the city undertakes removal of graffiti from private property after complying with the notice provisions of paragraph 13.1-6(2)(a) or section 13.1-7 above, as applicable, then the total cost for such removal of graffiti shall be chargeable to and paid by the subject property owner, and may be collected as a special assessment against the respective lot or parcel of land to which it relates in the manner in which city taxes and levies are collected. 
(b)  Every charge authorized by this section with which the owner of any such property has been assessed and which remains unpaid shall constitute a lien against such property with the same priority as liens for unpaid local taxes and enforceable in the same manner as such liens. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-9. - Retention of rights. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to be a limitation on the rights of the city to seek and enforce the removal of graffiti by any other means or remedies available at law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Sec. 13.1-10. - Severability. 
    If any, section, subsection, paragraph, sentence or part of this chapter is for any reason determined by a court of competent jurisdiction law to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-847, § 1, 3-11-08) 
Chapter 13.3 - HEALTH, SAFETY AND WELFARE 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 13.3-1-13.3-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HEALTH AND SAFETY MENACES 

Sec. 13.3-15. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Designated enforcement officer. The director of community development or his designee, any city law enforcement officer, or any duly designated sworn special police officer. 
    Hazardous waste. Any hazardous material (as defined in section 13-11) which, because of its quantity, concentration or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, may: 
(1)  Cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating illness; or 
(2)  Pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed. 
    Public health or safety menace. Any condition which might endanger the health or safety of the public, including but not limited to: 
(1)  Unsanitary or improper storage or disposal of trash, garbage, refuse, debris, other solid waste or hazardous waste; 
(2)  Unburied dead animals; 
(3)  Accumulation of water causing mosquito or other vector breeding or proliferation; 
(4)  Rodent or insect infestation; 
(5)  Accumulation of bees, fowl or animals in such a manner as to create a condition that may be injurious to the public health or safety; 
(6)  The accumulation of solid waste or hazardous waste in such a manner as to create a condition that may be injurious to the public health or safety; 
(7)  Hazards such as open excavations, open wells, pits, or parts thereof in danger of falling, discarded refrigerators and freezers with doors attached, unsecured vacant structures, and or habitation for bats, wasps or other venomous pests; 
(8)  Garbage that is not contained in a watertight, rodent proof container that is equipped with a tightfitting lid; 
(9)  Improper disposal of medical, dental, veterinary or pharmaceutical equipment or supplies, including but not limited to syringes, needles, scalpels, blades and other medicinal items in solid or liquid form, in such a manner as to make it possible for any other person to retrieve and utilize said equipment or supplies; 
(10)  Any other condition that may be injurious to the public health or safety. 
    Solid waste. Any refuse, bulky waste, organic waste (as those terms are defined in section 13-11), garbage, sludge, or other discarded material, including solid, liquid, semisolid, or contained gaseous material, resulting from industrial, commercial, mining or agricultural operations or from community activities. The term "solid waste" does not include: 
(1)  Solid or dissolved material in domestic sewage; 
(2)  Solid or dissolved material in irrigation return flows or in industrial discharges which are sources subject to a permit from the state water control board; or 
(3)  Source, special nuclear, or byproduct material as defined by the Federal Atomic Energy Act of 1954, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 2, 6-21-16) 
Sec. 13.3-16. - Health or safety menaces prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to create or maintain with the city any public health or safety menace. 
(Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 2, 6-21-16) 
Sec. 13.3-17. - Inspection and notice. 
(a)  The designated enforcement officer is authorized to inspect occupied or vacant land or premises to ascertain the existence of health or safety menaces on such land or premises. The designated enforcement officer shall inspect the land or premises at reasonable daylight times in a reasonable manner. If the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises denies the designated enforcement officer free access for such purposes, the designated enforcement officer may inspect after obtaining a search warrant from a Virginia court of competent jurisdiction. 
(b)  When any condition that constitutes a public health or safety menace is found on occupied or vacant land or premises, the designated enforcement officer shall notify in writing the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of such land or premises. Such written notice shall contain a description of the public health or safety menace; the time within which the menace shall be abated, corrected or eliminated; a statement that the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises may request a hearing within ten (10) days of the receipt of the notice; and an address or telephone number at which information may be obtained concerning such public health or safety menace. The amount of time allowed to abate, correct or eliminate the condition shall be forty-eight (48) hours. Upon a good-faith showing that a longer period of time is required to abate, correct or eliminate the condition, the designated enforcement officer may allow a longer period of time, not to exceed ten (10) days. Notice sent by registered or certified mail to the last known address of the owner as shown on the current real estate tax assessment books shall be deemed compliance with the notice requirement to the owner. 
(c)  When the written notice as provided for in this section is undeliverable, or if an emergency is found to exist, the designated enforcement officer shall cause a notice, as described in subsection (b) above, to be posted on the land or premises on which the public health or safety menace exists. 
(Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 2, 6-21-16) 
Sec. 13.3-18. - Health or safety menaces abatement, correction or elimination. 
(a)  Following receipt of the written notice required by section 13.3-17, the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises on which a public health or safety menace exists, shall promptly abate, correct or eliminate the public health or safety menace as required by the notice. Failure to abate, correct or eliminate the public health or safety menace within the time required shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(b)  If the written notice is undeliverable and is therefore posted, or if, after the receipt of the written notice, the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises on which the condition exists fails to abate, correct or eliminate the condition as required, the designated enforcement officer, after granting such owner, lessee, occupant or person in control an opportunity to be heard, may take reasonable steps to abate, correct or eliminate the condition whether the land or premises are occupied or vacant. If the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises denies free access for such purposes, the designated enforcement officer may proceed after obtaining a search warrant from a Virginia court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  Costs and expenses incurred by the city for abating, correcting or eliminated the public health or safety menace that remain unpaid shall be treated as follows: 
(1)  If against the owner of the land or premises, such costs and expenses shall constitute a lien against such property ranking on a parity with liens for unpaid local taxes and shall be enforceable in accordance with Article 3 (Va. Code § 58.1-3940 et seq.) and Article 4 (Va. Code § 58.1-3965 et seq.) of Title 58.1 of the Code of Virginia. The city may waive such liens in order to facilitate the sale of the property. Such liens may be waived only as to a purchaser who is unrelated by blood or marriage to the owner and who has no business association with the owner. All such liens shall remain a personal obligation of the owner of the property at the time the liens were imposed. 
(2)  If against the lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises, such costs and expenses shall constitute a personal obligation of such lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises. 
(Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 2, 6-21-16) 
Sec. 13.3-19. - Emergency procedure. 
    In the case of an emergency, the designated enforcement officer may take reasonable steps to abate, correct or eliminate, to the extent immediately necessary, a public health and safety menace without providing the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises an opportunity to be heard until afterwards. In such an emergency, any request for hearing must be made within ten (10) days after the condition is abated, corrected or eliminated. 
(Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 2, 6-21-16) 
Sec. 13.3-20. - Hearing and appeals procedure. 
    Each hearing request shall be in writing and directed to the designated enforcement officer who issued the notice, who shall forward any such request to the city manager within two (2) days of its receipt. All hearings shall be before the city manager or the city manager's designee. The city manager, or the designee of the city manager, shall set a time and place for the hearing, which shall occur within ten (10) days of the request for the hearing, and shall so notify the designated enforcement officer and the appellant. After the hearing, the city manager, or the designee of the city manager, may order the appellant to abate, correct or eliminate the health or safety menace in the same manner as the designated enforcement officer may require. Any person who fails, refuses, or neglects to comply with any such order shall be guilty of violating the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 2, 6-21-16) 
Sec. 13.3-20.1. - Penalty. 
    If after receipt of the written notice or an order from the city manager or the designee of the city manager, the owner, lessee, occupant or person in control of the land or premises refuses or neglects to abate, correct or eliminate the condition as required, such individual shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. Further, each additional day that the violation of this article continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 2, 6-21-16) 
ARTICLE III. - CLEAN AIR[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-1700-428, adopted Oct. 16, 1990, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Ch. 13.3, Art. I, §§ 13.3-1-13.3-6. In order to maintain the structural integrity of the Code as well as to provide space for future expansion of said Ch. 13.3, said provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 13.3, Art. II, §§ 13.3-21-13.3-26 at the discretion of the editor.  Subsequently, Ord. No. 16-1700-993, § 1, adopted June 21, 2016, renumbered Art. II to Art. III. 

Sec. 13.3-21. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the Clean Air Ordinance of the city of Manassas Park. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-428, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 13.3-22. - Purpose and intent. 
    Based on a substantial body of scientific evidence and based on the 1986 Report of the Surgeon General, entitled "The Health Consequences of Involuntary Smoking," the city hereby acknowledges that passively inhaled tobacco smoke poses a potential health hazard. The purpose of this article is to protect the public health, safety and welfare by regulating smoking in certain city facilities and in other public places in the city. 
(Ord. No. 90-1770-428, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 13.3-23. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article unless the context requires a different meaning: 
    City means the City of Manassas Park. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
    Private workplace means any office or work area which is not open to the public in the normal course of business, except by individual invitation. 
    Smoke or smoking means the carrying of any lighted pipe, cigar, or cigarette of any kind, or any other lighted smoking equipment, or the lighting, inhaling, or exhaling of smoke from a pipe, cigar, or cigarette of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-428, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 13.3-24. - Smoking in governmental facilities. 
(a)  All government buildings owned, leased and/or occupied by the city ("city building") are hereby designated nonsmoking facilities. These facilities include, but are not necessarily limited to: 
(1)  City hall; 
(2)  School board; 
(3)  Public works; 
(4)  Social services; 
(5)  Public safety; and 
(6)  Parks and recreation. 
(b)  The city shall provide reasonable no smoking areas, considering the nature of the use and the size of the building, in all city buildings. The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Public and private assembly rooms when these places are being used for private functions; and 
(2)  Office or work areas which are not entered by the general public in the normal course of business or use of the premises. 
(c)  The city manager shall be responsible for designation of rooms or areas in which smoking is permitted with all city buildings as follows: 
(1)  Designated smoking areas shall not encompass so much of the building structure, space, place, or areas open to the general public that reasonable no smoking areas, considering the nature of the use and size of the building, are not provided; 
(2)  Designated smoking areas shall be separate to the extent reasonably practicable from those rooms or areas entered by the public in the normal use of the particular business or institution; and 
(3)  In designated smoking areas, ventilation systems and existing physical barriers shall be used when reasonably practicable to minimize the permeation of smoke into no smoking areas. However, this section shall not be construed as requiring modifications or alterations to any structure. 
(d)  In all city buildings, the city manager, or his designee, shall post in a clear, conspicuous and appropriate manner a sufficient number of signs, including: "Smoking Permitted," "No Smoking," or "No Smoking Section Available." 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-428, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 13.3-25. - Regulation of smoking in private places of employment. 
    Employers may regulate smoking in the private workplace as they deem appropriate under the following conditions: 
(1)  If the designation of smoking and no smoking areas is the subject of a written agreement between the employer and his employees, the provisions of the written agreement shall control such designation; and 
(2)  A total ban on smoking in any workplace shall only be enforced by the employer upon an affirmative vote of a majority of the affected employees voting, unless such ban is the subject of a contract of employment between the employer and the employees as a prior condition of employment. This section shall not affect no smoking policies established by employers prior to the adoption of this section. 
(Ord. No. 90-1770-428, 10-16-90) 
Sec. 13.3-26. - Smoking prohibited in certain public places. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to smoke in any of the following places: 
(1)  Elevators, regardless of capacity; 
(2)  Common areas in an educational facility, including but not limited to, classrooms, libraries, hallways, auditoriums, and public meeting rooms; 
(3)  Any part of a restaurant designated a "no smoking" area pursuant to the provisions of Chapter 8.1 of the Virginia Indoor Clean Air Act; 
(4)  Indoor service lines and cashier areas; 
(5)  School buses and public conveyances; 
(6)  Election polling rooms; 
(7)  Hospital emergency rooms; and 
(8)  Designated no smoking areas. 
(b)  Any restaurant having a seating capacity of fifty or more persons shall have a designated no smoking area sufficient to meet customer demand. In determining the extent of the no smoking area the following shall not be included as seating capacity: 
(1)  Seats in any bar or lounge area of a restaurant; and 
(2)  Seats in any separate room or section of a restaurant which is used exclusively for private functions. 
(c)  The proprietor or other person in charge of an educational facility, health care facility, or a retail establishment of fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet or more serving the general public, including, but not limited to, department stores, grocery stores, drug stores, clothing stores, and shoe stores, shall designate reasonable no smoking areas, considering the nature of the use and the size of the building. 
(d)  The proprietor or other person in charge of a space subject to the provisions of this article shall post signs stating "Smoking Permitted" or "No Smoking," and in restaurants, signs conspicuous to ordinary public view at or near each public entrance stating "No Smoking Section Available." Any person failing to post such signs may be subject to a civil penalty of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(e)  No person shall smoke in a designated no smoking area and any person who continues to smoke in such area after being asked to refrain from smoking may be subject to a civil penalty of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(f)  This section shall not be construed to permit smoking where it is otherwise prohibited or restricted by other applicable provisions of law. 
(Ord. No. 90-1700-428, 10-16-90) 
Chapter 14 - LICENSES[1] 
Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. 96-1700-552, adopted Dec. 17, 1996, amended Ch. 14 to read as herein set out in §§ 14-1-14-179. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Ch. 14, §§ 14-1-14-179 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 94-1700-506, adopted May 17, 1994; Ord. No. 94-1700-513, adopted Oct. 18, 1994; Ord. No. 95-1700-527, §§ 1, 2, adopted Apr. 4, 1995; and Ord. No. 96-1700-544, adopted May 8, 1996.

State Law reference- Licenses taxes, Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3700 to 58.1-3735. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, and as applied to the businesses, trades, professions, occupations and callings enumerated in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    Affiliated group. "Affiliated group" means: 
(1)  One or more chains of corporations subject to inclusion connected through stock ownership with a common parent corporation which is a corporation subject to inclusion if: 
a.  Stock possessing at least eighty (80) per cent of the voting power of all classes of stock and at least eighty (80) per cent of each class of the nonvoting stock of each of the corporations subject to inclusion, except the common parent corporation, is owned directly by one or more of the other corporations subject to inclusion; and 
b.  The common parent corporation directly owns stock possessing at least eighty (80) per cent of the voting power of all classes of stock and at least eighty (80) per cent of each class of the nonvoting stock of at least one of the other subject to inclusion corporations. As used in this subdivision, the term "stock" does not include nonvoting stock which is limited and preferred as to dividends; the phrase "corporation subject to inclusion" means any corporation within the affiliated group irrespective of the state or country of its incorporation; and the term "receipts" includes gross receipts and gross income. 
(2)  Two (2) or more corporations if five (5) or fewer persons who are individuals, estates or trusts own stock possessing: 
a.  At least eighty (80) per cent of the total combined voting power of all classes of stock entitled to vote or at least eighty (80) per cent of the total value of shares of all classes of the stock of each corporation; and 
b.  More than fifty (50) per cent of the total combined voting power of all classes of stock entitled to vote or more than fifty (50) per cent of the total value of shares of all classes of stock of each corporation, taking into account the stock ownership of each such person only to the extent such stock ownership is identical with respect to each such corporation. 
    When one or more of the corporations subject to inclusion, including the common parent corporation is a nonstock corporation, the term "stock" as used in this subdivision shall refer to the nonstock corporation membership or membership voting rights, as is appropriate to the context. 
    Assessment. "Assessment" means a determination as to the proper rate of tax, the measure to which the tax rate is applied, and ultimately the amount of tax, including additional or omitted tax, that is due. An assessment shall include a written assessment made pursuant to notice by the commissioner of the revenue or a self-assessment made by a taxpayer upon the filing of a return or otherwise not pursuant to notice. Assessments shall be deemed made by the commissioner of the revenue when a written notice of assessment is delivered to the taxpayer by the commissioner of the revenue or an employee of the commissioner of the revenue, or mailed to the taxpayer at his last known address. Self-assessments shall be deemed made when a return is filed, or if no return is required, when the tax is paid. A return filed or tax paid before the last day prescribed by ordinance for the filing or payment thereof shall be deemed to be filed or paid on the last day specified for the filing of a return or the payment of tax, as the case may be. 
    Base year. "Base year" means either the calendar year preceding the license year, except for contractors subject to the provisions of Section 58.1-3715 of the Code of Virginia, or the immediately preceding fiscal year used by the business, provided that the base year employed must coincide with the year used for federal and state income tax purposes. 
    Business. "Business" means a course of dealing which requires the time, attention and labor of the person so engaged for the purpose of earning a livelihood or profit. It implies a continuous and regular course of dealing, rather than an irregular or isolated transaction. A person may be engaged in more than one business. The following acts shall create a rebuttable presumption that a person is engaged in a business: (i) advertising or otherwise holding oneself out to the public as being engaged in a particular business or (ii) filing tax returns, schedules and documents that are required only of persons engaged in a trade or business. 
    Business service occupation. "Business service occupation" includes every business, trade, profession, occupation or calling described in section 14-43(c). 
    Carnival. "Carnival" means an aggregation of shows, amusements, concessions, eating places and riding devices or any of them, operated together on one lot or street or on contiguous lots or streets, moving from place to place, whether or not the same are owned and actually operated by separate persons, firms or corporations. The term includes, but is not limited to, sideshows, dog and pony shows, trained animal shows, circuses and menageries. 
    City. "City" means the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
    Commission merchant. "Commission merchant" means any person engaged in the business of selling merchandise on commission by sample, circular, or catalogue for a regularly established retailer, who has no stock or inventory under his control other than floor samples held for demonstration or sale and owned by the principal retailer. For purposes of this chapter, a commission merchant is engaged in a business service. 
    Commissioner of the revenue. "Commissioner of the revenue" means the commissioner of the revenue of the City of Manassas Park. 
    Commonwealth. "Commonwealth" means the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
    Contractor. "Contractor" includes every person engaged in the conduct of the business, trade, profession, occupation or calling of a contractor as defined in section 14-40. Every person who shall build, erect or construct a house or houses, or building, for the purpose of selling or renting the same, and who shall not have employed therefor in writing a contractor or person who has paid the license tax required by section 14-38(1), and who has acted as superintendent of the whole construction shall, himself, be deemed a contractor and shall be subject to all the provisions of this chapter. Any person who shall erect or construct a house or building and later sell or offer to sell or rent the same, without having himself resided in the same for not less than ninety (90) days, shall be prima facie deemed to have erected or constructed that house or building for the purpose of selling or renting the same. 
    Definite place of business. "Definite place of business" means an office or a location at which occurs a regular and continuous course of dealing for thirty (30) consecutive days or more. A definite place of business for a person engaged in business may include a location leased or otherwise obtained from another person on a temporary or seasonal basis and real property leased to another. A person's residence shall be deemed to be a definite place of business if there is no definite place of business maintained elsewhere and the person is not subject to licensure as a peddler or itinerant merchant. 
    Department. "Department" means the Virginia Department of Taxation. 
    Direct seller. "Direct seller" means any person who engages in the trade or business of selling or soliciting the sale of consumer products primarily in private residences and maintains no public location for the conduct of such business; and receives remuneration for such activities, with substantially all of such remuneration being directly related to sales or other sales-oriented services, rather than to the number of hours worked; and performs such activities pursuant to a written contract between such person and the person for whom the activities are performed and such contract provides that such person will not be treated as an employee with respect to such activities for federal tax purposes. 
    Federally appropriated funds.
