    If any person commits adultery or fornication, as defined in section 17-17 with any person whom he or she is forbidden by law to marry, such person shall be guilty of a misdemeanor; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to apply to a person committing adultery or fornication with his daughter or granddaughter, or with her son or grandson, or her father or his mother. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-366, which declares adultery or fornication by persons mentioned in the proviso to be a felony. 
Sec. 17-19. - Lewd and lascivious cohabitation. 
    If any persons, not married to each other, lewdly and lasciviously associate and cohabit together, or whether married or not, be guilty of open and gross lewdness and lasciviousness, each of them shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. Upon a repetition of the offense, each of them shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-24) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-345. 
Sec. 17-20. - Prostitution generally. 
    Any person who, for money or its equivalent, commits adultery or fornication, as defined in section 17-17, or offers to commit adultery or fornication and thereafter does any substantial act in furtherance thereof, shall be guilty of being a prostitute, or prostitution, which shall be unlawful. 
(Code 1971, § 17-52) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-346. 
Sec. 17-21. - Bawdy places. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any bawdy place, or to frequent, reside in or at or visit, for immoral purposes, any bawdy place. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, "bawdy place" shall mean any place, within or without any building or structure, in this city which, is used or is to be used for lewdness, assignation or prostitution, and the term shall include, but shall not be limited to, every house of prostitution, house of ill fame, bawdy house, house of assignation and brothel. 
(Code 1971, §§ 17-53, 17-54) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-347. 
Sec. 17-22. - Aiding prostitution or illicit sexual intercourse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or any officer, employee or agent of any firm, association or corporation, with knowledge of or good reason to believe the immoral purpose of such visit, to take or transport or assist in taking or transporting or offer to take or transport, on foot or in any way, any person to a place, whether within or without any building or structure, used or to be used for the purpose of lewdness, assignation or prostitution within the city, or to procure or assist in procuring, for the purpose of illicit sexual intercourse, or to give any information or direction to any person with intent to enable such person to commit an act of prostitution. 
(Code 1971, § 17-55) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-348. 
Sec. 17-23. - Using vehicle to promote prostitution or unlawful sexual intercourse. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or chauffeur of any vehicle, with knowledge or reason to believe the same is to be used for such purpose, to use the same or to allow the same to be used for the purpose of prostitution or unlawful sexual intercourse, or to aid or promote such prostitution or unlawful sexual intercourse by the use of such vehicle. 
(Code 1971, § 17-56) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-349. 
Sec. 17-24. - Confinement of persons convicted of violating sections 17-20-17-23. 
    Every person convicted of violating any of the provisions of sections 17-20 through 17-23 shall be punished as for a Class 1 misdemeanor; provided that, in every case in which a city or county farm or hospital is available for the confinement of persons so convicted, confinement may be in such farm or hospital, in the discretion of the court or judge. 
(Code 1971, § 17-57) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-350. 
Sec. 17-25. - Sale, distribution, possession, etc., of controlled substances (drugs). 
(a)  As used in this section, the terms "controlled substances" and "Schedules III, IV, V and VI" refer to those terms as they are used or defined in the State Drug Control Act, being chapter 15.1 (§ 54-524.1 et seq.) of title 54 of the Code of Virginia. 
(b)  Except as authorized provided in the Drug Control Act referred to above, it shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell, give, distribute, or possess with intent to manufacture, sell, give or distribute, any controlled substance classified in Schedule III, IV, V or VI within the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally possess a controlled substance classified in Schedule III or marijuana, within the city, unless the substance was obtained directly from, or pursuant to, a valid prescription or order of a practitioner while acting in the course of his professional practice, or except as otherwise authorized by the Drug Control Act referred to in subsection (a) above. Upon the prosecution of a person for a violation of this subsection, ownership or occupancy of the premises or vehicle upon or in which a controlled substance was found shall not create a presumption that such person either knowingly or intentionally possessed such controlled substance. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conspire to commit any offense defined in this section. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to attempt to commit any offense defined in this section. 
(f)  Any person violating any provision of this section, except subsection (e), shall be deemed guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. Any person violating subsection (e) shall be deemed guilty of a Class 2 misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-247, 18.2-248, 18.2-250, 18.2-256, 18.2-257. 
Sec. 17-26. - Premises frequented by persons under influence of illegally obtained controlled substances or used for illegal possession, distribution, etc., of such substances. 
    Any office, store, shop, restaurant, dance hall, theater, poolroom, clubhouse, storehouse, warehouse, dwelling house, apartment, building of any kind, vehicle, vessel, boat or aircraft which, with the knowledge of the owner, lessor, agent of any such lessor, manager, chief executive officer or operator thereof, is frequented by persons under the influence of illegally obtained controlled substances, as defined in § 54-524.2 of the Code of Virginia, or for the purpose of illegally obtaining possession of, manufacturing or distributing such controlled substances, or which is used for the illegal possession, manufacture or distribution of such controlled substances, shall be deemed a common nuisance. It shall be unlawful for such owner, lessor, agent of any such lessor, manager, chief executive officer or operator to knowingly permit, establish, keep or maintain such a common nuisance. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-258. 
Sec. 17-27. - Inhaling drugs or other noxious chemical substances or causing others to do so. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deliberately smell or inhale any drugs or any other noxious chemical substances, including but not limited to fingernail polish or model airplane glue, containing any ketones, aldehydes, organic acetates, ether, chlorinated hydrocarbons or vapors, with the intent to become intoxicated, inebriated, excited, stupefied or to dull the brain or nervous system. Any person violating the provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than one duly licensed, to deliberately cause, invite or induce any person to smell or inhale any drugs or any other noxious substances or chemicals containing any ketone, aldehydes, organic acetates, ether, chlorinated hydrocarbons or vapors with the intent to intoxicate, inebriate, excite, stupefy or to dull the brain or nervous system of such person. Any person violating the provisions of this subsection shall be guilty of a Class 2 misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-264. 
Sec. 17-28. - Fraudulent use of coin-operated machines or devices. 
(a)  No person shall operate, cause to be operated or attempt to operate or cause to be operated any coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine that operates on the coin-in-the-slot principle, whether of like kind or not, designed only to receive lawful coin of the United States of America, in connection with the use or enjoyment of telephone or telegraph service, parking privileges or any other service, or the sale of merchandise or other property, by means of a slug, or any false, counterfeit, mutilated, sweated or foreign coin, or by any means, method, trick or device whatsoever, not authorized by the owner, lessee or licensee of such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine. 
(b)  No person shall obtain or receive telephone or telegraph service, parking privileges, merchandise or any other service or property from any such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine, designed only to receive lawful coin of the United States of America, without depositing in or surrendering to such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine lawful coin of the United States of America to the amount required therefor by the owner, lessee or licensee of such coin box telephone, parking meter, vending machine or other machine. 
(c)  Any violation of any provision of this section shall constitute a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-179. 
Sec. 17-29. - False statements for publication. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly and willfully state, deliver or transmit, by any means whatever, to any publisher, or employee of a publisher, of any newspaper, magazine or other publication, any false or untrue statement concerning any person or corporation, with intent that the same shall be published. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall constitute a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-22) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-209. 
Sec. 17-30. - Petit larceny. 
    Any person who: 
(1)  Commits larceny from the person of another of money or other thing of value of less than five dollars ($5.00); or 
(2)  Commits simple larceny, not from the person of another, of goods and chattels of the value of less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), shall be deemed guilty of petit larceny, which shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-32; Ord. No. 01-1700-648, § 2, 2-6-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-96. 
Sec. 17-31. - Shoplifting. 
(a)  Whoever, without authority, with the intention of converting goods or merchandise to his own or another's use without having paid the full purchase price thereof, or of defrauding the owner thereof out of the value of the goods or merchandise: 
(1)  Willfully conceals or takes possession of the goods or merchandise of any store or other mercantile establishment, or 
(2)  Alters the price tag or other price marking on such goods or merchandise, or transfers the goods from one container to another, or 
(3)  Counsels, assists, aids or abets another in the performance of any of the above acts, 
shall be deemed guilty of larceny and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished as provided by subsections (b) and (c) below. The willful concealment of goods or merchandise of any store or other mercantile establishment, while still on the premises thereof, shall be prima facie evidence of an intent to convert and defraud the owner thereof out of the value of the goods or merchandise. 
(b)  Any person convicted for the first time of an offense under this section, when the value of the goods or merchandise involved in the offense is less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), shall be as punished as for a Class 1 misdemeanor. 
(c)  Any person convicted of an offense under this section, when the value of the goods or merchandise involved in the offense is less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), and it is alleged in the warrant or information on which he is convicted, and admitted, or found by the jury or judge before whom he is tried, that he has been before convicted in the Commonwealth of Virginia for a like offense, regardless of the value of the goods or merchandise involved in the prior conviction, shall be confined in jail not less than thirty (30) days nor more than twelve (12) months. 
(d)  A merchant, agent or employee of the merchant, who causes the arrest of any person pursuant to the provisions of this section shall not be held civilly liable for unlawful detention, if such detention does not exceed one hour, slander, malicious prosecution, false imprisonment, false arrest, or assault and battery of the person so arrested, whether such arrest takes place on the premises of the merchant or after close pursuit from such premises by such merchant, his agent or employee; provided that, in causing the arrest of such person, the merchant, agent or employee of the merchant, had, at the time of such arrest, probable cause to believe that the person had shoplifted or committed willful concealment of goods or merchandise. 
(e)  For the purposes of this section, "agents of the merchant" shall include attendants at any parking lot owned or leased by the merchant, or generally used by customers of the merchant through any contract or agreement between the owner of the parking lot and the merchant. 
(Code 1971, §§ 17-13-17-15; Ord. No. 01-1700-648, § 3, 2-6-01) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-103-18.2-106. See § 18.2-104 for conditions under which the above offense is a felony. 
Sec. 17-32. - Damaging property generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or maliciously damage or injure any property not his own, real or personal, public or private. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-47; Ord. No. 01-1700-648, § 5, 2-6-01) 
Cross reference- Interfering or tampering with fire-fighting equipment, § 9-3; damage or injury to property of sewer plant or waterworks, § 25-11. 
State Law reference- Damaging property, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-137 et seq. 
Sec. 17-33. - Injuring trees on streets and public grounds. 
(a)  No person shall wilfully injure in any way any tree on any street or in the public places of the city. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-46; Ord. No. 01-1700-648, § 6, 2-6-01) 
Cross reference- Cutting, trimming or removal of trees on streets, §§ 20-10, 20-11. 
Sec. 17-34. - Defacing, etc., signs posted by city. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deface, destroy or remove any sign posted by the city. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a Class 2 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-48; Ord. No. 01-1700-648, § 7, 2-6-01) 
Sec. 17-35. - Interfering or tampering with utility property. 
(a)  No person shall interfere with or in any way tamper with, any telephone or telegraph wire or other property of any telephone, telegraph or telecasting company, or with any of the lights, electric wires or other property used in lighting the city. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, §§ 17-50, 17-51; Ord. No. 01-1700-648, § 8, 2-6-01) 
Cross reference- Telephones, Ch. 23. 
Sec. 17-36. - Injuring, tampering with, etc., vehicles, aircraft, etc. 
(a)  No person shall, individually or in association with one or more others, wilfully break, injure, tamper with or remove any part of any vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel for the purpose of injuring, defacing or destroying such vehicle or temporarily or permanently preventing its useful operation, or for any purpose against the will or without the consent of the owner of such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, or in any other manner wilfully or maliciously interfere with or prevent the running or operation of such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel. 
(b)  Any person who shall, without the consent of the owner or person in charge of a vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad, climb into or upon such vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad with intent to commit any crime, malicious mischief or injury thereto, or who, while a vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad is at rest and unattended, shall attempt to manipulate any of the levers and starting crank or other device, brakes or mechanism thereof or to set such vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad is at rest and unattended, shall attempt to manipulate any of the levers and starting crank or other device, brakes or mechanism thereof or to set such vehicle, aircraft, boat, vessel, locomotive or other rolling stock of a railroad in motion, with the intent to commit any crime, malicious mischief or injury thereto, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. This subsection shall not apply when any such act is done in an emergency or in furtherance of public safety or by or under the direction of an officer in the regulation of traffic or performance of any other official duty. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to a bona fide repossession of a vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel by the holder of a lien on such vehicle, aircraft, boat or vessel, or by agents or employees of such lienholder. 
(Code 1971, §§ 16-5, 17-42-17-45) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-146-18.2-148. 
Sec. 17-37. - Posted advertising matter etc., on utility poles, highway signs, trees, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to tack or otherwise attach any advertising matter or other substance to any telephone, telegraph or electric transmission pole, to any traffic or highway sign or signal or to any tree within the city. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-5; Ord. No. 01-1700-648, § 4, 2-6-01) 
Cross reference- Advertising generally, Ch. 3; prohibition of zoning ordinance against attachment of signs to utility poles and trees, § 31-29(e)(9). 
Sec. 17-38. - Destroying, defacing, etc., properly posted advertisements or public notices. 
    Any person pulling down, writing on, cutting or otherwise defacing any handbill, advertisement or public notice of any kind posted in a proper place shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
Sec. 17-39. - Trespass in or on municipal buildings. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass in or on the public buildings or other structures belonging to the city. 
Sec. 17-39.1. - Hunting of birds, mammals or relics on city and private property. 
(a)  The city council hereby declares that all land owned by the city, and all land under option to purchase by the city, located within the city and Prince William County, Virginia (specifically the Signal Hill Tract, the Bull Run Tract, the Bobby Tract, the Conner Tract and all other unnamed land owned by the city) shall be posted to all hunting of birds and mammals (game and nongame) and it shall be unlawful for any person to carry or have in his possession any weapons legal in Virginia for hunting purposes on such land. 
(b)  The hunting of relics or the use or possession of metal detectors shall be unlawful on all of the land referred to in subsection (a) above, unless written permission, authorized by the city council and signed by the mayor, is granted. 
(c)  Any title owner of real property within the corporate limits of the city may request, in writing, that the city enforce the prohibition on the hunting of relics or the use of metal detectors, set forth in subsection (b) above, on such private property. Following receipt of such request by the city, the city will thereafter enforce the prohibition on the hunting of relics or the use of metal detectors on such private property until such time as the title owner of such private property rescinds his request in writing or the governing body amends or revokes this subsection accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 78-1700-129, 10-3-78; Ord. No. 07-1700-831, § 5, 5-15-07) 
Cross reference- Animals and fowl, Ch. 5; weapons, Ch. 26. 
Sec. 17-40. - Entering or remaining on property of another after having been forbidden to do so. 
    No person shall, without authority of law, go upon or remain upon the lands, buildings or premises of another, or any part, portion or area thereof, after having been forbidden to do so, either orally or in writing, by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person lawfully in charge thereof, or after having been forbidden to do so by a sign posted on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof at a place where it may be reasonable seen. 
(Code 1971, § 17-58) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-119. 
Sec. 17-41. - Instigating, etc., trespass by others; preventing service to persons not forbidden on premises. 
    No person shall solicit, urge, encourage, exhort, instigate or procure another or others to go upon or remain upon the lands, buildings or premises of another, or any part, portion or area thereof, knowing such other person or persons to have been forbidden, either orally or in writing, to do so by the owner, lessee, custodian or other person lawfully in charge thereof, or knowing such other person or persons to have been forbidden to do so by a sign posted on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof at a place where it may reasonably be seen; and no person shall, on such lands, buildings, premises or part, portion or area thereof prevent or seek to prevent the owner, lessee, custodian, person in charge or any of his employees from rendering service to any person or persons not so forbidden. 
(Code 1971, § 17-59) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-120. 
Sec. 17-42. - Peeping toms. 
    No person shall unlawfully enter upon the property of another, in the nighttime, and secretly or furtively peep through or attempt to so peep, into, through, or spy through, a window, door or other aperture of any building, structure or other enclosure of any nature occupied or intended for occupancy as a dwelling, whether or not such building, structure or enclosure be permanently situated or transportable and whether or not such occupancy be permanent or temporary. 
(Code 1971, § 17-60) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-130. 
Sec. 17-43. - Unlawful entry on church or school property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of some person authorized to give such consent, to go or enter upon, in the nighttime, the premises or property of any church or upon any school property for any purpose other than to attend a meeting or service held or conducted in such church or school property. A violation of this section shall constitute a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-62) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-128. 
Sec. 17-44. - Unlawful entry on cemetery property. 
    If any person, without the consent of the owner, proprietor or custodian, go or enter in the nighttime, upon the premises, property, driveways or walks of any cemetery, either public or private, for any purpose other than to visit the burial lot or grave of some member of his family, he shall be guilty of a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-61) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-125. 
Sec. 17-45. - Entering premises of another for purpose of damaging property or interfering with its use. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter the land, dwelling, outhouse or any other building of another for the purpose of damaging such property or any of the contents thereof or in any manner to interfere with the rights of the owner, user or the occupant thereof to use such property free from interference. 
(Code 1971, § 17-63) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-121. 
Sec. 17-46. - Spitting on floors, etc., of public buildings or conveyances or on sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to spit or expectorate upon the floor, stairway or any other part of any public building or place where the public assembles, or upon the floor or any other part of any public conveyance, or upon any sidewalk within the city. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall constitute a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-322. 
Sec. 17-47. - Pollution of state waters. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge or deposit, or to cause or allow to be discharged or deposited, in any state waters of the city, any wastes, sewerage, rubbish, trash, garbage, dirt, soil or any matter causing or aiding pollution, or to discharge or deposit, or to cause or allow to be discharged or deposited, any wastes, sewerage, rubbish, trash, garbage, dirt, soil or any matter causing or aiding pollution on any property in this city in any manner so as to allow such to be washed into any state waters by storm or flood waters. 
(b)  The meaning of "pollution" and "state waters," as used in this section, shall be as defined by section 62.1-44.3, Code of Virginia. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the discharge or deposit of waste into state waters, when such discharging or depositing has been approved by the state water control board. The provisions of this section shall not in any manner affect nor be applicable to any agricultural or farming operation. 
(Code 1971, § 11-2) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prohibit pollution of water, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-292. 
Sec. 17-48. - Accumulations of trash, garbage, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any accumulation of trash, garbage, refuse, litter or noxious, unsanitary or offensive matter or other substance, which might endanger the health or safety of other residents of the city, to be or remain on any property in his possession or under his control. 
(b)  The owner of any property in the city shall remove any condition described in subsection (a) from such property at intervals to be designated by the council. Reasonable notice of the date fixed by the council for such removal shall be given by newspaper publication, mail or delivery of a written notice to the owner of the property. Upon the failure of the owner of the property to comply with such notice, the city manager may have such trash, garbage, refuse, litter and/or other substance removed and bill the owner for the work. Upon the owner's failure to pay such bill by tax billing time, such bill shall be placed upon the tax bill of the owner so delinquent and collected as taxes are collected. 
(Code 1971, §§ 22-7, 22-8) 
Cross reference- Garbage and trash generally, Ch. 13; taxation, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11. See also, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-867. 
Sec. 17-49. - Grass and weeds. 
(a)  Definition. Weeds are vegetative growth generally deemed to exhale unpleasant and noxious odors; to be foreign growth, undesirable, rank or detrimental to the public health or safety; or to have minimal use or value. 
(b)  Cutting required. The person owning or having possession or charge of any premises, vacant lot, private roadway, whether in use or not, or other lands within the city, within five hundred (500) feet of any inhabited building or dwelling, shall cut the grass and weeds on such property when such grass or weeds reach a height of ten (10) inches or greater. 
(c)  Failure to cut, generally. 
(1)  When any grass or weeds with a height of ten (10) inches or greater are found on such property, the city manager shall give written notice to the person owning or having possession or charge of same, requiring such grass or weeds to be cut within ten (10) days of the receipt of the notice. Notice sent by registered or certified mail to the last known address of the owner as shown on the current real estate tax assessment books shall be deemed in compliance with the notice requirement to the owner. 
(2)  If the written notice is undeliverable or if, after receipt of the written notice, the person owning or having possession or charge of the property on which the violation exists fails to cut grass or weeds, the city manager shall cut such grass or weeds, whether the property is occupied or vacant. If the person owning or having possession or charge of the property denies free access for such purposes, the city manager may proceed after obtaining a warrant. Costs and expenses incurred by the city manager shall be assessed against the person owning or having possession or charge of the property and shall be recoverable from the person owning or having possession or charge in the same way as taxes and levies. 
(3)  Any person owning or having possession or charge of the property may appeal any action of the city manager under this section within ten (10) days of such action. All hearing requests shall be in writing and directed to the city manager who shall forward the request to the local board of appeals within ten (10) days of receipt. All hearings shall be before the local board of appeals. The city manager shall set a time and place for the hearing, which shall occur within ten (10) days of the request for the hearing, and shall so notify the appellant to correct or eliminate the violation in the same manner as the city manager or may require other action or may direct that no further action is necessary. 
(4)  When the written notice as provided for in this article is undeliverable, the city manager shall cause a public notice to be posted on the property for a period of ten (10) days stating the nature of the violation, the action which is being taken to correct or eliminate the violation and an address and/or telephone number where additional information can be obtained concerning the violation. Such posting or notice shall not preclude the city manager from cutting the grass or weeds on the property. 
(d)  Penalty for failure to cut. Any person who shall be in violation of the provisions of this section and who, upon receipt of written notice from the city manager to correct the same, shall fail or refuse to correct the violation within the time prescribed, shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished as provided by section 17-2. 
(Code 1971, § 22-9; Ord. No. 85-1700-289, 8-6-85) 
Cross reference- Taxation, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11. See also, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-867. 
Sec. 17-50. - Stagnant water. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any stagnant water to be or remain on his property. 
(Code 1971, § 22-6) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require the raising or drainage of grounds subject to be covered by stagnant water, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-867. 
Sec. 17-51. - Abandoned or discarded refrigerators and other airtight containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discard, abandon, leave or allow to remain in any place any icebox, refrigerator or other container, device or equipment of any kind with an interior storage area of more than two (2) cubic feet of clear space, which is airtight, without first removing the doors or hinges from such icebox, refrigerator, container, device or equipment. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any icebox, refrigerator, container, device or equipment which is being used for the purpose for which it was originally designed, or is being used for display purposes by any retail or wholesale merchant, or is crated, strapped or locked to such an extent that it is impossible for a child to obtain access to any airtight compartment thereof. 
(c)  A violation of this section constitutes a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1971, § 17-23) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-319. 
Sec. 17-52. - Fencing of junk yards. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, either owner or tenant, to place, store or abandon, or permit to be placed, stored or abandoned, any junk, disused machinery, equipment or motor vehicle on any lot or other premises bordering upon any street in the city, unless such junk, disused machinery, equipment or motor vehicle is concealed from such street by a tight boarding or fence not less than six (6) feet in height, which boarding or fence shall be constructed and maintained in a sightly and workmanlike manner by the owner of such lot or premises or his bona fide tenant, so as completely to screen from the street a view of such junk, disused machinery, equipment or motor vehicle. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, the word "junk" shall mean any secondhand or used material or machine or part thereof. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to affect or limit any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city providing for the licensing of junk dealers or junk collectors or further regulating the conduct of a junk dealer's business. 
(Code 1971, §§ 13-1-13-3) 
Cross reference- License tax for junk dealers, § 14-69; screening requirements of zoning ordinance, § 31-33(d). 
Sec. 17-53. - Open storage of inoperative motor vehicles in residential districts. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, except within a fully enclosed building or structure, on any property within a residential district, as established by the zoning ordinance, any motor vehicle whose condition is such that it is economically impractical to make it operative. 
(Code 1971, § 22-10) 
Cross reference- Parking, 24-47 et seq.; zoning ordinance, Ch. 31. 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-11.1. 
Sec. 17-54. - Repairing or dismantling automobiles, boats, etc., in residential districts. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "repair" does not include minor adjustments or replacement of parts, where such adjustments or replacement may reasonably be expected to be accomplished within a seventy-two-hour period. 
(b)  No person shall repair or dismantle in the open, in any residential district established by the zoning ordinance, any automobile, boat or other vehicle or conveyance without having first obtained a permit to do so from the office of the building official. Each such permit shall specify the time period in which the work shall be accomplished, which time period shall not be more than fifteen (15) days; provided that, the permit may be renewed for one additional fifteen-day period. 
(c)  No person shall repair a vehicle until a permit is secured from the office of the building official. The cost of the permit is seventeen dollars ($17.00). A performance deposit of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be required. The deposit will be refunded only if the vehicle is repaired and operable within fifteen (15) days or within thirty (30) days if an extension has been granted. 
(d)  Applicants for a permit under this section shall be required, as a condition to the granting of the permit, to authorize the police department to remove and store, at the owner's expense, any conveyance or parts thereof, or both, where the dismantling or repair is not completed within the time specified in the permit and such permit has not been renewed. 
(Code 1971, §§ 22-11-22-15; Ord. No. 86-1700-339, 6-17-86) 
Cross reference- Loud and excessive noise from repairing vehicles, § 15-9; zoning ordinance, Ch. 31. 
Sec. 17-55. - Wells and pits-Filling prior to abandonment. 
(a)  Every person who has caused to be dug on his own land or the land of another any well or pit shall fill such well or pit with earth, so that the same shall not be dangerous to human beings, animals or fowl, before such well or pit is abandoned. Any person owning land whereon any well or pit is located shall, in the same manner, fill with earth any such well or pit which has been abandoned, provided such person has knowledge of the existence of such well or pit. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-316. 
Sec. 17-56. - Same-Covers required on certain wells. 
(a)  Every person owning or occupying any land on which there is a well having a diameter greater than six (6) inches, and which is more than ten (10) feet deep, shall at all times keep the same covered in such a manner as not to be dangerous to human beings, animals or fowl. 
(b)  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions and authority of city to adopt above section, Code of Virginia, §§ 18.2-317, 18.2-318. 
Sec. 17-57. - Distribution of handbills. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or otherwise affix to any motor vehicle parked within a publicly-owned parking lot or to distribute within a publicly-owned parking lot any advertisement, flyers, handbills or other printed or written material, without first obtaining a permit therefore from the commissioner of the revenue and paying the applicable permit fee. Applications for such permits shall be filed with the commissioner of the revenue in such form and shall give such information as the commissioner of the revenue may require. The form shall require the person making the application to agree to be responsible for all damage to public and private property caused by the distribution. 
(b)  The city council shall from time to time fix the amount of the fee required to obtain a permit. The fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) payable to city treasurer which includes the estimated cost of cleaning up any discarded materials. 
(c)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall be guilty of a Class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 92-1700-478, 12-1-92; Ord. No. 00-1700-628, § 1, 6-6-00) 
Chapter 17.1 - PARKS AND RECREATION 
ARTICLE I. - ORDINANCES 

Sec. 17.1-1. - Effect of city ordinances. 
    All parks and the recreational facilities owned by the city, whether located within or outside of the city boundaries, shall be under the police jurisdiction of the city, and the ordinances of the city shall be enforceable therein. Any member of the police force of the city shall have the power to make arrests in parks owned by the city, whether located within or outside of the city, for violations of any such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-2. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant thereto, where no other penalty is provided and which is not otherwise defined as a misdemeanor or felony, shall be punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) per offense. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Secs. 17.1-3-17.1-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PARKS OPERATION 

Sec. 17.1-21. - Park rules and regulations. 
    The governing body shall have the power to establish, by ordinance, rules and regulations relating to the operation and use of parks and the recreational facilities therein owned by the city, whether located within or outside of the city, and for the preservation of order, safety and decency therein. The rules shall, inter alia, designate the criteria under which use of a park or recreational facility therein owned by the city is permitted, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Procedures for permit application; 
(2)  Procedures for appeals of permit denial; 
(3)  Fee schedules for city services beyond established regular service levels for the activity or performance; 
(4)  Permitted hours for scheduled performances or activities; 
(5)  Rules and regulations governing use of swimming and wading pools, tennis courts and other facilities; 
(6)  Operation and parking of motorized and nonmotorized vehicles; 
(7)  Rollerskating, skateboarding, rollerblading and other wheeled device activities; 
(8)  Grilling, barbecuing and cooking activities; and 
(9)  Any other criteria necessary to the safe, sufficient and orderly use of a public or city-owned park or recreational facility. 
    The rules and regulations shall be made available in convenient public facilities throughout the city and shall be available to any person upon written request. The governing body may require the rules and regulations, or portions thereof, to be posted at one or more parks owned by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-22. - Enforcement. 
    For the purpose of enforcing park rules and regulations, all parks and the recreational facilities therein owned by the city, whether located within or outside of the city, shall be under the police jurisdiction of the city. Any member of the police force of the city or park employee appointed as a special policeman shall have the power to make arrests for violations of any park rule or regulation. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any park rule or regulation. Any such violation shall be punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-23. - Park closings. 
    Any section or part of any park or recreational facility therein owned by the city, whether located within or outside of the city, may be declared closed to the public by the city manager at any time or for any interval of time, either temporarily or at regular and stated intervals, daily or otherwise and either in entirely or merely to certain uses, as the city manager shall find reasonably necessary. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-24. - Closing hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon or remain upon the lands or premises of any park owned by the city, whether located within or outside of the city, including any city-owned parking area appurtenant thereto, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m., Eastern Standard Time or Daylight Savings Time, whichever time is in effect, except as follows: 
(1)  Public officials or employees in the performance of their duties; 
(2)  Persons participating in or witnessing events where public authorities have given specific permission to exceed the above-stated time limits. 
    The city manager or his designee may issue permits for nighttime use of a city-owned park upon written application accompanied by reasonable demonstration that such use or activity is not at variance with the preservation of the public health, safety and welfare, with particular regard to lighting, noise control and sanitation, and that such use or activity shall comply with other applicable state statutes and rules and regulations and with other city ordinances and rules and regulations and accompanied by such other documentation as the governing body may reasonably require. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-25. - Swimming, wading or bathing in streams, brooks, etc., prohibited. 
    It shall unlawful for any person to in any manner swim, wade or bathe in any stream, brook, run or any other type of watercourse located in or running through any park owned by the city, whether located in or outside of the city, provided that any such watercourse in such a park has been posted with signs indicating that swimming, wading or bathing is prohibited. Any such violation shall be a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-26. - Open fires prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ignite or maintain any open fire or to leave unattended any fire in any grill, hibachi, charcoal cooker, brazier or any gasoline or liquified petroleum or other flammable fuel stove or similar device in any park or recreational facility therein owned by the city, whether located in or outside of the city. Violation of this section shall be a Class 4 misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-27. - Camping prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to set up or maintain any tent or other shelter structure, except for tents or shelters set up on a temporary basis for an event for which a permit has been obtained from the city, or to establish any campsite in any park owned by the city, whether located in or outside of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-28. - Use of alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or to drink or consume or to tender to another, whether or not accepted, any beer, wine, whiskey or other alcoholic beverage in a park or recreational facility therein owned by the city, whether located in or outside of the city, or parking area appurtenant thereto, except by express written permission of the city manager where a permit has been issued by the state alcoholic beverage control commission. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Secs. 17.1-29, 17.1-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADVISORY COMMISSION 

Sec. 17.1-31. - Advisory commission. 
    There is hereby established an advisory group to the governing body to be known as the Parks and Recreation Advisory Commission of the City of Manassas Park. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-32. - Purpose. 
    The advisory commission shall serve as the advisory body to the governing body of the city, shall serve as a liaison on parks and recreation issues among the governing body, city staff and the citizens of the city, shall advise the city manager on matters affecting parks and recreation policies, programs and properties. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 17.1-33. - Membership. 
    The advisory commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed at large by the governing body of the city. One (1) member may be a member of the governing body and one (1) member may be a member of the school board. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96; Ord. No. 01-1700-677, § 1, 11-7-01; Ord. No. 04-1700-772, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 17.1-34. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the advisory commission shall be determined by ordinance of the governing body and enumerated in the bylaws of the advisory commission. 
(Ord. No. 1996-1700-549, 9-17-96) 
Chapter 18 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Members of police department designated as part of official safety program and entitled to benefits under Line of Duty Act, § 2-11; traffic code, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- General powers and duties of local police force, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-138. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Appointment and dismissal of chief. 
    The chief of police shall be appointed by the city manager, with the concurrence of a majority of the council. The chief of police may be dismissed or otherwise relieved of duty by the manager, with the concurrence of the council. 
(Code 1971, § 21-5) 
Sec. 18-2. - Appointment and removal of other officers. 
(a)  The chief of police shall, with the approval of the city manager, be responsible for hiring or employing, and for deputizing or otherwise utilizing, all police officers, either regular or special, below the rank of chief. The chief of police shall, with the approval of the city manager, be responsible for dismissing, suspending or otherwise removing from duty any police officer, either regular or special, below the rank of chief. 
(b)  Any police officer dismissed, suspended or otherwise relieved from duty by the chief of police under this section, may, by written request to the council, have a hearing before the council, either in closed or open session, as he may choose. All members of the council shall be notified in writing of such hearing at least twenty-four (24) hours prior thereto. 
(Code 1971, §§ 21-6, 21-7) 
Sec. 18-3. - Limitation on action of council relative to officers and chief. 
    No member of the council shall at any time interpret the duties of or direct or act in the capacity of a police officer. Questions relative to the police shall be decided at a regular meeting of the council and any directives to the chief of police from the council shall be executed only after majority approval of the council at a regular council meeting. 
(Code 1971, § 21-1) 
Sec. 18-4. - Hearing to call officer to account for his actions. 
    Any police officer called before the council to account for his actions shall do so at a regularly scheduled open council meeting. Such hearing may only be held at the request of the chief of police or at the written request of five (5) or more citizens of the city. All members of the council shall be notified in writing of such hearing, at least twenty-four (24) hours prior thereto. 
(Code 1971, § 21-3) 
Sec. 18-5. - Department rules. 
    The police department shall be operated in accordance with rules and regulations adopted and promulgated by the council. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail, neglect or refuse to comply with such rules and regulations so adopted and promulgated. 
(Code 1971, § 21-4) 
Sec. 18-6. - Resisting or interfering with arrests. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to resist, obstruct or in any way interfere with any arrest made or attempted by any police officer or other officer having authority to make arrests. 
(Code 1971, § 17-37; Ord. No. 70-1700-44, 11-17-70) 
Cross reference- Intimidating or impeding law-enforcement officers,§ 17-4. 
Sec. 18-7. - False reports to police. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly give a false report, as to the commission of any crime, to any police officer of the city, with intent to mislead. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-461. 
Sec. 18-8. - Refusal to assist officer. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse or neglect to assist any police officer of the city, upon being requested by such officer to assist him: 
(1)  In the execution of his office in a criminal case; 
(2)  In the preservation of the peace; 
(3)  In the apprehending or securing of any person for a breach of the peace; or 
(4)  In any case of escape or rescue. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall constitute a Class 2 misdemeanor. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-463. 
Sec. 18-9. - Disposition of unclaimed property in possession of police department or sheriff. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section: 
(1)  Unclaimed personal property means any personal property, not including contraband, belong to another which has been acquired by a law enforcement officer pursuant to his duties, which is not needed in any criminal prosecution, which has not been claimed by its rightful owner and which the state treasurer has indicated will be declined if remitted under the Uniform Disposition of Unclaimed Property Act (55-210-1 et seq., Code of Virginia). 
(2)  Found property means any personal property, not including contraband, which has been found and delivered to the chief of police, sheriff, or his or her duly authorized agent, the owner of which cannot be identified, which has been offered to the finder thereof but declined and which is not needed in any criminal prosecution. 
(b)  Applicability. None of the provisions of this section shall be held to require the chief of police to take possession of or to make disposition of any lost or stolen property, the disposition or possession of which is otherwise provided by law. None of the provisions of this section shall apply to pistols, revolvers, derringers, bowie knives, dirks, slingshots, metallic knuckles or other deadly weapons of like character. 
(c)  Duty of officers for delivery of seized, taken, or found property. It shall be the duty of all officers and members of the police into whose possession any property seized, taken or found shall come, to deliver such property as soon as possible to the chief of police, or a person designated by him, unless the property is needed for immediate use as evidence in any case, and in that event a report and inventory of the same shall be forwarded as soon as possible to the chief of police. 
(d)  Duty of chief of police to keep records. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to keep or cause to be kept a record of all property seized or otherwise taken possession of by the City of Manassas Park Police Department. 
(e)  Disposition. The chief of police or his or her duly authorized agent is hereby authorized to dispose of unclaimed personal property, which has been in his or her possession for more than sixty (60) days, by a public sale. Prior to any such public sale, the chief of police or his or her duly authorized agent, shall make reasonable attempts to notify the rightful owner of the property, obtain a written statement from the attorney for the city or for the commonwealth advising that the item is not needed in any criminal prosecution, and cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city once a week for two (2) successive weeks, notice that there will be a public sale of unclaimed personal property. The property shall be described generally in the notice, along with the date, time and place of the sale. 
(f)  Disposition of proceeds of sale. The chief of police or his or her duly authorized agent shall pay from the proceeds of the sale the costs of advertisement, removal, storage, investigation as to ownership and liens, and notice of the sale. The balance of the proceeds from any sale pursuant to subsection (d) above shall be held by such officer for the owner and paid to the owner upon satisfactory proof of ownership. 
    If no claim has been made by the owner of the proceeds of such sale within sixty (60) days of the sale, the remaining funds shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. Upon satisfactory proof of ownership, the owner of any property sold pursuant to subsection (d) above may apply to the city within three (3) years of the date of the sale, and the city shall pay the remaining proceeds of the sale to the owner without interest or other charges. No claim shall be made nor any suit, action or proceeding be instituted for the recovery of such funds after three (3) years from the date of the sale. 
(g)  Disposition of dangerous property. Any property coming into the possession of the police department, pursuant to subsection (d) above, which the chief of police determines is dangerous or likely to be dangerous to persons or property, may be disposed of by the chief of police immediately, and without further notice, in such manner as the chief of police deems appropriate. 
(h)  Disposition of perishable property. Any property coming into the possession of the police department, pursuant to subsection (d) above, which the chief of police determines is perishable, may with prior approval of the city manager after consulting the city attorney, be sold at public auction at such time and after such notice as the chief of police shall deem property. Perishable property not claimed or sold shall forthwith be reported to the city manager, who may cause such property to be used as he deems to serve the interest of the city, or may order it destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 94-1700-507, 5-17-94) 
Secs. 18-10-18-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUXILIARY POLICE FORCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 09-1700-874, § 1, adopted June 16, 2009, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. II, §§ 18-21-18-24, pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 76-1700-82, adopted April 6, 1976. 

Sec. 18-21. - Establishment; appointment; revocation of appointment; uniforms; organization, rules and regulations. 
(a)  There is hereby established an auxiliary police force for the city, which shall consist of no more than fifteen (15) members appointed by the chief of police; provided, however, that the appointment of members shall be revocable at any time by the governing body. 
(b)  The auxiliary police force shall wear uniforms as directed, and shall be subject to the rules, regulations and general orders established by the chief of police. The members of the auxiliary police force shall have all the powers and authority and all the immunities of constables at common law. 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything in subsection (b) above to the contrary, once the auxiliary police force has met the training requirements established by the department of criminal justice services under § 9.1-101 of the Code of Virginia, the members of the auxiliary police force shall have all the powers and authority and all the immunities of full-time law-enforcement officers. 
(Ord. No. 09-1700-874, § 1, 6-16-09) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1731, 15.2-1733. 
Sec. 18-22. - Calling auxiliary police officers into service; police officers performing service to wear uniform; exception. 
(a)  Auxiliary police officers may be called into service when deemed necessary (i) in time of public emergency, (ii) at such times as there are insufficient numbers of regular police officers to preserve the peace, safety and good order of the community, and (iii) at any time for the purpose of training such auxiliary police officers. At all times when performing such service, the members of the auxiliary police force shall wear the prescribed uniform. 
(b)  At such time as the members of the auxiliary police force have all the powers and authority and all the immunities of full-time law-enforcement officers as provided for in subsection 18-21(c) above, such members may be called into service by the chief of police to aid and assist regular police officers in the performance of their duties. 
(c)  When the duties of an auxiliary police officer are such that the wearing of the prescribed uniform would adversely limit the effectiveness of the auxiliary police officer's ability to perform his prescribed duties, then clothing appropriate for the duties to be performed may be required by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 09-1700-874, § 1, 6-16-09) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1734. 
Sec. 18-23. - Acting beyond limits of jurisdiction of the city. 
    The members of the auxiliary police force shall not be required to act beyond the limits of the jurisdiction of the city except when called upon to protect any city-owned public property located beyond its boundaries, or as provided in section 18-24 below. 
(Ord. No. 09-1700-874, § 1, 6-16-09) 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1725, 15.2-1735. 
Sec. 18-24. - Mutual aid agreements. 
    The city has entered into, and may in the future enter into or become a party to, reciprocal agreements, mutual aid agreements and/or contracts with other localities, sheriffs, state-supported institutions of higher learning having police forces, and the director of the department of conservation and recreation with commissioned conservation officers, or any combination thereof, for the use of the city's forces, both regular and auxiliary, and their equipment and materials, to maintain peace and good order. Any police or other law-enforcement officer, regular or auxiliary, while performing his duty under any such reciprocal agreement, mutual aid agreement or contract, shall have the same authority as he has within the city. 
State Law reference- Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1736. 
(Ord. No. 09-1700-874, § 1, 6-16-09) 
Chapter 19 - RAILROADS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- For-hire vehicles, Ch. 11; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; traffic code, Ch. 24. 
State Law reference- Railroad corporations, Code of Virginia, § 56-345 et seq. 

Sec. 19-1. - Trains obstructing crossings. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any railroad company, or any receiver or trustee operating a railroad, to obstruct, for a longer period than five (5) minutes, the free passage on any street or road by standing cars or trains across the same, except a passenger train while receiving or discharging passengers, but a passway shall be kept open to allow normal flow of traffic; provided that, when a train has been uncoupled, so as to make a passway, the time necessarily required, not exceeding three (3) minutes, to pump up the air after the train has been recoupled shall not be included in considering the time such cars or trains were standing across such street or road. Any such railroad company, receiver or trustee, violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00); provided that the fine may be one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each minute beyond the permitted time, but the total fine shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(b)  This section shall not apply when a train is stopped due to breakdown, mechanical failure or emergency. 
(Code 1971, § 16-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 56-412.1. 
Sec. 19-2. - Standing of vehicles on tracks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stand any wagon or other vehicle on the track of any railroad which will hinder or endanger a moving train. 
(Code 1971, § 16-15) 
Cross reference- Parking vehicle near railroad crossing, § 24-48(a)(8). 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 56-412.1. 
Chapter 19.4 - SNOW EMERGENCY ROUTES* 

Sec. 19.4-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Local streets means all streets designated as other than arterial and collector streets in the city comprehensive plan. 
    Snow emergency route means those streets marked as such in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 19.4-2. - Parking on snow emergency routes. 
(a)  Whenever the city manager determines based on a forecast by the U.S. Weather Service that snow, sleet, or freezing rain conditions will make it necessary for motor vehicle traffic to be expedited then parking on city streets shall be restricted. The city manager shall put into effect a parking prohibition on parts of or all snow emergency routes as necessary by declaring it in a manner prescribed by this chapter. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, a parking prohibition shall automatically go into effect on any part of any snow emergency route on which there has been an accumulation of snow and ice of four (4) inches or more. 
(c)  Once in effect, a prohibition under this section shall remain in effect until terminated by an announcement of the city manager in accordance with this chapter. While the prohibition is in effect, no person shall park or allow any vehicle to remain parked on any portion of a snow emergency route to which it applies. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Parking, stopping, and standing regulations; presumption as to violation of ordinances; penalty, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 
Sec. 19.4-3. - Cleats, etc., on tires; chains; tires with studs. 
    No tire on a vehicle moved on a highway shall have on its periphery any block, stud, flange, cleat, spike, or any other protuberance of any material other than rubber, which projects beyond the tread of the traction surface of the tire. It shall be permissible, however, to use on the highways farm machinery having protuberances, which will not injure the highway, and to use tire chains of reasonable proportions when required for safety because of snow, ice, or other conditions tending to cause a vehicle to slide or skid. It shall also be permissible to use on any vehicle whose gross weight does not exceed ten thousand (10,000) pounds tires with studs which project no more than one-sixteenth ( 1/16 ) of an inch beyond the tread of the traction surface of the tire when compressed if the studs cover no more than three (3) percent of the traction surface of the tire. The use of studded tires shall be permissible only from October 15 to April 15. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Use of tire chains, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1044. 
Sec. 19.4-4. - Stalled vehicles on snow emergency route. 
(a)  Any person who obstructs or impedes traffic on a designated snow emergency route through his failure to have the vehicle operated by him equipped with snow tires or chains shall have his vehicle towed. 
(b)  No person shall abandon or leave his vehicle in the roadway of a snow emergency route, except for the purpose of securing assistance during the actual time necessary to travel to a nearby garage, gasoline station, or other place of assistance and immediately return. 
(c)  The city manager shall impose reasonable charges for removal and storage of vehicles, further fines affixed shall not exceed fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Regulation of operation of vehicles in snow, sleet, etc.; penalties, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1302. 
Sec. 19.4-5. - Announcement of parking prohibition. 
(a)  The city manager shall initiate each declaration pursuant to this chapter announced publicly by means of broadcasts from stations with a normal operating range covering the city. He may also initiate further announcements in newspapers of general circulation and cable television. Each announcement shall describe the action taken by the city manager, including the time it became or will become effective, and shall specify the streets or areas affected. A parking prohibition shall go into effect four (4) hours after the announcement with at least one (1) announcement between 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. in accordance with this chapter, or at such other times as designated by the city manager. 
(b)  The city manager or his designee shall record the time and date each declaration occurs in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Delegation of authority to make and enforce regulations, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 
Sec. 19.4-6. - Termination of parking prohibition. 
    Whenever the city manager shall find that some or all of the conditions that give rise to a parking prohibition in effect pursuant to this chapter no longer exist, he may declare the prohibition terminated, effective immediately upon announcement. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 19.4-7. - Posting of signs on snow emergency routes. 
    On each street designated as a snow emergency route, the city manager shall decree signs at proper intervals reading "Snow Emergency Route," "No Parking or Obstructing Traffic Flow," "Towing Enforced." These signs shall be distinctive and uniform in appearance and shall be unmistakable to all drivers. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Erection of traffic signs and markers, maximum penalties, Code of Virginia §§ 46.2-1300, 46.2-1312. 
Cross reference- Removal of snow and ice from sidewalks, §20-12. 
Sec. 19.4-8. - Snow emergency routes designated. 
    The following streets or portions of streets, within the city, are designated "snow emergency routes": 
(1)  Manassas Drive from Baker Street to Gulf Court; 
(2)  Denver Drive from Manassas Drive to Rugby Road; 
(3)  Digital Drive from Manassas Drive to West Carondelet Drive. 
(4)  Polk Drive from Old Centreville to Manassas Drive. 
(5)  Carondelet Drive (All). 
(6)  Matthew Drive (All). 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 19.4-9. - Removal of unlawfully parked vehicles. 
(a)  The police department shall order the removal of any vehicle from a snow emergency route to the nearest public parking lot or to an area designated or maintained by the police department, or otherwise maintained by this city, when: 
(1)  The vehicle parked is on a snow emergency route in which the prohibition is in effect; 
(2)  The vehicle is stalled on part of a snow emergency route on which there is a covering of snow, sleet or ice or on which there is a parking prohibition in effect and the person who was operating such vehicle does not appear to be removing it in accordance with the provision of this chapter; 
(3)  The vehicle parked is in violation of any parking ordinance or provision of law and is interfering or about to interfere with snow removal operations. 
(b)  Such removal, impoundment and returning of vehicles will be in accordance with section 4-4 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
Sec. 19.4-10. - Citations and penalties. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle is unattended, in violation of any provision of this chapter, the motor vehicle shall be impounded. The officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and any other information displayed on the vehicle identifying its user. He shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a traffic citation, on a form provided by the chief of police, for the driver to answer to the charge against him within fourteen (14) days during the hours and at a place specified in the citation. 
(b)  Failure to make payment in accordance with subsection (a) of this section or present ticket, notice or citation for a violation to the office of the city treasurer for certification to the general district court, within 30 days, shall render such owner, upon conviction of such violation, subject to a fine of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(c)  Any person contesting a parking citation shall certify, in writing, on an appropriate form, to the city treasurer. The city treasurer shall issue complaints, summons or warrants for delinquent parking citations to the appropriate district court. 
(d)  Every action to collect unpaid parking citation penalties imposed for violation of a city ordinance regulating parking under this article shall commence within three years of the date upon which such penalty became delinquent. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Penalties for violations, Code of Virginia, §§46.2-113, 46.2-1225. 
Sec. 19.4-11. - Procedure for creation, modification or deletion of restricted parking areas. 
(a)  The city manager shall create, modify, or delete restricted parking areas as needed. 
(b)  Creation, modification or deletion of restricted parking areas shall only be effective after initial notice, in writing, to the property owners of record in the area under consideration. The notice shall clearly state the exact location and boundaries of the restricted parking area under consideration. The notice shall supply reasons why such creation, modification, or deletion of a restricted parking area occurs. 
(c)  The initial notice shall contain a conspicuous statement that any interested person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager to create, modify or delete a restricted parking designation in the stated area, may petition the governing body for a hearing on the matter. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to issue parking permits, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1230. 
Sec. 19.4-12. - Appeal of creation, modification or deletion of restricted parking area. 
(a)  Any interested person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager to create, modify or delete a restricted parking area may petition the governing body for a hearing on the proposed change. For purposes of this section, the term "interested persons" shall include but not be limited to business entities such as a corporation, limited liability company or partnership. 
(b)  Appeal shall commence by delivering a certified letter to the city manager no later than the effective date of the proposed creation, modification or deletion of a restricted parking area. Such appeal letter shall contain a short statement specifying the objection to the proposed change and the grounds therefor. 
(c)  Upon receiving an appeal letter, the city manager shall suspend the creation, modification or deletion of a restricted parking area. He shall send an additional notice to the property owners of record, indicating a hearing regarding the restricted parking area shall occur with the governing body, within sixty (60) days of the proposed effective date stated in the initial notice. Additionally, the city manager shall publish or cause to be published a notice of the coming hearing in a newspaper of general circulation at least two (2) weeks before the date of such hearing. However, failure to comply strictly with the requirements of this subsection shall not affect the validity of the action taken. 
(d)  The city manager shall promptly notify the governing body of the appeal and the necessity for a public hearing. The governing body shall schedule a hearing on the matter within sixty (60) days of the proposed effective date stated in the initial notice. After the hearing, the city manager shall post a brief summary describing the action taken in a place open to the public in city hall. Failure to comply with the posting requirements of this section shall not affect the validity of the action taken. If the governing body elects to create or modify a restricted parking area, the governing body shall also specify an effective date. If the governing body elects to delete a restricted parking area, such deletion shall be effective immediately. 
(e)  In the alternative, the city manager may also elect to withdraw the proposed creation, modification or deletion of a restricted parking area. In such case, no public hearing shall be necessary. The city manager shall post a brief notice indicating that the proposed change is void, in a place open to the public in city hall, and mail a copy of the notice to the affected property owners of record. However, failure to strictly comply with the posting and notice requirements of this section shall not affect the validity of the action taken. 
(Ord. No. 05-1700-795, 12-20-05) 
State Law reference- Legal notices in the newspapers, Code of Virginia, §§ 8.01-323, 8.01-324. 
Chapter 19.5 - SOLICITORS AND DOOR-TO-DOOR SALESMEN[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Chapter 19.5 is derived from Ord. No. 79-1700-147, §§ 1-12, adopted Dec. 4, 1979, which ordinance did not expressly amend this Code. 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 14; noises by peddlers, solicitors, etc., § 15-5. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 19.5-1. - Purpose of chapter. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to reasonably control the activities of solicitors, canvassers, agents and door-to-door salesmen for the safety and well-being of people residing in the city. 
(Ord. No. 79-1700-147, § 1, 12-4-79) 
Sec. 19.5-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  For the purpose of this chapter, the term "solicitor" means any person who shall engage in selling goods, wares, merchandise or services, by sample, display or other means, where delivery is not made at the time of the sale and where the goods, wares, merchandise or services are subsequently delivered and are not the sample or display, or who solicits or canvasses for orders of goods, wares, merchandise or services of any character or description, or who gives or furnishes goods, wares, merchandise or services to induce or invite such orders of goods, wares, merchandise or services of any character or description. 
(b)  For the purpose of this chapter, the term "door-to-door salesman" means any person who shall go from one place of human habitation to another offering an item or items, other than newspapers and fresh farm products. 
(Ord. No. 79-1700-147, § 2, 12-4-79) 
Secs. 19.5-3-19.5-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, adopted Jan. 21, 2003, amended art. II in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former art. II derived from Ord. No. 79-1700-147, §§ 3-12, adopted Dec. 4, 1979; and Ord. No. 92-1700-450A, adopted Feb. 18, 1992. 

Sec. 19.5-11. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or door-to-door salesman to enter in or upon any private residence, apartment or premises in the city for the purpose of engaging in business as a solicitor or door-to-door salesman, without permission of the resident, and until he shall first have applied for and received a permit therefor from the city manager or his designee for the purpose of identification to the general public, police and other law enforcement officers. Representatives of religious, civic and educational organizations are exempted from the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-12. - Application. 
    Any person desiring to secure a permit required by this article shall apply therefor, in writing, over his or her signature, to the city manager or his designee on forms provided by the city. Such application shall state: 
(1)  The name, date of birth, and permanent and local business addresses of the applicant. 
(2)  The name and address of the person, firm or organization by whom the applicant is employed, if any. 
(3)  The length of service of the applicant with such employer. 
(4)  The place of residence and nature of the employment of the applicant during the last preceding year. 
(5)  The nature or character of the goods, wares, merchandise or services to be offered by the applicant. 
(6)  The length of time the applicant intends to do business in the city. 
(7)  The place or places where the goods, wares, merchandise or services are to be sold or offered for sale or barter. 
(8)  If a vehicle is to be used, a description of said vehicle, together with the license number and proof of insurance. 
(9)  A current Virginia criminal record check of the applicant, including any prior criminal convictions, and excluding traffic offenses, if any. 
    The application shall be accompanied by such credentials and evidence of good moral character and the identity of the applicant as may be reasonably required by the city manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-13. - Investigation of applicant; issuance or denial. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application for a permit under this article, the city manager or his designee shall conduct a thorough investigation of the applicant avoiding unnecessary delay, but it shall not be mandatory that the permit applied for be granted at the time of the filing of the application. 
If the city manager or his designee shall determine, after such investigation, that the person filing the application in question has met the required credentials, evidences good moral character, and proposes to engage in a lawful and legitimate commercial or professional enterprise, he shall, subject to section 19.5-14, issue the permit applied for. 
Such permit shall be issued on forms prepared for such purpose and shall set forth identification of the holder, shall state the company represented and contain any other pertinent information deemed desirable by the city manager. 
(b)  Any of the following findings by the city manager shall constitute grounds for the denial of a permit required by this article:
