(1)  That the applicant has not properly completed the permit application or that he has falsified such application in a material manner. 
(2)  That the applicant has a criminal record which reveals a pattern of criminal misconduct involving moral turpitude. 
(3)  That the applicant has a history of taking orders for goods, wares and merchandise which are not subsequently delivered in accord with the terms of the order or which are not of the quality represented by the seller. 
(4)  That the applicant fails to cooperate with law enforcement officers in the performance of their official duties. 
(c)  A two hundred dollar ($200.00) fine shall be levied against the applicant if any false and/or misleading statements are made on the application and discovered after a permit has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-14. - Fee. 
(a)  Before the issuance of a permit under this article, the applicant therefor shall pay to the city treasurer, and obtain a receipt therefor, a nonrefundable fee in the amount of twenty dollars ($20.00), which fee shall be considered as the cost incident to the investigation of the application and other services; provided, however, if such applicant has held a like permit from the city for the year immediately preceding the one for which a permit is requested, then such applicant shall pay the city treasurer a fee of five dollars ($5.00) which amount shall represent the cost of issuing a renewal permit. 
(b)  The fees provided for in this section shall not be prorated. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-15. - Bond. 
(a)  Every applicant of a permit under the provisions of this chapter shall file with the chief of the Manassas Park Police Department or his authorized agent a cash or corporate surety bond naming the governing body of Manassas Park as obligee in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). The applicant shall (1) comply fully with all city ordinances and state statutes regulating and concerning solicitors, canvassers, and/or door-to-door salesmen, as defined in this chapter, (2) guarantee that all money paid to the solicitor or door-to-door salesman will be accounted for and applied according to the representations of the solicitor or door-to-door salesman, (3) guarantee that the property purchased will be delivered according to such representation and that such property meets the standards as represented by the solicitor or door-to-door salesman, either directly or indirectly, or by manufacturer's representations apparent on the goods, wares, or merchandise. Action under such bond may be brought by and in the name of the aggrieved purchaser or by and in the name of the city. 
(b)  A bond filed pursuant to this section shall be maintained in full force and effect during the term of the permit issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-16. - Term. 
    All permits issued under this article shall run from the date of issuance to the thirty-first day of December following. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-17. - Not transferable. 
    Permits issued under this article shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-18. - To be carried on the person and exhibited upon request. 
(a)  The permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be carried and displayed at all times by the permittee when soliciting or canvassing in the city. 
(b)  In accordance with Code of Virginia, title 57, section 57-63, charitable organizations must register their names, the names of their solicitors, and the dates and times that they will be soliciting in the city, with the Manassas Park Police Department. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-19. - Revocation. 
    Any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this article may be revoked by the city manager for violation by the holder thereof of any of the provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city or of any state or federal law, or whenever the holder of such permit shall, in the judgment of the city manager, cease to possess the character and qualifications required by this article for the issuance of such permit. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-20. - Records to be kept. 
    The city manager or his designee shall keep records of all investigations under this article and of applications filed and permits issued or refused under this article. 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Sec. 19.5-21. - Penalty. 
    Upon conviction of any person for violation of this article, the penalty imposed shall be a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-700, § 1, 1-21-03) 
Chapter 20 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Erection of signs on or over rights-of-way, § 3-21; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; for-hire vehicles, Ch. 11; littering streets, § 13-5; spitting on sidewalks, § 17-46; railroads, Ch. 19; traffic code, Ch. 24; zoning, Ch. 31. 
State Law reference- General authority of municipal corporations relative to streets and other public ways, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2000 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Certain ordinances relating to streets not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance opening, dedicating, relocating, altering, vacating or naming any street or alley, or establishing the grade thereof, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Sec. 20-2. - Begging on street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to beg on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 17-10) 
Sec. 20-3. - Obstructions, etc., generally. 
    No person shall construct or place any obstruction, structure, foreign matter or material, be it permanent or temporary, in or upon the streets, gutters or sidewalks in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 23-1) 
Cross reference- Trash and garbage obstructing mailboxes, § 13-2; trains obstructing crossings, § 19-1; vehicles obstructing mailboxes, § 24-48. 
State Law reference- Authority to prevent street obstructions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2009. 
Sec. 20-4. - Use of sidewalks during building operations generally. 
    When any building or wall is being erected, repaired or demolished, the sidewalks in front thereof may, subject to section 20-5, be occupied and used by the contractor or builder in connection with such work for such period of time as may be reasonable, provided reasonable means are taken for the protection and safe passage of pedestrians and vehicular traffic. 
(Code 1971, § 23-4) 
Cross reference- Building regulations, Ch. 7. 
Sec. 20-5. - Placing building materials on street, alley or sidewalk. 
    No person shall place building materials upon any street, sidewalk or alley for use in connection with construction work, unless he shall have first obtained a permit from the city manager to do so and unless he shall place such materials in the space assigned and in the manner directed by the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 23-3) 
Sec. 20-6. - Limitation on stopping vehicles used on streets for sale of beverages, ice cream, etc. 
    No person paying a license tax under section 14-94 of this Code shall stop his wagon, cart or vehicle within one hundred (100) feet of the front of any open store, shop or stand, in or from which similar merchandise is sold, nor shall he, in using his wagon, cart or vehicle, interfere with or obstruct traffic on the streets. He shall, upon being required to do so by a police officer, move his wagon, cart or vehicle, as directed. 
(Code 1971, § 15-120) 
Cross reference- Hours for sale of ice cream on streets, § 10-1. 
Sec. 20-7. - Washing, greasing, etc., vehicle on street. 
    No person shall, for compensation, wash, polish or grease a vehicle upon a street, nor shall the owner of a vehicle permit it to be washed, polished or greased, for compensation, upon a street. 
(Code 1971, § 16-6) 
Sec. 20-8. - Deposit of hazardous or injurious materials on, and removal thereof from, streets. 
    No person shall throw or deposit or cause to be deposited upon any street any glass bottle, glass, nail, tack, wire, can or any other substance likely to injure any person or animal, or damage any vehicle upon such street, nor shall any person throw or deposit or cause to be deposited upon any street any soil, sand, mud, gravel or other substances so as to create a hazard to the traveling public. Any person who drops, or permits to be dropped or thrown, upon any street any destructive, hazardous or injurious material shall immediately remove the same or cause it to be removed. Any person removing a wrecked or damaged vehicle from a street shall remove any glass or other injurious substance dropped upon the street from such vehicle. 
(Code 1971, §§ 16-13, 23-5) 
Cross reference- General prohibition against littering streets, § 13-5. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 18.2-324. 
Sec. 20-9. - Projection of trees or shrubs over street or sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning or occupying property abutting a street or sidewalk to allow any trees, plants or shrubs growing on such property to project over the street or sidewalk in such manner as to obstruct or interfere with the safe passage of vehicles or pedestrians. 
(Code 1971, § 28-1) 
Sec. 20-10. - Cutting, trimming or spraying trees, on streets. 
    No tree or shrub on any street shall be cut, trimmed or sprayed, except as authorized by franchise, unless a permit therefor shall have been obtained from the city manager. Such cutting, trimming or spraying shall be permitted only when fully justified in the public interest and then only in a manner prescribed in the permit issued therefor. 
(Code 1971, § 28-2) 
Cross reference- Injuring trees on streets and other public grounds, § 17-33. 
Sec. 20-11. - Removal of trees and limbs, dangerous to life or property upon street. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of a tree or of a tree limb endangering life or property upon a street to fail, neglect or refuse to remove such tree or tree limb. 
(Code 1971, § 28-3) 
Sec. 20-12. - Removal of snow and ice from sidewalks. 
    The tenant or occupant and, in case there shall be no tenant or occupant, the owner or any person having the care of any building or lot of land abutting on any curbed or paved sidewalk shall, during the first eight (8) hours of daylight following the time when snow or ice ceases to fall or form, cause the same to be removed from such curbed or paved sidewalk. 
(Code 1971, § 23-2) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, §15.1-867. 
Sec. 20-13. - Access streets to construction or development areas to be kept free from dust and mud. 
    Subdividers, builders and contractors shall be responsible for keeping streets and roads used as access to any area of construction or development free from dust and mud. 
(Code 1971, § 23-6) 
Sec. 20-14. - Permit to break curb. 
(a)  No person shall break, or cause to be broken, any curbing within the city, unless he shall first have secured from the building official a permit therefor. A performance deposit of three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be required. The deposit will be refunded after final inspection and approval. 
(b)  Any person desiring a permit required by this section shall file an application therefor with the building official. Such application shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant has met all requirements of the state highway department. 
(Code 1971, § 23-15; Ord. No. 84-1700-245, 9-4-84) 
Secs. 20-15-20-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 20-26. - Article not applicable to work done by city. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to work done by city forces under the supervision of the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 23-13) 
Sec. 20-27. - Permit required. 
    No person, unless specially authorized by the council, shall take up or remove any portion of the surface of a sidewalk or street, or excavate in any public street of the city, without a written permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 23-9) 
Sec. 20-28. - Application for permit. 
    Any person desiring a permit required by section 20-27 shall file an application therefor with the city manager. Such an application shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant has met all requirements of the state highway department. 
(Code 1971, § 23-8) 
Sec. 20-29. - Permit applicant's deposit and assent to provisions of article. 
(a)  Before a permit required by this article is granted, the city manager shall require a deposit sufficient to pay for resurfacing the street to be disturbed, the amount of such deposit to be determined by the city manager. 
(b)  Every person who shall make application for a permit under this article shall be deemed to have assented thereby to all the provisions and terms of this article, including the right of the city to collect the actual cost of replacing the pavement, sidewalk or street surface in the manner above directed. 
(Code 1971, § 23-9) 
Sec. 20-30. - Refusal of permit. 
    The city manager shall not refuse a permit applied for under this article, except for cause. In case of refusal, the applicant may appeal to the council. 
(Code 1971, § 23-7) 
Sec. 20-31. - Required safety precautions; responsibility for damages. 
    Any person to whom a permit required by this article is granted shall place guards or barriers around the excavation in question and shall protect it by warning lights at night, and shall be responsible for damages to persons or property caused by such excavations, until taken in charge by the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 23-12) 
Sec. 20-32. - Duty to prosecute work without delay; notice of completion. 
    It shall be the duty of every person to whom a permit is issued under this article to institute at once and prosecute without delay the work for which such permit was obtained, and promptly, on its completion, give written notice thereof to the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 23-10) 
Sec. 20-33. - Replacing surface. 
    No pavement, sidewalk or street surface shall be replaced, after being taken up pursuant to a permit issued under this article, by any person except under the direction of the city manager. If the applicant fails to resurface the street disturbed promptly and in a manner approved by the city manager, the city manager is authorized to cause such work to be done at the expense of the applicant. 
(Code 1971, § 23-11) 
Chapter 21 - SUBDIVISION OF LAND[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Chapter 21 is derived from Res. No. 79-1322, adopted Oct. 2, 1979. Absence of a history note following a particular section or subsection indicates that such section or subsection derives unchanged from Res. No. 79-1322; conversely, legislation included in parentheses () following a section or subsection indicates amendment of the provisions by the legislation shown in such history note. Prior to the adoption of Res. No. 79-1322, Ch. 21, § 21-1, saved from repeal ordinances regulating the subdivision of land, particularly Ch. 24 of the 1971 Manassas Park Town Code, as amended. 
Cross reference- Planning commission, § 2-141 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; erosion and sedimentation control, Ch. 8; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 20; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 25; zoning, Ch. 31. 
State Law reference- Land subdivision and development, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-465 et seq.; codification of ordinances relating to subdivision of land, § 15.1-37.3. 

ARTICLE I. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 21-1. - Words and terms. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain words and terms used herein shall be interpreted and defined as follows. Words used in the present tense include the future tense, the singular includes the plural, and the plural the singular, unless the natural construction of the word indicates otherwise; the word "lot" includes the word "plot" and "parcel;" the word "shall" is mandatory and not advisory; the word "approve" shall be considered to be followed by the words "or disapprove;" any reference to this chapter includes all ordinances amending or supplementing the same; and all distances and areas refer to measurements in a horizontal plane. 
(1)  Administrator: The representative of the governing body who has been appointed to serve the governing body in the process of reviewing and approving subdivision plats. 
(2)  Alley: A permanent service right-of-way providing a secondary means of access to abutting properties. 
(3)  Building: Any structure having a roof, supported by columns or walls, for the housing or enclosure of persons, animals, vehicles or other personal property. 
(4)  Building permit: A document issued by the building inspector granting permission to another party to construct, extend, repair, remove or alter a structure. 
(5)  Building setback: The minimum distance by which any structure must be separated from the front property line of a lot. 
(6)  Governmental engineer: The licensed engineer designated by the governing body to furnish engineering assistance for the administration of these regulations. 
(7)  Clerk: The clerk of the circuit court of Prince William County, Virginia. 
(8)  Commission: The planning commission for the city of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
(9)  Council: The city council of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
(10)  Cul-de-sac: A street with one outlet and with an appropriate turnaround for safe and convenient reverse traffic movement. 
(11)  Easement: A grant by a property owner to another person for the use of land for a specific purpose without including title to the land. 
(12)  Engineer: An engineer certified by the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
(13)  Floodplain: An area(s) flooded by a flood of specific frequency or magnitude, which has been delineated as a regulated area(s) by federal, state or local government order through the use of maps, flood elevations, flood profiles or other techniques. 
(14)  Frontage: The shortest distance between the side lines of any lot measured along a line coinciding with, tangent to, or meeting at one point, the street upon which the lot fronts. 
(15)  Governing body: The city council of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
(16)  Health official: The health director or sanitarian serving the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
(17)  Jurisdiction: The area or territory subject to the legislative control of the governing body. 
(18)  Lot: A numbered and recorded portion of a subdivision intended for transfer of ownership or for the construction of a building and its accessory buildings. 
(19)  Lot, corner: A lot abutting upon two (2) or more streets at their intersection; the shortest side, fronting upon a street, shall be considered the front of the lot, and the longest side, fronting upon a street, shall be considered the side of the lot. 
(20)  Lot, depth of: The mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
(21)  Lot, double frontage: An interior lot having frontage on two (2) streets. 
(22)  Lot, interior: A lot other than a corner lot. 
(23)  Lot of record: A lot which has been recorded in the office of the clerk of the appropriate court. 
(24)  Lot, width of: The mean horizontal distance between the side lot lines. 
(25)  Monuments: Permanent markers from which property lines can be accurately surveyed. 
(26)  Person: An individual, a partnership, a corporation or any other legal entity by whatever term customarily known. 
(27)  Plat, final: A drawing of a survey of a tract or parcel of land prepared by a certified engineer or surveyor. 
(28)  Plat, preliminary: A drawing of a tract or parcel of land prepared by a certified engineer, land surveyor, owner of the land, city planners, land planners, architects, landscape architects or others having training or experience in subdivision planning or design. 
(29)  Regulatory flood elevation: The one hundred-year flood elevation plus a freeboard safety factor or one and one-half (11/2) feet. 
(30)  Right-of-way: A strip of land dedicated or reserved for a street, crosswalk, railroad, road, water main, sanitary or storm sewer main, public utilities or other special uses. For land platting purposes, the term "right-of-way" shall mean that every right-of-way, hereafter established and shown on a final plat, is to be separate and distinct from the lots or parcels adjoining such right-of-way and is not included within the dimensions or areas of such lots or parcels. A right-of-way intended for a street, crosswalk, water main, sanitary sewer, storm drain or any other use involving maintenance by a public agency shall be dedicated to public use. 
(31)  Secretary: The secretary of the planning commission of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
(32)  Street: A strip of land, including the entire right-of-way, intended to be dedicated for use as a means of vehicular and pedestrian circulation by the public at large. 
(33)  Street, major: Any existing or future street identified in an adopted plan, which carries traffic, or anticipated traffic, exceeding five hundred (500) vehicles per day. 
(34)  Street, minor: A street that is used primarily as a means of public access to abutting properties with anticipated traffic of less than five hundred (500) vehicles per day. 
(35)  Street width: The total right-of-way width of the strip of land dedicated or reserved for public travel, including roadway, curbs, gutters, sidewalks and planting strips. 
(36)  Street, service: A public street, generally parallel and contiguous to major streets, primarily designed to promote safety by properly spacing points of access to major streets. 
(37)  Subdivide: The division of a parcel of land into two (2) or more lots or parcels of less than two (2) acres each for the purpose of transfer of ownership or building development, or, if a new street is involved in such division, any division of a parcel of land. The word "subdivide" and any derivative thereof shall have reference to the term subdivider as defined in subsection (38) of this section. 
(38)  Subdivider: A person (as defined in subsection (26) of this section) owning any tract, lot or parcel of land to be subdivided, or a group of two (2) or more persons owning any tract, lot or parcel of land to be subdivided, or the person given power of attorney to act on the owner's behalf in the subdivision of land. 
(39)  Surveyor: A land surveyor certified by the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
(40)  Zoning ordinance: The adopted zoning ordinance for the city of Manassas Park, Virginia [Chapter 31 of this Code.] 
Secs. 21-2-21-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PURPOSE AND TITLE 

Sec. 21-11. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to establish subdivision standards and procedures for the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. These regulations are part of a long-range general plan to guide and facilitate orderly, beneficial growth of the community, and to provide for: 
(1)  The coordination of existing streets with proposed streets; 
(2)  Adequate open spaces for traffic, recreation, light and air; 
(3)  A distribution of population and traffic which will tend to create conditions favorable to public health, safety, convenience, comfort, prosperity and general welfare; 
(4)  Assurance, insofar as possible, for purchasers of lots that they are buying a commodity which is suitable for their development and use; and 
(5)  Adequate public services. 
Sec. 21-12. - Title. 
    This chapter is known and may be cited as the "Subdivision Ordinance of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia." 
Secs. 21-13-21-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 21-21. - Administrator's general responsibilities and duties. 
    The administrator appointed by the governing body is hereby delegated the responsibility and authority to administer this chapter, and his approval or disapproval of subdivision plats shall be considered as though it were given by the governing body. The administrator shall consult with the planning commission on matters contained herein. 
Sec. 21-22. - Administrator's duties to be performed in accordance with chapter and Land Subdivision and Development Act. 
    The administrator shall perform his duties regarding subdivisions and subdividing in accordance with this chapter and the Land Subdivision and Development Act, Title 15.1, Chapter 11, Code of Virginia (1950), as amended. 
Sec. 21-23. - Consultation. 
    In the performance of his duties and with the consent of the city manager, the administrator may call for opinions or decisions, either verbal or written, from other departments in considering details of any submitted plat. This authority of the administrator shall have particular reference to the governmental engineer, health officer and planning commission. 
Sec. 21-24. - Additional authority. 
    In addition to the regulations herein contained for the platting of subdivisions, the administrator may, from time to time, establish any reasonable additional administrative procedures deemed necessary for the administration of this chapter. 
Secs. 21-25-21-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMPLIANCE WITH CHAPTER 

Sec. 21-31. - Platting required. 
    Any owner or developer of any tract of land situated within the City of Manassas Park, who subdivides the same shall prepare a plat of such subdivision in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and shall record the plat in the office of the clerk of the appropriate court. No such subdivision plat shall be recorded unless it has been submitted, approved and certified by the administrator in accordance with the regulations set forth in this chapter. 
Sec. 21-32. - Recordation required. 
    No lot shall be sold in any proposed subdivision, nor shall any building permit be granted, until a final plat for the subdivision has been approved and recorded. 
Sec. 21-33. - Appeal from the decision of the administrator. 
    In the event a plat of a subdivision is disapproved by the administrator, the subdivider may appeal the decision of the administrator to the planning commission. If the subdivider is still aggrieved he may appeal to the governing body. 
Sec. 21-34. - Conflicting ordinances. 
    In any instance where other ordinances, or parts thereof, are inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter, the more restrictive ordinance(s), or parts thereof, shall prevail. 
Sec. 21-35. - City exempt from bonding, fee and assessment requirements. 
    The provisions of this subdivision chapter shall not be construed or interpreted to require the City of Manassas Park to post bonds, or pay fees or other administrative assessments imposed by this subdivision chapter. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-222, § 2, 7-5-83) 
Secs. 21-36-21-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PREPARATION AND RECORDATION OF SUBDIVISION PLATS 

Sec. 21-41. - Draw and certify. 
    Every subdivision plat, intended for recording, or the deed of dedication to which the plat is attached, shall be prepared by a surveyor or engineer duly licensed by the Commonwealth of Virginia, who shall endorse upon each plat a certificate signed by him setting forth the source of the title of the land subdivided and the place of record of the last instrument in the chain of title. When the plat is of land acquired from more than one source of title, the outlines of the several tracts shall be indicated upon such plats, within an inset block, or by means of a dotted line upon the plat. 
Sec. 21-42. - Owner's statement. 
    Every subdivision plat, intended for recording or the deed of dedication to which the plat is attached, shall contain, in addition to the surveyor's or engineer's certificate, the following statement: 
    "The platting or dedication of the following described land (here insert a correct description of the land subdivided) is with the free consent and in accordance with the desire of the undersigned owners, proprietors and trustees, if any." 
This shall be signed by the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, and shall be duly acknowledged before some officer authorized to take acknowledgements of deeds and, when thus executed and approved as herein specified, shall be filed and recorded in the office of the clerk of the appropriate court and indexed under the names of the landowners signing such statement and under the name of the subdivision. 
Sec. 21-43. - No one exempt. 
    No person shall subdivide any tract of land that is located within the city except in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
Sec. 21-44. - Private contracts. 
    This chapter bears no relation to any private easement, covenant, agreement or restriction, nor is the responsibility of enforcing such private easement, covenant, agreement or restriction implied herein to any public official. When this chapter calls for more restrictive standards than are required by private contracts, the provisions of this chapter shall control. 
Sec. 21-45. - Changes. 
    No change, erasure or revision shall be made on any subdivision plat intended for recording nor on accompanying data sheets after the approval of the administrator has been endorsed in writing on the plat or sheets unless authorization for such changes has been granted in writing by the administrator. 
Sec. 21-46. - Fees. 
    There shall be a charge for reviewing a subdivision plat in the amount established by the fee schedule. Payment is due at the time of submission. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-214, Ex. B, § 1, 3-1-83; Ord. No. 91-1700-450E, 9-17-91; Ord. No. 18-1700-1015, § 2, 6-19-18) 
Sec. 21-47. - Transfer of areas for public use. 
    The recording of a plat shall operate to transfer, in fee simple to the respective counties and municipalities in which the land lies, all portions of the area platted which are set apart for streets, alleys, easements or other public use and to create a public right-of-passage over the same. No such areas dedicated to public use shall be encumbered by easements retained by the subdivider or granted to utility companies or other corporate or natural persons. Nothing contained herein, however, shall prevent the subdivider from constructing and maintaining improvements as required by this chapter. 
Secs. 21-48-21-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GENERAL REGULATIONS 

Sec. 21-61. - Mutual responsibility. 
    There is a mutual responsibility between the subdivider and the City of Manassas Park, to divide the land so as to improve the general use pattern of the land being subdivided. 
Sec. 21-62. - Land must be suitable. 
    The administrator shall not approve the subdivision of land if, from adequate investigations conducted by all public agencies concerned, it has been determined that, in the best interest of the public, the site is not suitable for platting and development purposes of the kind proposed. The administrator may require the subdivider to furnish topographic maps, floodplain profile elevation information or other relevant information. 
Sec. 21-63. - Flooding. 
    Land subject to flooding and land deemed to be topographically unsuitable shall not be platted for residential occupancy, or for such other uses in such a way as to endanger health, life or property or aggravate erosion or flood hazard. Such land within the subdivision shall be set aside on the plat for such uses as shall neither be endangered by periodic or occasional inundation nor produce conditions contrary to public welfare. 
Sec. 21-64. - Erosion and sediment control. 
    All subdivision plans shall include adequate provisions for control of temporary flooding, erosion and sedimentation, both during construction and after completion of construction, in conformance with applicable ordinances. 
Cross reference- Erosion and sedimentation control, Ch. 8. 
Sec. 21-65. - Improvements. 
    All required improvements shall be installed by the subdivider at his cost and in accordance with city rules and regulations. The subdivider's performance bond shall not be released until construction has been completed, inspected and approved by the governmental engineer or appropriate official. 
(1)  STREETS: 
(a)  Alignment and layout: The arrangement of streets in new subdivisions shall make provision for the continuation of existing streets in adjoining areas and proposed streets as shown in the adopted plan. The street arrangement must be such as to cause no necessary hardship to owners of adjoining property when they plat their own land and seek to provide for convenient access to it. Where, in the opinion of the administrator, it is desirable to provide for street access to adjoining property, proposed streets shall be extended to the boundary line of such property. New perimeter half-streets along the boundary of land proposed for subdivision shall not be permitted. Wherever possible, streets should intersect at right angles. In all hillside areas, streets running with contours shall be required to meet intersecting streets at angles of not less than sixty (60) degrees, unless approved by the administrator upon recommendation of the highway engineer. The finished elevation of proposed streets shall not be more than one foot below the regulatory flood elevation. 
(b)  Access to major streets: Where a subdivision borders on or contains an existing or proposed major street, the planning commission may require the subdivider to provide that the access to such streets be limited by one or more of the following means: 
1.  The subdivision of lots so that they will back onto the major street and front onto a parallel minor street. No access shall be provided from the major street and screen planting shall be provided in a strip of land along the rear property line of such lots. 
2.  The subdivision of lots along a series of cul-de-sacs, U-shaped streets or short loops entered from and designed generally at right angles to such a parallel minor street, with the rear lines of the terminal lots contiguous with the major street right-of-way. 
3.  The subdivision of lots along a service street and physically separated from the major street by a planting or grass strip and having access thereto at approved points. 
(c)  Approach angle: Major streets shall approach major or minor streets at an angle or not less than ninety (90) degrees, unless the administrator, upon recommendation of the highway engineer, shall approve a lesser angle of approach for reasons of contour, terrain or matching of existing patterns. 
(d)  Minimum widths: The minimum width of proposed streets, measured from lot line to lot line, shall be fifty (50) feet. 
(e)  Cul-de-sacs: Generally, permanent cul-de-sacs shall be no longer than four hundred (400) feet to the beginning of the turnaround. Each cul-de-sac must be terminated by a turnaround of not less than one hundred (100) feet in diameter. 
(f)  Alleys: No alleys shall be platted and/or allowed within any subdivision on or after the adoption of this chapter. 
(g)  Private streets and reserve strips: Private streets in any subdivision shall only be allowed when provision has been made for perpetual maintenance of such streets and proof of such provision shall become part of the final plat and shall be submitted with the final plat. Every private street shall be served from a publicly maintained street or highway. The creation of reserve strips shall not be permitted adjacent to a proposed street in such a manner as to deny access from adjacent property to such street. 
(h)  Names: Proposed streets, which are obviously in alignment with other existing and named streets, shall bear the names of the duplicate existing street names, irrespective of the use of the suffixes street, avenue, boulevard, road, driveway, place, lane or court. Street names shall be indicated on the preliminary and final plats, and shall be approved by the administrator. Names of existing streets shall not be changed except by approval of the governing body. 
(i)  Identification signs: Street identification signs, readable from either side, of a design approved by the administrator shall be provided and installed by the subdivider at all intersections. 
(2)  MONUMENTS: 
(a)  Generally: As required by this chapter, all monuments must be provided and installed by the subdivider and shall meet the minimum specifications described below. Upon completion of subdivision streets, sewers and other improvements, the subdivider shall make certain that all monuments required by the administrator are clearly visible for inspection and use. Such monuments shall be inspected and approved by the administrator before any improvements are accepted by the governing body. 
(b)  Location-Concrete: Concrete monuments four (4) inches in diameter or four (4) inches square, three (3) feet long, with a flat top, shall be set at all street corners, at all points where the street line intersects the exterior boundaries of the subdivision, and at right angle points, and points of curve in each street. The top of the monument shall have an appropriate mark to identify properly the location and shall be set six (6) inches above the finished grade. 
(c)  Location-Iron pipe: All other lot corners shall be marked with iron pipe not less than three-fourths (3/4) inch in diameter and twenty-four (24) inches long, and driven so as to be flush with the finished grade. When rock is encountered, a hole shall be drilled four (4) inches deep in the rock into which shall be cemented a steel rod one-half (1/2) inch in diameter, the top of which shall be flush with the finished grade line. 
(3)  WATER FACILITIES: Public water service shall be extended by the subdivider to all lots within a subdivision in accordance with the approved design standards and specifications for water service, construction and improvements in the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. All water facilities located in any designated floodplain shall be floodproofed up to the regulatory flood elevation. 
(4)  SEWERAGE FACILITIES: Public sewerage facilities shall be extended by the subdivider to all lots within a subdivision and septic tanks will not be permitted. The subdivider shall provide each lot with a satisfactory and sanitary means of sewage collection and disposal in accordance with the approved design standards and specifications for sewerage construction and improvements in the City of Manassas Park. All sanitary sewerage facilities located in any designated floodplain shall be floodproofed up to the regulatory flood elevation. 
(5)  PRIVATE WATER AND SEWER FACILITIES: Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the installation of privately owned water and/or sewerage facilities in areas where public water and/or sewerage facilities are not available; provided, however, that such installations meet all the regulations of the state water control board, the state health department and any other state or local body having authority over such installation. All privately owned water and/or sewerage facilities located in any designated floodplain shall be floodproofed up to the regulatory flood elevation. 
(6)  OTHER PUBLIC UTILITIES AND FACILITIES: All other public and/or private utilities and facilities, including gas and electric, shall be elevated or floodproofed up to the regulatory flood elevation. 
(7)  STORM DRAINAGE FACILITIES: The subdivider shall provide all necessary information needed to determine what drainage improvements are necessary to develop properly such property. Such information shall include, but may not be limited to, contour data, drainage plans and flood-control devices. The subdivider shall also provide plans for all such improvements, together with a certified engineer's or surveyor's statement that such improvements, when properly installed, will be adequate for development and will not increase the rate of storm water runoff. The governmental engineer shall then approve or disapprove the plans. The subdivider shall also provide any other information required by the governmental engineer. The subdivider shall install the approved storm drainage facilities. 
(8)  FIRE PROTECTION: Fire hydrants shall be required in a subdivision at locations approved by the administrator, provided adequate public water is available. The location and design of the fire hydrants shall meet the National Board of Fire Underwriters specifications. 
(9)  EASEMENTS: The administrator may require the subdivider to provide drainage easements through adjoining property. The width of easements provided for drainage, water, sewer, power lines and other utilities in the subdivision shall be determined by the administrator. 
(10)  PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS: Nine (9) blue or black line prints of the plans and specifications, for all required physical improvements to be installed, shall be prepared by a certified engineer or land surveyor and shall be submitted with the final plat to the administrator for approval or disapproval within thirty (30) days. If approved, one copy bearing certification of such approval shall be returned to the subdivider. If disapproved, all papers shall be returned to the subdivider with the reason for disapproval stated in writing. 
(11)  BONDING: 
(a)  Performance bond: The subdivider shall furnish a cash bond or equivalent, a surety bond of a surety company or a certified check, payable to the City of Manassas Park, in an amount equal to one hundred and twenty (120) per cent of the total cost of the improvements determined by the administrator. Such bond or check shall guarantee that the improvements will be installed within a designated reasonable length of time in a manner acceptable to the administrator. The period within which required improvements must be completed shall be specified by the planning commission in the resolution approving the final plat and shall be incorporated in the bond. Said period shall not, in any event, exceed two (2) years from date of final approval. The bond or check shall accompany the final plat. 
(b)  Maintenance bond: The subdivider shall be required to file a maintenance bond payable to the City of Manassas Park, in an amount considered adequate and in a form satisfactory to the administrator, in order to assure the satisfactory condition of the required improvements for a period of one year after the date of their acceptance by the City of Manassas Park. 
(c)  Staged development: In the case where development is projected over a period of years, the planning commission may authorize submission of final plats by section or stages of development, subject to such requirements or guarantees for improvements in future sections or stages of development as it finds essential for the protection of any approved section of development. 
(d)  Absence of bond: In the absence of a performance bond or check, no final plat shall be approved or recorded until the required improvements have been installed and approved by the administrator or his authorized agent. 
(12)  SIDEWALKS: Sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of every interior street proposed in a subdivision and on at least one side of every street boarding the subdivision. 
(13)  CURB AND GUTTER: Curbs and gutters shall be installed in accordance with the standards and specifications of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-215, Ex. D, § 1, 3-1-83) 
Sec. 21-66. - Lots. 
    Lots shall be arranged in order that the following considerations are satisfied: 
(1)  Lot size: The minimum lot size in any subdivision shall be in accordance with zoning ordinances of the jurisdiction in which the lot is located. 
(2)  Shape: The lot arrangement, design and shape shall be such that lots will provide satisfactory and desirable sites for buildings, and be properly related to topography, and conform to requirements of this chapter. Lots shall not contain peculiarly-shaped extensions solely to provide necessary square footage of area which would be unusable for normal purposes. 
(3)  Location: Each lot shall abut on an existing or proposed dedicated public street or on a street which has become public by right-of-use. If the existing streets are not fifty (50) feet in width, the subdivider shall make provisions, in the deeds to the lots, that all buildings be constructed so as to permit the widening by dedication of such roads or streets to a width of fifty (50) feet. 
(4)  Corner lots: Corner lots shall have width sufficient for adequate site distance on both streets as determined by the administrator. 
(5)  Side lines: Side lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles or radial to the street line. 
(6)  Remnants: All property of a subdivided tract must be included in lots, or otherwise disposed of, rather than allowed to remain as unusable parcels. 
(7)  Separate ownership: Where the land covered by a subdivision includes two (2) or more parcels in separate ownership, and lot arrangement is such that a property ownership line divides one or more lots, the land in each lot so divided shall be transferred by deed to single ownership simultaneously with the recording of the final plat. Said deed is to be deposited with the clerk of the court and held with the final plat until the subdivider is ready to record same, and then both shall be recorded. 
(8)  Off-street parking and delivery facilities: All subdivisions, including those intended for business and industrial uses, shall include space set aside for off-street parking and/or delivery facilities, as required by the City of Manassas Park. 
Sec. 21-67. - Blocks. 
    Where created by the subdivision of land, all new blocks shall be designed to comply with the following general requirements: 
(1)  Length: Generally, the maximum length of blocks shall be twelve hundred (1,200) feet, and the minimum length of blocks upon which lots have frontage shall be five hundred (500) feet. 
(2)  Width: Blocks shall be wide enough to allow two (2) tiers of lots of minimum depth consistent with section 21-66 of this chapter, unless prevented by topographical conditions or size of the property, in which case the administrator may approve a single tier of lots of minimum depth. 
(3)  Orientation: Where a proposed subdivision will adjoin a major road, the administrator may require that the greater dimension of the block shall front or back upon such major thoroughfare to avoid unnecessary ingress or egress. 
Sec. 21-68. - Variances and waivers. 
(a)  Administrator's authority. The administrator may waive or grant variances to the requirements of this Article VI, subject to review by the planning commission and city council, after the administrator determines the following criteria are satisfied: 
(1)  The entire parcel of land proposed for subdivision and subject to the request for a waiver or variance is located within an area zoned I-1 (industrial) as defined by the zoning ordinance of the City of Manassas Park, as amended, and 
(2)  The waiver or variance sought will not adversely affect public health, safety or welfare and is in keeping with the overall intent and objectives of the subdivision ordinance. 
(b)  Review by the city council. Any person aggrieved by the administrator's decision to grant or deny a variance or waiver of any of the requirements of Article VI, may appeal the decision at issue to the city council by filing a notice of appeal with the city clerk within ten (10) days after the administrator's decision. 
(c)  Submission requirements. The administrator shall require any applicant for a variance or waiver of the requirements of Article VI to submit: 
(1)  A written statement detailing the reasons for the requested variance or waiver, and 
(2)  Evidence demonstrating that the grant of the requested variance or waiver will not adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(d)  Application to extend time. An application for a variance or waiver under this section shall extend the time allowed to the administrator or planning commission to act upon the submitted subdivision plat by a period equal to the time necessary to issue a decision on the variance or waiver application, including any appeals. 
(Ord. No. 83-1700-222, § 1, 7-5-83) 
Secs. 21-69-21-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - APPROVAL OF PLATS 

Sec. 21-81. - Preliminary sketch. 
    Prior to the preparation of preliminary or final plats, the subdivider may submit two (2) copies of a preliminary sketch to the administrator. The purpose of a preliminary sketch is to permit the administrator to advise the subdivider whether his plans are generally in accordance with the requirements of this chapter. The administrator may mark the preliminary sketch indicating necessary changes and any such marked sketch shall be returned to the subdivider. 
(1)  Sketch requirements: The preliminary sketch shall be drawn on white paper or on a print of a topographic map of the property. It shall be drawn to a scale of one hundred (100) feet to the inch. It shall show the name, location and dimensions of all streets entering the property, adjacent to the property or terminating at the boundary of the property to be subdivided. It shall show the location of all proposed streets, lots, parks, playgrounds and other proposed uses of the land to be subdivided, and shall include the approximate dimensions. 
(2)  Part of tract: Whenever part of a tract is proposed for platting and it is intended that additional parts will be subdivided in the future, a sketch plan for the entire tract shall be submitted with the preliminary plat. This sketch is merely for informational purposes and is not binding on the subdivider or the governing body. 
Sec. 21-82. - Submission of preliminary plat. 
    The subdivider shall present to the planning commission five (5) prints of a preliminary layout at a scale of one hundred (100) feet to the inch as a preliminary plat. The preliminary plat shall include the following information: 
(1)  Identification: Name of subdivision, owner, subdivider, person preparing drawing, date of drawing, number of sheets, north point and scale. If true north is used, method of determination must be shown. 
(2)  Location of subdivision: Location of proposed subdivision by an inset map at a scale of not less than two (2) inches equal one (1) mile showing adjoining roads, their names and numbers, towns, subdivisions, watershed areas, other landmarks and, where appropriate, the existing zoning of the land and adjoining property. 
(3)  Boundaries of subdivision: The boundary survey or existing survey of record provided such survey shows a closure with an accuracy of not less than one in twenty-five hundred (1:2,500), with reference to a known, permanent monument, total acreage, acreage of subdivided area, number and approximate area and frontage of all building sites, existing buildings within the boundaries of the tract, names of owners and their property lines within the boundaries of the tract and adjoining such boundaries. 
(4)  Streets, utilities and other data: All existing, platted and proposed streets, their names, numbers and widths; existing utility or other easements; public areas and parking spaces; culverts, drains and watercourses, their names; flood profile and other pertinent data. 
(5)  Storm drainage: The complete storm drainage layout, including all pipe sizes, types, drainage easements and means of transporting the drainage to a well-defined open stream which is considered natural drainage, or to another approved drainage-control facility. 
(6)  Water and sewer: Proposed connections with existing sanitary sewers and existing water supply or alternate means of sewage disposal and water supply. The location, type, profile, percentage of slope, pipe size and location of manholes for all sewers shall be shown. The distance between manholes shall not exceed three hundred (300) feet. The location, type and sizes of all water lines shall be shown as well as the location of necessary control valves and fire hydrants. 
(7)  Street construction: A cross section showing the proposed street construction, depth and type of base, type of surface, etc. 
(8)  Grades: A profile or contour map showing the proposed grades for the streets and drainage facilities, including the elevations of existing and proposed ground surface at all street intersections, and at points of major grade change along the center of streets together with the proposed connecting grade lines. 
(9)  Location map: A location map tying the subdivision into the present road system by using either aerial photographs or topographic maps of the U.S. Geological Survey. 
(10)  Dedication: All parcels of land to be dedicated for public use and the condition of dedication. 
Sec. 21-83. - Approval of preliminary plat. 
    The administrator shall discuss the preliminary plat with the subdivider in order to determine whether or not the preliminary plat generally conforms to the requirements of the subdivision, zoning and soil erosion and sedimentation control ordinances of the City of Manassas Park, and any other appropriate ordinances, rules or regulations. Within sixty (60) days of the preliminary plat submission, the commission shall direct the administrator to advise the subdivider in writing, by formal letter or by legible markings on the preliminary plat, of any additional data that may be required, the character and extent of public improvements that will have to be made, and an estimate of the cost of construction or improvements and the amount of the performance bond which will be required as a prerequisite to approval of the final subdivision plat. In determining the cost of required improvements and the amount of the performance bond, the administrator may consult with the governmental engineer who shall prepare these data for the administrator, or may require a bona fide estimate of the cost of improvements to be furnished by the subdivider. 
Sec. 21-84. - No guarantee. 
    Approval of the preliminary plat does not guarantee approval of the final plat. 
Sec. 21-85. - Six months' limit. 
    Within six (6) months after receiving approval of the preliminary plat, the subdivider shall file with the administrator a final subdivision plat in accordance with this chapter. Failure to do so shall make the preliminary approval null and void. The administrator may, on written request by the subdivider, grant an extension not to exceed ninety (90) days. Any extensions thereafter must be approved by the commission. 
Sec. 21-86. - Submission of final plat. 
    The subdivision plats submitted to the commission for final approval and subsequent recording shall be clearly and legibly drawn in ink upon stable and reproducible plastic or linen material at a scale not smaller than one hundred (100) feet to the inch on sheets having a size of not more than twenty (20) inches by twenty-four (24) inches. In addition to the requirements of the preliminary plat, the final plat shall include the following: 
(1)  Approval space: A blank space three (3) inches by five (5) inches shall be reserved for the use of the approving authority. 
(2)  Certificates of title: Certificates signed by a surveyor or engineer setting forth the source of title of the owners of the land subdivided and the place of record of the last instrument in the chain of title. 
(3)  Owner's statement: A statement to the effect that the subdivision as it appears on this plat is with the free consent and in accordance with the desires of the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, which shall be signed by the owners, proprietors and trustees, if any, and shall be duly acknowledged before some officer authorized to take acknowledgements of deeds. 
(4)  Identification of tracts: When the subdivision consists of land acquired from more than one source of title, the outlines of the various tracts shall be indicated by dashes and the identification of the respective tracts shall be placed on the plat. 
(5)  Streets, public uses, utilities: The accurate location and dimensions by bearings and distances with all curve data on all lots and streets, boundaries of all proposed or existing easements; parks; school sites; all existing public and private streets, their names, numbers and widths; existing utilities and those to be provided such as sanitary sewers, storm drains, water mains, manholes and underground conduits including their size and type; watercourses and their names; and names of owners and their property lines, both within the boundary of the subdivision and adjoining said boundaries. 
(6)  Accuracy: Distances and bearings must balance and close with an accuracy of not less than one in ten thousand (1:10,000). 
(7)  Street curves: The data of all curves along the street frontage shall be shown in detail at the curve data table containing the following: Delta, radius, arc, tangent, chord and chord bearings. 
Sec. 21-87. - Approval of final plat. 
    The plat shall not be approved by the commission until the subdivider has complied with the general requirements and minimum standards of design in accordance with this chapter, and has made satisfactory arrangements for performance bond, cash or cash bond to cover the cost of necessary improvements, in lieu of construction, to the satisfaction of the administrator. Approval of final plat shall be written on the face of the plat by the administrator and no plat shall be recorded until approval has been made. 
(1)  Procedure for approval or disapproval: The completed plat shall be submitted to the administrator for approval. Upon the approval by the administrator, the plat will be signed by the administrator or his designated representative, marked approved, and returned to the subdivider who will cause the plat to be recorded in the clerk's office, City of Manassas Park, Virginia. If not approved, the administrator will return the plat to the subdivider with corrections to be made by the subdivider indicated thereon. 
Secs. 21-88-21-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - EFFECTUAL CLAUSES 

Sec. 21-101. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating the foregoing provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each lot or parcel of land so subdivided or transferred or sold; and the description of such lot or parcel by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document used in the process of selling or transferring shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties or from the remedies herein provided. 
Sec. 21-102. - Validity. 
    Should any article, section, subsection or provision of this chapter be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity or constitutionality of this chapter as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part so declared to be invalid or unconstitutional. 
Sec. 21-103. - Amendments. 
    This chapter may be amended in whole or in part by the governing body, provided that any such amendment shall either originate with or be submitted to the planning commission for recommendation; and further provided that no such amendment shall be adopted without a public hearing having been held by the governing body. Notice of the time and place of the hearing shall have been given in accordance with the provisions of Section 15.1-431, Code of Virginia (1950), as amended. 
Sec. 21-104. - Adoption and effective date. 
    This chapter was duly considered, following a required public hearing held on May 23, 1979, and was adopted by the city council of Manassas Park, Virginia, at the regular meeting held on October 2, 1979. This chapter shall be effective on and after 12:01 a.m., October 3, 1979. 
Secs. 21-105-21-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - COMMON OPEN SPACE AND COMMON IMPROVEMENT REGULATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 91-1700-442, adopted May 21, 1991, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Art. VIII, §§ 21-88-21-92. Inasmuch as there are already provisions so designated, said provisions have been redesignated as Art. IX, §§ 21-111-21-114 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 21-111. - Applicability. 
    The regulations set forth in this article shall apply to the following features in all residential developments where such features are proposed to be dedicated or conveyed for public use or are to be held in common ownership by the person residing in the development: 
(1)  All lands in common open space, not a part of individual lots, designed for the mutual benefit of a group of persons residing in the development, where such lands are not to be dedicated or conveyed for public use, whether or not such lands are required by the provisions of this Subdivision Ordinance; and 
(2)  All private streets, driveways, parking bays, uses, facilities, and buildings or portions thereof, as may be provided for the common use, benefit and/or enjoyment of the occupants of the development, whether or not such improvements are required by the provisions of this Subdivision Ordinance. 
(3)  Where a condominium development is proposed, such shall be established and regulated in strict accordance with the provisions of the Condominium Laws of Virginia. 
(4)  All lands to be deeded or conveyed for public use. 
(Ord. No. 91-1700-442, 5-21-91) 
Sec. 21-112. - General requirements. 
    All lands and improvements set forth in subparagraphs (1), (2), and (3) of section 21-111 above shall be established and maintained in accordance with the following requirements: 
(1)  The applicant or developer shall provide for and establish a nonprofit organization or other legal entity under the laws of Virginia for the ownership, care and maintenance of all such lands and improvements. 
(2)  Such organization shall be created by covenants and restrictions running with the land and shall be composed of all persons having ownership within the development. Such organization shall be responsible for the perpetuation, maintenance, and function of all common lands, uses and facilities. 
(3)  All lands and improvements shall be described and identified as to location, size, use and control in a restrictive covenant, and such covenants shall set forth the method of assessment for the maintenance of such land. These restrictive covenants shall be written so as to run with the land and be in full force and effect for a period of not less than twenty (20) years, and shall be automatically extended for successive periods of twenty (20) years unless terminated in a manner set forth hereinafter. These covenants shall become part of the deed to each lot or parcel within the development. 
(4)  Such restrictive covenant and organization shall continue in effect so as to control the availability of the facilities and land thereby provided, to maintain the land and facilities for their intended function, and to protect the development from additional and unplanned densities of use. Such organization shall not be dissolved nor shall such organization conceived and organized to own and maintain the common open space, without first offering to dedicate the same to the city or other appropriate governmental agency. 
(5)  No lands in common open space shall be denuded, defaced nor otherwise disturbed in any manner at any time without the approval of the zoning administrator. 
(6)  If the zoning administrator shall determine that the public interest requires assurance as to adequate maintenance of common open space areas and improvements, the zoning administrator may require that the covenants creating such organization, shall at any time after establishment of the development fail to maintain the common open space/improvements in reasonable order and condition in accordance with the approved plans, the city may serve notice in writing upon such organization or upon the residents of the development setting forth the manner in which the organization has failed to maintain the common open space/improvements in reasonable condition, and said notice shall contain a demand that such deficiencies of maintenance be cured within thirty (30) days thereof and shall state the date and place of a public hearing thereon which shall be held within twenty (20) days of the notice. 
(7)  At such hearing the city may modify the terms of the original notice as to the deficiencies and may grant an extension of time within which they shall be cured. 
(8)  If the deficiencies set forth in the original notice or in the modifications thereof shall not be cured within said thirty (30) days or any extension thereof, the city, in order to preserve the taxable values of the properties within the development and to prevent the common open space/improvements from becoming a public nuisance, may enter upon said common open space and maintain the same for one year. 
(9)  Said entry and maintenance shall not vest in the public any rights to use the common open space/improvements except when the same is voluntarily dedicated to the public by the owners. 
(10)  Before the expiration of said one-year period, the city shall, upon its initiative or upon the request of the organization theretofore responsible for the maintenance of the common open space/improvements, call a public hearing upon notice in writing to such organization or to the residents of such development, to be held by the city council, at which hearing the organization shall show cause why such maintenance by the city shall not, at the election of the city council, continue for a succeeding one-year period. 
(11)  If the city council shall determine that such organization is ready and able to maintain the common open space/improvements in reasonable condition, the city shall cease to maintain the common open space/improvements at the end of said one-year period. 
(12)  If the city council shall determine that such organization is not ready and able to maintain the common open space/improvements in a reasonable condition, the city may, in its discretion, continue to maintain the common open space/improvements during the next succeeding year, and subject to a similar hearing and determination in each year thereafter. 
(13)  The covenants creating such organization shall further provide that the cost of such maintenance by the city shall be assessed ratably against the properties within the development that have a right of enjoyment of the common open space/improvements, and shall become a charge on said properties, and such charge shall be paid by the owners of said properties within thirty (30) days after receipt of a statement therefor. 
(Ord. No. 91-1700-442, 5-21-91) 
Sec. 21-113. - Submission requirement. 
(a)  Prior to the dedication or conveyance of those features described in sections 21-88 and 21-89 above, the following documents shall be submitted to and approved by the city. 
(1)  The articles of incorporation or other organizational documentation for the nonprofit organization. 
(2)  The bylaws of the nonprofit organization. 
(3)  The covenants or restrictions related to the use of common property, including the system and amounts of assessments for perpetuation and maintenance. 
(4)  A fiscal program for a minimum of ten (10) years, including adequate reserve funds for the maintenance and care of all lands, streets, facilities, and uses under the purview of the nonprofit organization. 
(5)  A document granting the right of entry upon such common property to the city and county law enforcement officers, rescue squad personnel, and the firefighting personnel while in the pursuit of their duties; and, in the case of private streets and common driveways, permitting the enforcement of cleared emergency vehicle access. 
(6)  A complete listing of all land, buildings, equipment, facilities, and other holdings of the nonprofit organization, as such is proposed, and a complete description of each. 
(7)  A recommended time schedule for the maintenance of major facilities, including streets, street signs, pools, sidewalks, parking areas and buildings. 
(8)  A copy of the proposed notice that will be given to prospective buyers regarding the organization, assessments and fiscal program. 
(9)  A copy of the deed of conveyance and a title certificate or, at the discretion of the city manager, a commitment for a policy of title insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the Commonwealth of Virginia, assuring unencumbered title for all lands proposed to be conveyed to the city, or other appropriate governmental agency, or other organization, including the nonprofit organization. 
(b)  The documents set forth in subparagraph (a) above shall be reviewed and approved by the city manager and the city attorney, and such approval shall be obtained before any final subdivision plat is recorded. Such documents, once approved, shall become part of the recorded subdivision plat. 
(c)  In no event shall a final inspection of the improvements be made or the agreement bond be released in accordance with the provisions of section 31-43 of Chapter 31 until it is substantiated that the nonprofit organization has elected officers from its member homeowners. 
(Ord. No. 91-1700-442, 5-21-91) 
Sec. 21-114. - Payments in lieu of providing developed recreational facilities. 
    In those instances where a developer in a Planned Unit Development (PUD) district provides cash in lieu of developed recreational facilities, pursuant to proffers accepted with the rezoning regulations, such payment shall be made before a certificate of occupancy is issued. 
    Payment shall be made into a trust account set up for the organization, so established to hold the funds until the majority of the association/organization membership is comprised of individual homeowners, at which time such funds shall be released unless the organization shall determine that the funds should be held to some subsequent specified time; provided, however, that where a given development is to be staged over a period in excess of three (3) years, such funds can be released upon the request of the organization, based on the number of units occupied, as a given stage is completed. 
(Ord. No. 91-1700-442, 5-21-91) 
Sec. 21-115. - City not responsible for maintenance. 
    Except as provided in subparagraph (8) of section 21-112 above, the city shall not be responsible for the maintenance of any of the common open space and common improvements required by this article or any rezoning associated therewith. Where the city becomes the owner of such open space and improvements, under the provisions of subparagraph (4) of section 21-112 above, there shall accrue to the city or other appropriate governmental agency no responsibility except to the general public of the entire city. 
(Ord. No. 91-1700-442, 5-21-91) 
Chapter 22 - TAXATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Tax year. 
    The tax year of the city shall begin on the first day of January of each year and end on the thirty-first day of December of each year. Effective January 1, 2009, a short calendar year real estate tax shall begin January 1, 2009, and end on June 30, 2009. Effective July 1, 2009, and thereafter, however, the tax year for real property shall be the first day of July each year and end on the thirtieth day of June each year. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96; Ord. No. 08-1700-860, § 3, 11-18-08) 
Cross reference- Fiscal year, § 2-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia §§ 58.1-3010; 58.1-3281. 
Sec. 22-2. - Collection of delinquent taxes. 
    Should any tax or taxes become delinquent, the city treasurer shall proceed promptly to collect the same in such manner as may be prescribed by the provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the city or by state law. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Delinquent taxes, Code of Virginia §§ 58.1-3919; 58.1-3919.1;and 58.1-3934. 
Sec. 22-3. - Sale or lease of personal property and real property for taxes due thereon. 
    The city treasurer may sell or lease any personal property or real property for taxes due thereon or from the owner thereof in the same manner and under the same procedures as may be prescribed by the provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the city or by state law. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Tax sales, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3940 et seq. 
Sec. 22-4. - Interest charge on late taxes. 
    Interest at the rate of ten (10) percent per annum from the first day following the day such taxes are due shall be assessed and collected upon the principal and penalties of all taxes then remaining unpaid, which interest shall be collected and accounted for by the city treasurer, along with the principal amount of such taxes, as provided by state law. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Interest, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3916. 
Sec. 22-5. - Penalty for late filing. 
    Any person who fails to file an application, return or report required by this chapter on or before the due date established therefor shall be assessed a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax assessable on such application, return or report or ten dollars ($10.00), whichever is greater, which penalty shall be added to the amount of tax due from such person. The city treasurer shall proceed with the collection of such penalty as provided by law. This penalty for failure to file an application, return or report shall be assessed on the day after such application or return is due. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Penalty, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3916. 
Sec. 22-6. - Penalty for late payment. 
    Any person who fails to pay any tax or installment required by this chapter on or before the due date established therefor shall be assessed a penalty of ten (10) percent of the tax assessable or a sum of ten ($10.00) dollars, whichever is greater, which penalty shall be added to the amount of tax due from such person. The city treasurer shall proceed with the collection of such penalty as provided by law. This penalty for failure to pay a tax or installment shall be assessed on the day after the first installment is due. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Penalty, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3916. 
Sec. 22-7. - Administrative costs, attorney's fees and collection agency's fees. 
    A fee is hereby imposed upon each person chargeable with delinquent taxes or other delinquent charges in an amount necessary to cover the city's administrative costs and reasonable attorney's or collection agency's fees. The attorney's or collection agency's fees shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the taxes or other charges so collected. The administrative costs shall be in addition to all penalties and interest, and shall not exceed thirty dollars ($30.00) for taxes and other charges collected subsequent to thirty (30) or more days after notice of delinquent taxes or charges but prior to the taking of any judgment with respect to such delinquent taxes or charges, and thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for taxes or other charges collected subsequent to judgment. If the collection activity is to collect on a nuisance abatement lien, the fee for administrative costs shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) or twenty-five (25) percent of the cost, whichever is less; however, in no event shall the fee be less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 11-1700-902, § 1, 4-19-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 11-1700-902, § 1, adopted Apr. 19, 2011, repealed former § 22-7, and enacted a new § 22-7 as set out herein. Former § 22-7 pertained to the same subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 96-1700-543, adopted May 8, 1996. 
Sec. 22-8. - Criminal penalties. 
    It shall be a misdemeanor for any person to willfully fail or refuse to file a return, application or report at the time or times required by this Chapter 22 or to make a false statement with intent to defraud in such returns. The penalty for such misdemeanor shall not exceed those prescribed by general law for (a) a Class 3 misdemeanor if the amount of the tax lawfully assessed in connection with the return, application or report is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or less, or (b) a Class 1 misdemeanor if the amount of the tax lawfully assessed in connection with the return is more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3916.1. 
Sec. 22-9. - Refund of taxes erroneously paid. 
    If the commissioner of the revenue determines that any taxes provided by this Chapter 22 are erroneously paid and such erroneous payment was not caused by willful failure or refusal of the taxpayer to furnish the tax-assessing authority with the necessary information, as required by law, then such taxes may be refunded or exonerated to the extent they are erroneous. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3990. 
Secs. 22-10-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAX ON REAL PROPERTY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinances levying and prescribing the rate for real estate taxes for specific years are not included in this Code and, under the terms of § 1-6, are not affected by the Code or the ordinance adopting the Code. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-16. - When and where due and payable; tax bills. 
    Taxes accruing on real property in the city shall be due and payable at the office of the treasurer on or before the fifth day of each June and December of each year, except as provided below. Tax bills shall be rendered on or before the fifth day of each May and November of each year. 
    Second half real property taxes for tax year 2000 shall be due and payable at the office of the treasurer on or before December 15, 2000. This provision shall only be effective for the tax year 2000. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96; Ord. No. 97-1700-560, 4-22-97; Ord. No. 01-1700-649, § 1, 2-6-01) 
State Law reference- Authority of governing body to establish time for payment of taxes, Code of Virginia, § 58.1-3916. 
Sec. 22-17. - Collection. 
    The city treasurer shall commence to receive any and all taxes and other amounts payable with respect to real property as soon as he receives copies of the commissioner's books. The city treasurer, after the due date of any tax, shall proceed to collect such tax from the person chargeable therefor by distress or as otherwise permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Collection, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3910 et seq. 
Sec. 22-18. - Release of lien on portion of real property. 
    When an individual purchases or acquires a portion of a tract of real property located in the city, the individual may apply to the commissioner of the revenue to determine the amount of any tax or assessment that is properly chargeable against such portion of real property. The city treasurer shall release such portion of real property from any lien for delinquent taxes upon receipt of payment for the total amount of taxes and penalty and interest due on such portion of real property. 
(Ord. No. 96-1700-543, 5-8-96) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia § 58.1-3226.1. 
Secs. 22-19-22-25. - Reserved.
