(b)  When the city manager has set the maximum speed limit in a highway work zone pursuant to this section, and one (1) or more signs or markers have been placed in conformity with section 46.2-1300 of the Code of Virginia, as the same may be amended from time to time, and such signs or markers are not missing, substantially defaced, or obscured so that an ordinarily observant person under the same circumstances would not be aware of the existence of this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle in excess of such maximum speed limit. Operation of a motor vehicle in excess of a maximum speed limit established pursuant to this section shall be unlawful and constitute a traffic infraction. 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in the preceding subsection (b), when workers are present and when a highway work zone is indicated by appropriately placed signs displaying the maximum speed limit and the penalty for violations, operation of any motor vehicle in excess of a maximum speed limit established pursuant to this section shall be unlawful and constitute a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall preclude the prosecution or conviction for reckless driving of any motor vehicle operator whose operation of any motor vehicle in a highway work zone, apart from speed, demonstrates a reckless disregard for life, limb, or property. 
(Ord. No. 09-1700-869, § 1, 4-21-09) 
Sec. 24-29. - Police escort for funeral processions; right-of-way for such processions. 
(a)  The chief of police is hereby authorized, in his discretion, to provide a police escort for funeral processions. 
(b)  Funeral processions traveling under police escort shall have the right-of-way in any street through which they may pass. 
State Law reference- Right-of-way for funeral processions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-828. 
Sec. 24-30. - Driving in funeral processions. 
    Each driver in a funeral procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as is practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(Code 1971, § 16-8) 
Sec. 24-31. - Driving through funeral or other processions. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles, persons or animals comprising a funeral or other authorized procession, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. This provision shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(Code 1971, § 16-8) 
Sec. 24-32. - Limitations on backing. 
    The operator of a vehicle in the city shall not back such vehicle, unless such movement can be made with safety and without interfering with other traffic. 
(Code 1971, § 16-19) 
Sec. 24-33. - Blocking intersections or marked cross-walks. 
    No operator of a vehicle shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk, unless there is sufficient space beyond such intersection or crosswalk, in the direction in which such vehicle is proceeding, to accommodate the vehicle without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic-control signal indication to proceed. 
(Code 1971, § 16-20) 
Sec. 24-34. - Driving over curbs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle over a curb, except for the purpose of parking such vehicle in accord with the provisions of section 24-53. 
Sec. 24-34.1. - Truck traffic prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)  The operator of every truck passing through the city at any point shall only proceed through the city on the truck route or routes depicted in blue on a map on file at city hall and designated within this section. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a truck on a street in the city that has been posted with signs prohibiting the passage of trucks. It shall be unlawful for any truck operator to deviate from those streets designated and marked as truck routes; provided, however, that deviations therefrom and return thereto may be made by the most direct routes reasonably possible for the purpose of making or receiving truck deliveries. 
    The word "truck" as used in this section shall mean every motor vehicle meeting any one (1) or more of the following specifications: 
Having more than two (2) axles; 
Having more than six (6) wheel surfaces in contact with the street surface; 
Having a total length that exceeds twenty-four (24) feet; 
Having a registered weight on record with any state agency of motor vehicles that exceeds ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross vehicle weight. 
    The following streets are hereby designated as truck routes within the city: 
Centreville Road [State Route 28]; 
Digital Drive; 
Enterprise Court; 
Euclid Avenue; 
Euclid Court; 
Hardee Drive 
Industry Drive; 
Manassas Drive; 
Mathis Avenue; 
Owens Drive; 
Vassau Court; and 
Venture Court. 
    The provisions of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to government or emergency vehicles or to such other vehicles that carry a written permit issued by the chief of police of the city. The chief of police shall issue such permits only where it is clearly demonstrated to him or his authorized agent that such permit will alleviate a hardship or will promote better flow of traffic through the city. 
    The city manager is hereby authorized and directed to provide and maintain signs which will apprise an ordinarily observant person of the prohibitions and requirements of this section and which will conform substantially in size, design and color to those erected for the same purpose by the Virginia Department of Transportation. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 04-1700-740, § 1, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 24-35. - Driving while under influence of alcohol or drugs; adoption of state law. 
    The provisions of article 2 (section 18.2-266 et seq.) of chapter 7 of title 18.2, as amended and reenacted, of the Code of Virginia are hereby adopted and incorporated mutatis mutandis as a part of this chapter to the same extent as if set out at length herein and it shall be unlawful for any person within the city to violate or fail or refuse to comply with any such provision. 
(Ord. No. 76-1700-84, 8-3-76; Ord. No. 82-1700-203, 8-17-82; Ord. No. 83-1700-227, 12-20-83; Ord. No. 84-1700-239, 6-5-84; Ord. No. 85-1700-285, 7-2-85; Ord. No. 86-1700-340, 6-17-86; Ord. No. 87-1700-360, 6-2-87; Ord. No. 88-1700-381, 6-21-88; Ord. No. 89-1700-400, 6-6-89; Ord. No. 90-1700-422, 6-19-90; Ord. No. 90-1700-429, 12-4-90; Ord. No. 91-1700-447, 7-2-91; Ord. No. 92-1700-466, 7-7-92; Ord. No. 93-1700-490, 7-6-93; Ord. No. 94-1700-509, 7-5-94; Ord. No. 95-1700-525, 2-7-95; Ord. No. 95-1700-534, 7-5-95; Ord. No. 96-1700-546, 7-2-96; Ord. No. 97-1700-563, 7-1-97; Ord. No. 98-1700-586, 7-7-98; Ord. No. 99-1700-609, 7-6-99; Ord. No. 00-1700-630, 7-5-00; Ord. No. 01-1700-670, 7-3-01; Ord. No. 02-1700-688, 7-2-02; Ord. No. 03-1700-719, 7-1-03; Ord. No. 04-1700-750, 7-1-04; Ord. No. 04-1700-751, 7-1-04; Ord. No. 05-1700-783, 6-21-05; Ord. No. 06-1700-807, 6-29-06; Ord. No. 07-1700-833, 6-19-07; Ord. No. 08-1700-854, 6-17-08, eff. 7-1-08; Ord. No. 09-1700-876, 6-16-09, eff. 7-1-09; Ord. No. 10-1700-891, 6-15-10, eff. 7-1-10; Ord. No. 11-1700-910, 6-21-11, eff. 7-1-11; Ord. No. 13-1700-945, 7-16-13; Ord. No. 14-1700-953, 6-3-14, eff. 7-1-14; Ord. No. 18-1700-1016, 6-19-18, eff. 7-1-18) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt state law on above subject, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313. 
Sec. 24-36. - Operating motor vehicles on or over curbs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in such a manner as to cause the said vehicle to travel on or over any curb adjoining any public road, street or highway. 
    For the purpose of interpreting this section, "curb" shall be defined as an edging, as of concrete exceeding two (2) inches in height, built along a street to form part of a gutter except at approved driveway entries with aprons. 
    Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(Ord. No. 79-1700-146, 12-4-79) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 79-1700-146 amended Code 1971 by adding the provisions included herein as § 24-36. 
Sec. 24-37. - Failure to wear protective bicycle helmet. 
    Any person fourteen (14) years of age or younger riding or being carried on a bicycle within the city on any highway (as defined in Code of Virginia Section 46.2-100), sidewalk, public bicycle path or other public property shall wear a protective helmet. The helmet must be worn on the person's head and must meet the standards promulgated by the American National Standards Institute or the Snell Memorial Foundation. 
    Violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). However, such fine shall be suspended (1) for first-time violations and (2) for violators who, subsequent to the violation but prior to the imposition of the fine, purchase helmets of the type required by this section. 
    Violation of this section shall not constitute negligence, assumption of risk, be considered in mitigation of damages of whatever nature, be admissible in evidence or be the subject of comment by counsel in any action for the recovery of damages arising out of operation of any bicycle, nor shall anything in this section change any existing law, rule or procedure pertaining to any civil action. 
(Ord. No. 97-1700-562, 5-20-97) 
Sec. 24-38. - Exceeding speed limit. 
(a)  Operation of any motor vehicle on a highway in any residence district at a speed exceeding that indicated as a maximum speed by signs posted in such district by or on the authority of the governing body through its city manager, which also display the penalty for violation, shall be unlawful and shall constitute a traffic infraction punishable by a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00), in addition to any other penalties provided by law. The terms "highway" and "residence district" when used in this article shall have the definitions respectively ascribed to them in the Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100. 
(b)  Residents in a residence district may petition the governing body to have one (1) or more signs described in the preceding subsection (a) posted along any street or portion of a street in such residence district. Any such petition must be signed by residents representing more than fifty (50) per cent of the residences on the street or portion of a street that is the subject of the petition. 
(Ord. No. 97-1700-573, 10-21-97; Ord. No. 07-1700-817, § 1, 11-21-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 97-1700-573, adopted Oct. 21, 1997, set out provisions intended to create a new section, § 24-37. As § 24-37 already existed in the Code and at the editor's discretion, the provisions of said ordinance were set out as § 24-38. 
Sec. 24-39. - Safety equipment required for mopeds; penalty for violation. 
    Every person operating a moped on a public street or highway in the City of Manassas Park shall wear a face shield, safety glasses, or goggles of a type approved by the superintendent of the Virginia Department of State Police, or have his moped equipped with safety glass or a windshield at all times while operating such vehicle, and operators and passengers thereon, if any, shall wear protective helmets of a type approved by the superintendent. 
    Violation of this section shall constitute a traffic infraction and shall be subject to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 03-1700-706, § 1, 4-1-03) 
Sec. 24-40. - Operator to give full time and attention to driving. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon the streets or highways of this city without giving his full time and attention to the operation of the vehicle. 
(b)  Any violation of this section shall constitute a traffic infraction, not reportable to the department of motor vehicles, but punishable by a fine of not more than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Ord. No. 15-1700-970, § 1, 6-2-15) 
Sec. 24-41. - Photo and video monitoring systems to enforce law against passing stopped school buses; penalty. 
(a)  The Manassas Park City School Board is hereby authorized to install and operate photo and/or video monitoring systems in or on public schools buses operated by the school board, or to contract with a private vendor to install and operate such systems, for the purpose of recording violations of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-844.A. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, "monitoring system" means a system with one (1) or more camera sensors and computers installed and operated on a school bus that produce live digital and recorded photographs or videos of motor vehicles being operated in violation of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-859. 
(c)  All monitoring systems installed on public school buses shall, at a minimum, produce a recorded image of the license plate of the motor vehicle and shall record the activation status of at least one (1) warning device as prescribed in Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1090, and the time, date, and location of the school bus when the image is recorded. 
(d)  The driver of a motor vehicle found to be in violation of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-859, based on evidence obtained from a photo or video monitoring system, shall be liable for a civil penalty of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) imposed in accordance with this section. 
(e)  Any person who receives a summons or notice of violation from a law enforcement officer pursuant to this section may waive his right to appear in court and be formally tried for the offense pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 16.1-69.40:1.B. The waiver shall be effective when the person pays two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) to the Manassas Park Treasurer's Office within thirty (30) business days after receipt of the summons or notice of violation. 
(f)  All penalties collected for violations pursuant to this section shall be paid into the city treasury. The treasurer, after first deducting costs incurred by the police department in reviewing violations, shall remit the remaining balance of funds received to the school board. 
(Ord. No. 17-1700-1001, § 1, 5-2-17; Ord. No. 17-1700-1007, § 1, 8-15-17) 
Secs. 24-42-24-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Parking bicycles at Manassas Park Shopping Center, § 6-4; open storage of inoperative motor vehicles in residential districts, § 17-53; limitation on parking recreational equipment on streets, § 31-32(b)(2). 
State Law reference- General authority of city to regulate parking, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 

Sec. 24-47. - Regulations of city manager relative to parking. 
(a)  The city manager (or such other officer as may be designated) may classify with reference to parking and may designate the time, place and manner such vehicles may be allowed to park on the streets and highways, and may make and enforce such additional rules and regulations as parking conditions may require. When any parking regulation is established pursuant to this section, the city manager (or other designated officer) shall cause to be erected appropriate signs or markers so that an ordinarily observant person, who may be affected by such regulation will be aware of such regulation. 
(b)  When any regulation is made pursuant to this section and when appropriate signs or markers have been erected as required by this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to violate any such regulation. 
(Code 1971, § 16-3; Ord. No. 2000-1700-638 § 1, 10-17-00) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 
Sec. 24-48. - General prohibitions. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic-control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(2)  Within an intersection. 
(3)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant. 
(4)  On a crosswalk. 
(5)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection; provided that, where there is no crosswalk at an intersection, no person shall so park a vehicle within twenty (20) feet from the intersection of curblines or, if none, then within fifteen (15) feet of the intersection of property lines. 
(6)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing beacon, stop sign or traffic control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
(7)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by official signs or markings. 
(8)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing. [3] 
(9)  Within fifteen (15) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within seventy-five (75) feet of the entrance, when properly signposted. 
(10)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such parking would obstruct traffic. 
(11)  On the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(12)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a street or highway or within a tunnel. 
(13)  At any place where official signs prohibit parking. 
(14)  In spaces reserved for handicapped persons. 
(15)  In spaces reserved for residents of the city unless such vehicle displays a valid motor vehicle license decal issued by the city. 
(16)  In a designated fire lane. 
(17)  By a curb which has been painted yellow under the authority of the city manager. 
(18)  In front of or adjacent to a residential mailbox so as to obstruct or retard the passage of the United States mail or any carrier or vehicle carrying the mail. 
(19)  On the side of a street, unless parked parallel to and no farther than six (6) inches from the curb or shoulder, and facing in the same general direction as the flow of traffic. 
(b)  No person, other than a police officer, shall move a vehicle into any such prohibited area or away from a curb such distance as is unlawful. 
(Code 1971, § 16-34; Ord. No. 81-1700-182-A, 10-6-81, Ord. No. 2000-1700-638, § 1, 10-17-00; Ord. No. 01-1700-678, § 3, 11-20-01; Ord. No. 07-1700-821, § 3, 2-20-07; Ord. No. 10-1700-885, § 1, 2-2-10) 
Cross reference- Trash and garbage obstructing mailboxes, § 13-2; placing obstructions in or on streets, gutters and sidewalks, § 20-3. 
State Law reference- Parking in front of driveways, near fire hydrants, etc., Code of Virginia § 46.2-1239. 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Prohibition against standing vehicle on railroads tracks, § 19-2. 

Sec. 24-49. - Angle parking. 
    Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this chapter, the chief of police may, when in his discretion the public interest so requires, provide for angle parking on any street or portion thereof; provided, that such streets are marked so as to apprise an ordinarily observant person of such regulation. 
(Code 1971, § 16-36) 
Sec. 24-50. - Parking a vehicle having no current city motor vehicle license. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator of a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer registered in Manassas Park to fail to obtain and display a current city motor vehicle license as described in article III, city vehicle license, of chapter 14, Licenses, of the Code of the City of Manassas Park, Virginia. 
(b)  Violation of this section shall constitute a class 4 misdemeanor, the penalty for which shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(c)  Local law enforcement officers are authorized to issue citations, summonses, parking tickets, and/or uniform traffic summonses for violations of this section to all residents of Manassas Park to which [whom] a motor vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer is registered. 
(d)  A violation of this section by the registered owner of any vehicle registered in Manassas Park shall not be discharged by payment of a fine except upon presentation of satisfactory evidence that a current city motor vehicle license has been obtained. 
(Code 1971, § 16-35; Ord. No. 79-1700-140, 7-3-79; Ord. No. 79-1700-141, 8-21-79; Ord. No. 03-1700-704, § 1, 3-18-03; Ord. No. 11-1700-906, § 1, 5-24-11) 
Sec. 24-51. - Parking of motor trucks prohibited (excluding recreational vehicles); exception. 
(a)  No person shall park on the streets of the city any motor truck meeting any one of the following specifications: 
(1)  Having more than two (2) axles; 
(2)  Having more than six (6) wheel surfaces in contact with street surface; 
(3)  That exceeds a total length of twenty-four (24) feet; 
(4)  Registered with any state agency of motor vehicles exceeding ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross vehicle weight. 
(b)  A motor truck meeting any of the four (4) enumerated descriptions above may be parked on the streets of the city for the purpose of receiving loads and making deliveries to city residents. 
(Ord. No. 74-1700-63, 9-3-74; Ord. No. 86-1700-348, 10-21-86; Ord. No. 87-1700-362, 6-2-87) 
Sec. 24-51.1. - Parking when snow emergency plans are in effect. 
(a)  The procedures prescribed in this section are adopted and shall be in effect when a snow emergency has been declared by the mayor or the city council or its delegated agent. 
(b)  In the absence of the mayor and a conclusive decision of the council or its agent, the city manager or the assistant city manager may invoke either of the snow emergency plans in order of the plans. The order of the plans are: Snow emergency plan No. 1; snow emergency plan No. 2. 
(c)  When the proper authorities invoke snow emergency plan No. 1, all vehicles shall be parked on the side of the street on which off numbered houses are located. Any vehicle improperly parked will be issued a warning citation for improper parking and moved to the proper side of the street by the city. Any vehicle improperly parked after the snow emergency plan has been in effect for twenty-four (24) hours or any vehicle having been issued a warning citation and moved, as herein required, will be issued a citation for improper parking. 
(d)  After snow emergency plan No. 1 has been in effect a sufficient length of time to clear the streets and the weather conditions eliminate the further possibility of more snowfall for a reasonable length of time, the proper authorities, may declare snow emergency plan No. 2 in effect. All vehicles parked on the streets will be parked on the side of the street on which even numbered houses are located. Any vehicle improperly parked will be issued a warning citation for improper parking and moved to the proper side of the street by the city. Any vehicle improperly parked after snow emergency plan No. 2 has been in effect for twenty-four (24) hours or any vehicle having been issued a warning citation and moved, as herein required, will be issued a citation for improper parking. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to eliminate or take precedence over any other ordinance concerning parking, except where it is so stated. 
(Ord. No. 78-1700-113, 1-24-78) 
Sec. 24-52. - Parking on unpaved portion of street. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle on the unpaved portion of any street. 
Sec. 24-53. - Parking on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be parked on or obstruct any portion of a sidewalk which is set aside for the use of the public, unless temporarily in the process of loading or unloading furniture, appliances, building materials and the like. 
(Ord. No. 72-1700-48, 5-2-72) 
Sec. 24-53.1. - Parking for the handicapped; reserved areas; fine. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any nonhandicapped operator of a motor vehicle to park any motor vehicles in a parking space reserved for handicapped persons at privately owned shopping centers and business offices, except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. A city police officer, or any other authorized law enforcement officer, may issue a ticket or summons for any violation of this section without the necessity of a warrant being obtained by the owner of such shopping center or business office. 
(b)  The following motor vehicles may lawfully park in parking spaces reserved for the handicapped at privately owned shopping centers and business offices: 
(1)  Any motor vehicle registered to a handicapped person which is identified by a decal or distinguishing license plate issued by the division of motor vehicles of the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
(2)  Any motor vehicle actually being used to transport a handicapped person which displays the distinguishing decal issued by the division of motor vehicles of the Commonwealth of Virginia. 
(3)  Any motor vehicle which is registered in any state other than Virginia that displays such other state's license plate decal, or other device, indicating that the vehicle is registered to, or being used to transport, a handicapped person. 
(c)  For the purposes of this section, the distinguishing license plates and decals issued by the division of motor vehicles of the Commonwealth of Virginia shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Disabled veteran (DV0-000). 
(2)  Handicapped person (HP0-000). 
(3)  Handicapped person license plates displaying the international symbol of access. 
(4)  Decals issued by the division of motor vehicles for display on the sun visor of the driver's side of a vehicle, when the vehicle is parked in an area reserved for handicapped parking. 
(d)  For purposes of this section a parking space reserved for handicapped persons shall be any parking space located at a privately owned shopping center or business office that is marked by a sign. A symbol painted on the ground indicating that the parking space is reserved for handicapped persons is optional. Such sign and painted symbol may consist of words or phrases or may consist of the international symbol of access adopted by the Rehabilitation International Assembly. 
(e)  For purposes of this section a "handicapped person" shall be any person by the veterans' administration, social security administration, division of motor vehicles or the Commonwealth of Virginia, or any comparable organization or department of any other state. 
(Ord. No. 81-1700-182, 10-6-81; Ord. No. 89-1700-395, 4-4-89; Ord. No. 91-1700-450, 9-17-91; Ord. No. 2000-1700-638, § 1, 10-17-00; Ord. No. 18-1700-1019, § 1, 6-19-18, eff. 7-1-18) 
Sec. 24-53.2. - Parking reserved for residents of the city; reserved areas; fine. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any operator of a motor vehicle to park any motor vehicle in a parking space reserved for residents of the city unless such vehicle displays a valid motor vehicle license decal issued by the city. A city police officer, or any other authorized law enforcement officer, may issue a ticket or summons for any violation of this section. 
(b)  Any person receiving a ticket or summons showing a specific violation of this section may, within twenty-four (24) hours of the issuance of such ticket or summons, pay to the city treasurer the sum of twenty dollars ($20.00) as a fine for such violation, and on such payment, he shall be relieved of further prosecution for such violation. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, a parking space reserved for residents of the city shall be any parking space that is marked by a sign that provides reasonable notice. 
(Ord. No. 2000-1700-638, § 1, 10-17-00) 
Sec. 24-54. - Backing to curbs. 
    No vehicle shall be backed up to a curb, except during the time actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise therefrom. 
(Code 1971, § 16-37) 
Sec. 24-55. - Manner of using loading zones. 
    Where a loading and unloading zone has been set apart by the city manager, the following regulations shall apply with respect to the use of such areas: 
(1)  No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle for any purpose or length of time, other than for the expeditious unloading and delivery or pickup and loading of materials, in any place marked as a curb loading zone during hours when the provisions applicable to such zones are in effect. All delivery vehicles, other than regular delivery trucks using such loading zones, shall be identified by the owner's or company's name in letters three (3) inches high on both sides of the vehicle. 
(2)  The driver of a passenger vehicle may stop temporarily in a space marked as a curb loading zone for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, loading or unloading passengers or bundles, when such stopping does not interfere with any vehicle used for the transportation of materials which is waiting to enter or is about to enter such loading space. 
(Code 1971, § 16-38) 
Sec. 24-56. - Manner of using bus stops and taxicab stands. 
    Where a bus stop or taxicab stand has been set apart by the city manager, the following regulations shall apply as to the use thereof: No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in a bus stop, or other than a taxicab in a taxicab stand, when such stop or stand has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily stop therein for the purpose of and while actually engaged in the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus or taxicab waiting to enter or about to enter such zone. 
(Code 1971, § 16-39) 
Sec. 24-57. - General regulations governing private property. 
    No person shall stand or park a vehicle on any private lot or lot area, without the express or implied consent of the owner thereof. Whenever signs or markings have been erected on any lot or lot area, contiguous or adjacent to a street, thoroughfare or alley, indicating that no vehicles are permitted to stand or park thereon, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle across any curb or lot line or over any driveway from a street or alley into such lot or area for the purpose of standing or parking such vehicle, or for any person to stop, stand or park any vehicle in such lot or lot area. 
(Code 1971, § 16-43) 
Sec. 24-57.1. - Penalty for violation of parking ordinances or regulations; presumption as to guilt of owner of vehicle; payment of fine; contest of citation; notice of summons for delinquent fines. 
(a)  In the case of any violation of any parking regulation or ordinances contained in this article, or, with the exception of the zoning ordinance, any other ordinance of the City of Manassas Park relative to parking, the penalty therefore shall be a fine of forty dollars ($40.00) for each such violation. 
(b)  Notwithstanding subsection (a) above, the fine for a nonhandicapped operator of a motor vehicle parking in a space reserved for handicapped persons as prohibited by section 24-53.1 shall be one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00), and the fine for violation of subsections (3) and (16) of section 24-48 shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(c)  In any prosecution, for any violation of any ordinance or regulation relative to parking, proof that the vehicle described in the notice of violation was parked in violation of an ordinance or any regulation adopted thereunder, together with proof that the defendant was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner of the vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a rebuttable presumption that such registered owner of the vehicle was the person who parked the vehicle at the place where, and for the time during which, such violation occurred. 
(d)  In the event that the defendant elects not to contest the notice of violation issued against him pursuant to the provisions of this section, then within thirty (30) days following receipt of said notice of violation, he shall pay the penalty provided for in subsection (a) above to the treasurer of the City of Manassas Park or his designated agent. The treasurer shall collect and account for all sums received in payment of such uncontested citations. 
(e)  If the defendant elects to contest the notice of violation issued against him under the provisions of the ordinance referenced above, he shall, within five (5) calendar days following receipt thereof, notify the chief of police or his designated agent in writing of his intent to contest said citation, whereupon the chief of police or his designated agent shall certify in writing to the clerk of the general district court the defendant's intention to contest said citation. The clerk shall proceed to docket the case as provided by law. 
(f)  In the event that the defendant has not notified the chief of police or his designated agent of his intention to contest the parking citation within the five-day period set forth in subsection (e) above and has failed to pay the fine due within the 30-day period set forth in subsection (d) above, the fines set forth in subsections (a) and (b) above shall be doubled and the chief of police or his designated agent shall notify said person, by letter addressed to the person's last known address or the address shown for such violator on the records of the department of motor vehicles, that he may pay any fine required by law for such violation within thirty (30) days following receipt of said notice, and that if he fails to do so, a summons or other appropriate process may issue against him. The notice required by this section shall be sent in an envelope bearing the words "Law Enforcement Notice" stamped or printed thereon in letters at least one-half (1/2) inch in height. In the event that the defendant does not pay any fine required by law within the 30-day period provided in this subsection (f), the fine shall be deemed delinquent, and either (i) the police officer who issued the notice of violation will then seek the issuance of a criminal summons or other appropriate process, or (ii) the treasurer will proceed to collect the delinquent fine using a third party collection agency or notify the Virginia Department of Motor Vehicles that reissuance or renewal of vehicle registration is to be delayed until full payment of the delinquent fine has been made with the treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 78-1700-122, 6-20-78; Ord. No. 79-1700-148, 12-4-79; Ord. No. 81-1700-182A, 10-6-81; Ord. No. 84-1700-230, 2-21-84; Ord. No. 89-1700-395, 4-4-89; Ord. No. 2000-1700-638, § 1, 10-17-00; Ord. No. 01-1700-678, § 4, 11-20-01; Ord. No. 18-1700-1019, § 2, 6-19-18, eff. 7-1-18) 
Sec. 24-57.2. - Removal or immobilization of motor vehicles against which there are outstanding parking violations. 
(a)  Whenever there is found any motor vehicle parked upon a public street or highway or other public ground within the city against which there are three (3) or more outstanding unpaid or otherwise unsettled parking citations or parking violation notices, such vehicle may, by or under the direction of a city police officer, be removed or conveyed, by towing or otherwise, to a place in the city or in an adjacent locality designated by the city chief of police for the temporary storage of such vehicle, or such vehicle may be immobilized in a manner which will prevent its removal or operation except by authorized officers or members of the city police department. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the police officer removing or immobilizing a motor vehicle pursuant to this section, or under whose direction such vehicle is removed or immobilized, to inform as soon as practicable the owner of the removed or immobilized vehicle of the nature and circumstances of the prior unsettled parking citations or parking violation notices for which such vehicle was removed or immobilized. In any case involving immobilization of a vehicle under this section, there shall be placed on such vehicle, in a conspicuous manner, a notice warning that such vehicle has been immobilized and that any attempt to move such vehicle might damage it. 
(c)  The owner of an immobilized vehicle, or other person acting on his behalf, shall be allowed at least twenty-four (24) hours from the time of immobilization to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle. Failure to repossess or secure the release of the vehicle within that time period may result in the removal of such vehicle to a storage area for safekeeping under the direction of a police officer or member of the police department. 
(d)  The owner of a motor vehicle removed or immobilized pursuant to this section, or other person acting on his behalf, shall be permitted to repossess or to secure the release of such vehicle by payment of the outstanding parking fees for which the vehicle was removed or immobilized and by payment of all costs incidental to immobilization, removal and storage of the vehicle, and the efforts to locate the owner of the vehicle. Should the owner fail or refuse to pay such fines and costs, or should the identity or whereabouts of the owner be unknown and unascertainable, the motor vehicle may be sold in accordance with the procedures set forth in section 46.2-1213 of the Code of Virginia. 
(Ord. No. 18-1700-1019, § 3, 6-19-18, eff. 7-1-18) 
Sec. 24-58. - Unattended vehicles-Removal, storage and sale, generally. 
(a)  An "unattended vehicle" shall mean any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof that: 
(1)  Is left unattended on a public highway or other public property and constitutes a traffic hazard; 
(2)  Is illegally parked; 
(3)  Is left unattended for more than ten (10) days on public property, or is left unattended for more than ten (10) days on private property without the permission of the property owner, lessee, or occupant and no sign is posted on such private property as set forth in subsection 24-58(b) herein; or 
(4)  Is immobilized on a public roadway by weather conditions or other emergency situation. 
(b)  Any owner of private property that is normally left open to the public for parking may, upon full compliance with chapter 31 herein, post signs on his property warning that vehicles left on such property for more than seventy-two (72) hours will be towed or removed at their owners' expense. Upon complaint of the owner of such property, any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer, or part thereof that has been left for more than seventy-two (72) hours thereon shall be presumed to be an unattended vehicle and will be disposed in accordance with this section. 
(c)  Any unattended vehicle may be removed for safekeeping, by or under the direction of a law-enforcement officer, to a storage area; provided that no such unattended vehicle shall be so removed from private property without the written request of the owner, lessee or occupant thereof. 
(d)  Any person at whose request an unattended vehicle is removed from private property pursuant to this section shall indemnify the city against any loss or expense incurred by reason of the removal, storage or sale thereof; and any writing requesting the removal of an unattended vehicle from private property shall include language indemnifying the city against any loss or expense incurred by reason of the removal, storage or sale thereof. 
(e)  Each removal under this section shall be reported immediately to the police department, and notice thereof shall be given to the owner of the unattended vehicle as promptly as possible. 
(f)  Before obtaining possession of an unattended vehicle removed pursuant to this section, the owner of such unattended vehicle shall pay to the city, and any other parties entitled thereto, all costs incidental to the vehicle's removal and storage and all costs incidental to locating the owner. Should such owner fail or refuse to pay such costs, or should the identity or whereabouts of such owner be unknown and unascertainable after a diligent search has been made, and after notice to him at his last known address and to the holder of any lien of record in the office of the division of motor vehicles of this state against the unattended vehicle, the vehicle shall be treated as an abandoned vehicle and will be disposed in accordance with section 24-60. 
(g)  Any unattended vehicle shall be presumed to be an abandoned vehicle, and will be disposed of in accordance with section 24-60, if it: 
(1)  Lacks either a current license plate, a current county, city or town license plate or sticker, or a valid state safety inspection certificate or sticker; and 
(2)  Has been in a specific location for four (4) days without being moved. 
(Code 1971, §§ 16-40, 16-44; Ord. No. 03-1700-726, § 1, 9-2-03) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1213; department of motor vehicles to be notified of removals, § 46.2-1215. 
Sec. 24-59. - Same-Contracts with private persons for removal and storage. 
    The city may enter into contracts with the owners or operators of garages or other storage areas for the removal or storage of unattended vehicles as defined in section 24-58. The contracts shall provide for the payment by the city of reasonable charges for the removal and storage of such unattended vehicles, shall require such owners or operators to deliver such vehicles to the owners thereof or their agents upon demand therefor, provided that such owners or owners' agents first provide satisfactory evidence of identity and ownership or agency and make payment of such removal and storage charges, and shall require the owners or operators of such garages or places of storage to indemnify the owners of such vehicles for injury or damage thereto resulting from the negligent removal or storage thereof, and such owners or operators shall be required to provide themselves with adequate liability insurance to cover such indemnity. 
(Code 1971, § 16-41; Ord. No. 03-1700-726, § 1, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 24-60. - Removal and disposition of abandoned vehicles. 
(a)  An "abandoned vehicle" shall mean any motor vehicle, trailer, semitrailer or part thereof that: 
(1)  Is inoperable and is left unattended on public property, other than on an interstate highway or primary highway, for more than forty-eight (48) hours; 
(2)  Has remained illegally on public property for more than forty-eight (48) hours; 
(3)  Is inoperable, left unattended, or both, on an interstate highway; 
(4)  Is inoperable, left unattended, or both, on the shoulder of a primary highway; or 
(5)  Is presumed to be an abandoned vehicle pursuant to the provisions of subsection 24-58(g). 
(b)  An "inoperable abandoned vehicle" shall mean an abandoned vehicle that is inoperable and for which the fair market value, as determined by the city commissioner of the revenue, is less than the cost of its restoration to an operable condition. 
(c)  Any abandoned vehicle, or any vehicle treated as an abandoned vehicle pursuant to subsection 24-58(f), may be taken into custody and disposed of by the police department or an authorized agent of the city acting under the direction of a law enforcement officer ("authorized agent"). 
(1)  The police department or any authorized agent that takes an abandoned vehicle into custody shall, within fifteen (15) days, by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, notify the owner of record of the abandoned vehicle and any person of record having a security interest in the vehicle, that the vehicle has been taken into custody. The notice shall: 
a.  State the year, make, model, and serial number of the abandoned motor vehicle; 
b.  Set forth the location of the facility where it is being held; 
c.  Inform the owner and any person having a security interest therein of their right to reclaim the vehicle within fifteen (15) days after the date of the notice, provided that all towing, preservation, and storage charges resulting from placing the vehicle in custody shall first be paid by the owner or person(s) having a security interest in the vehicle; and 
d.  State that the failure of the owner or person(s) having a security interest in the vehicle to reclaim the vehicle within the time provided shall constitute (i) a waiver by the owner and any person having a security interest of all right, title, and interest in the vehicle and (ii) consent to the sale of the abandoned motor vehicle at a public auction. 
(2)  If records of the department of motor vehicles ("DMV") contain no address for the owner or no address of any person shown by the DMV's records to have a security interest in the vehicle, or if the identity and addresses of the owner and any person having a security interest in the vehicle cannot be determined with reasonable certainty, notice by publication once in a newspaper of general circulation in the area where the motor vehicle was abandoned shall be sufficient to meet all requirements of notice pursuant to this article as to any person who cannot be notified pursuant to the foregoing provisions of this section. Notice by publication may contain multiple listings of abandoned motor vehicles. Any notice of this kind shall be within the time requirements prescribed by this section for notice by mail and shall have the same contents required for a notice by mail. 
(d)  If an abandoned vehicle is not reclaimed pursuant to subsection 24-60(b), the police department or authorized agent shall sell it at public auction. The purchaser of the motor vehicle shall take title to the motor vehicle free of all liens and claims of ownership of others, shall receive a sales receipt at the auction, and shall be entitled to apply to and receive from the DMV a certificate of title and registration card for the vehicle. The sales receipt from the sale shall be sufficient title only for purposes of transferring the vehicle to a demolisher for demolition, wrecking, or dismantling, and in that case no further titling of the vehicle shall be necessary. From the proceeds of the sale of an abandoned motor vehicle the city or its authorized agent shall reimburse itself for the expenses of the auction, the cost of towing, preserving, and storing the vehicle which resulted from placing the abandoned motor vehicle in custody, and all notice and publication costs incurred pursuant to subsection 24-60(b). Any remainder from the proceeds of such sale shall be held for the owner of the abandoned motor vehicle or any person having security interests in the vehicle, as their interests may appear, for ninety days, and then be deposited into the treasury of the locality in which the abandoned motor vehicle was abandoned. 
(e)  Any inoperable abandoned vehicle taken into custody pursuant to the provisions of this section may be disposed of to a demolisher, without title and without the notification procedures set forth in this section, by the city or the person on whose property or in whose possession the inoperable abandoned vehicle is found. The demolisher, on taking custody of the inoperable abandoned vehicle, shall notify the DMV on forms and in the manner prescribed by the commissioner of the DMV. Notwithstanding any other provision of law, no other report or notice shall be required in this instance. 
(Code 1971, § 16-42; Ord. No. 03-1700-726, § 1, 9-2-03) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1214. 
Sec. 24-61. - Limitation on towing fees for vehicles located on private property. 
    Notwithstanding the provisions of this article III, if the owner or representative or agent of the owner of an unattended vehicle subject to removal from private property pursuant to section 24-58 is present and removes the unattended vehicle from such private property before it is actually towed, the unattended vehicle shall not be towed, but the owner or representative or agent of the owner of the unattended vehicle shall be liable for a reasonable fee, not to exceed twenty-five dollars ($25.00), in lieu of towing. 
(Code 1971, § 16-44; Ord. No. 03-1700, 726, § 1, 9-2-03) 
State Law reference- Authority for above section, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1215. 
Sec. 24-62. - Sale of personal property found in vehicles. 
    Any personal property found in any unattended vehicle or abandoned vehicle may be sold incident to the sale of any such vehicle authorized pursuant to section 24-60. 
(Ord. No. 79-1700-142, 8-21-79; Ord. No. 79-1700-143, 8-21-79; Ord. No. 80-1700-167, 11-18-80; Ord. No. 03-1700-726, § 1, 9-2-03) 
State Law reference- Abandoned vehicles, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1200-46.2-1208. 
Sec. 24-63. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 03-1700-726, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 2003, deleted § 24-63, which pertained to unlawful to keep inoperative motor vehicles; definitions, removal and disposition and derived from Ord. No. 87-1700-358, § 2, adopted April 21, 1987.

Chapter 25 - WATER, SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; plumbing code adopted, § 7-18; erosion and sedimentation control, Ch. 8; filling of wells prior to abandonment, § 17-55; covers required on certain wells, § 17-56; subdivision of land, Ch. 21; zoning, Ch. 31. 
State Law reference- Public water supply, Code of Virginia, § 32.1-167 et seq.; authority of city to establish, maintain and operate waterworks and sewage disposal system, § 15.2-2109 et seq.; authority to regulate sewage disposal, § 15.2-2157. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 25-1. - Developers to furnish plans showing location of water mains and sewers. 
    All developers doing business in or with the city shall be required to furnish the city with an "as built" plan showing the water main, sanitary sewer and storm sewer locations. 
(Ord. No. 74-1700-59, 2-19-74) 
Sec. 25-2. - Approved method of disposal of human excrement-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any house used as a human habitation, any warehouse or any public building or other place where human beings congregate or are employed in the city to use or occupy or to rent or lease the same for use or occupancy by any person, or for any person to use or occupy the same, unless and until the house or building in question shall have been supplied or equipped with an approved method of disposal of human excrement of such construction as will comply with the requirements of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 29-15) 
Sec. 25-3. - Same-What constitutes; maintenance. 
(a)  For the purpose of section 25-2, "an approved method of disposal of human excrement" shall be deemed to be either: 
(1)  A flush toilet connected to an approved public or private sewer. 
(2)  A flush toilet connected to an approved, properly installed septic tank system. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or tenant or lessee of any premises properly supplied with an approved method of disposal of human excrement, as defined in this section, to misuse or neglect the same, so as to allow or cause it to cease to be sanitary. 
(Code 1971, §§ 29-16, 29-29) 
State Law reference- Authority to require septic tanks, sewer connections or other means of sewage disposal, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2157. 
Sec. 25-4. - Pit privies prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to install or maintain a pit privy in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 29-28) 
Sec. 25-5. - Separate toilet facilities required for each family dwelling unit. 
    Any house or structure used as a human habitation shall have separate toilet facilities for each family dwelling unit. 
(Code 1971, § 29-17) 
Sec. 25-6. - When sewer connection required. 
    If a public or private sewer is within three hundred (300) feet of a building, the owner shall connect such building to the public sewer or to the private sewer, if the owner of the private sewer will permit such connection, and no other method of sewage disposal shall be used. 
(Code 1971, § 29-21) 
State Law reference- Authority to require sewer connection, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-876. 
Sec. 25-7. - Purchase and installation of water meter. 
    All persons who desire to connect their premises to the city's water system shall purchase a water meter from the City of Manassas Park. The city shall install such meter and it shall thereafter become and remain the property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 08-1700-846, 3-4-08) 
Sec. 25-8. - Availability fee for connections. 
(a)  Generally. Any person who is connected or who shall hereafter connect the water and sewerage facilities of any premises to the water and sewerage systems of the City of Manassas Park shall pay or cause to be paid the sums hereinafter provided for the availability of and connection to such systems. The availability fee shall be reserved and restricted for the City of Manassas Park's Water and Sewer (Enterprise) Capital Fund usage. 
(b)  Residential uses. The availability fee for connecting to the water and sewer systems of the City of Manassas Park for each equivalent residential dwelling unit within and outside the City of Manassas Park with standard, five-eighths ( 5/8 ) inch meter shall be fourteen thousand, three hundred dollars ($14,300.00). The total availability fee shall consist of sixty-four (64) per cent of the availability fee for sewer connection and thirty-six (36) per cent of the availability fee for water connection. Any variance shall require separate approval of the governing body. 
For the purpose of this section, the following shall constitute an equivalent residential dwelling unit: 
(1)  Each single-family attached or detached house. 
(2)  Each unit in a two-family or townhouse development, whether owned or rented. 
(3)  Each sixteen (16) pupils in a school building. 
(4)  Each trailer space in a trailer court. 
(5)  Each equivalent residential dwelling unit of multifamily dwelling units. 
For the purpose of this section, each one-bedroom multifamily dwelling unit shall constitute 0.60 equivalent residential dwelling unit, each two-bedroom multifamily dwelling unit shall constitute 0.64 equivalent residential dwelling unit and each multifamily dwelling unit containing three (3) or more bedrooms shall constitute 1.0 equivalent residential dwelling unit. 
For the purpose of this section, the term multifamily dwelling unit shall mean a single dwelling unit within a multifamily dwelling, whether rented or owned and shall not include townhouses. 
(c)  All other uses. There are hereby established the following availability fees for connecting to water and sewer systems of the City of Manassas Park for all other uses on the basis of the greater of: (i) the amount based on the number of fixture units as shown in paragraphs (d) and (e) below or (ii) the amount based on the size of the required water meter, as shown in paragraph (f) below. 
(d)  Availability fee based on fixture units. The availability fees shall be calculated based on the number of fixtures units, as shown below: 
(1)  For each fixture unit (including roughed-in fixture units) three hundred dollars ($300.00); however, 
(2)  The fixture unit count for uses discharging continuously or semicontinuously to a drainage system leading to the systems of the city shall be increased by two (2) fixture units for each gallon per minute of such continuous or semicontinuous discharge. The rate of such discharge shall be deemed to be that rate certified by the manufacturer of the fixture, or such rates as the city manager or his designee shall determine; 
(3)  A minimum charge of fourteen thousand, three hundred dollars ($14,300.00) shall be effective February 19, 2008, per premises. 
(e)  Fixture units. For the purposes of this section, the following fixture units shall apply: 
(1)  Automatic clothes washer (2-inch standpipe)-3 units. 
(2)  Bathroom group consisting of water closet, lavatory and bathtub or shower stall: 
a.  Flushometer valve closet-8 units. 
b.  Tank type closet-6 units. 
(3)  Bathtub (with or without overhead shower)-2 units. 
(4)  Combination sink and tray with food disposal unit-2 units. 
(5)  Combination sink and tray with 11/2-inch trap-2 units. 
(6)  Combination sink and tray with separate 11/2-inch traps-3 units. 
(7)  Dental unit or cuspidor-1 unit. 
(8)  Dental lavatory-1 unit. 
(9)  Drinking fountain- 1/2 unit. 
(10)  Dishwasher, domestic-2 units. 
(11)  Floor drains with 2-inch waste-2 units. 
(12)  Kitchen sink, domestic, with one 11/2-inch waste-2 units. 
(13)  Kitchen sink, domestic, with food waste grinder-2 units. 
(14)  Lavatory with 1/4-inch waste-1 unit. 
(15)  Laundry tray (one (1) or two (2) compartments)-2 units. 
(16)  Shower stall, domestic-2 units. 
(17)  Showers (group) per head-2 units. 
(18)  Sinks: 
a.  Surgeon's-3 units. 
b.  Flushing rim (with valve)-6 units. 
c.  Service (trap standard)-3 units. 
d.  Service (P trap)-2 units. 
e.  Pot, scullery, etc.-4 units. 
(19)  Urinal, pedestal, syphon jet blowout-6 units. 
(20)  Urinal, wall lip-4 units. 
(21)  Urinal, stall, washout-4 units. 
(22)  Urinal trough (each 6-foot section)-2 units. 
(23)  Wash sink (circular or multiple) each set of faucets-2 units. 
(24)  Water closet, tank-operated-4 units. 
(25)  Water closet, valve-operated-6 units. 
(26)  Fixture drain or trap size: 
a.  11/4-inch and smaller-1 unit. 
b.  11/2-inch-2 units. 
c.  2-inch-3 units. 
d.  21/2-inch-4 units. 
e.  3-inch-5 units. 
f.  4-inch-6 units. 
(f)  Availability fee based on water meter size. The availability fees shall be calculated based on the size of the required water meter, as shown below. The total availability fee shall consist of sixty-four (64) per cent of the fee for sewer connection and thirty-six (36) per cent of the availability fee for water.

(Code 1975, § 29-1; Ord. No. 72-1700-49, 6-20-72; Ord. No. 77-1700-112, § 1, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 79-1700-145, 11-6-79; Ord. No. 80-1700-170, 12-2-80; Ord. No. 86-1700-337, 6-3-86; Ord. No. 90-1700-411, 1-16-90; Ord. No. 92-1700-459, 4-21-92; Ord. No. 97-1700-571, 10-7-97; Ord. No. 97-1700-575, 12-16-97; 99-1700-605, § 1, 6-15-99; 99-1700-607, § 1, 6-1-99; Ord. No. 01-1700-643, § 1, 1-16-01; Ord. No. 01-1700-672, § 1, 7-3-01; Ord. No. 08-1700-846, 3-4-08) 
Sec. 25-9. - Separate connection for buildings. 
(a)  Except as otherwise allowed by the council, each building shall be separately connected with the public water system and the public sewer system. 
(b)  The water, plumbing and sewer drainage system of every building and each residential dwelling unit shall be separately connected with the public water system and public sewer system of the city at the property line. 
(Code 1971, § 29-2; Ord. No. 77-1700-112, § 2, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 79-1700-145, 11-6-79; Ord. No. 80-1700-170, 12-2-80; Ord. No. 86-1700-337, 6-3-86) 
Sec. 25-10. - Responsibility for breaks and stoppage in sewer lines. 
(a)  The city shall be responsible for any break or stoppage, not due to the property owner's negligence or wilful actions, occurring in the sewer line between the property line and the main sewer line. 
(b)  All property owners shall be responsible for any break or stoppage occurring in a sewer line between the house and the property line. 
(c)  If the underground water line from the city water meter to a private residence or business/commercial account breaks, the city will, upon request and sufficient proof, adjust the sewer charge only of the water/sewer fees. Any such adjustment of fees will be determined by the averaged water usage for the three (3) months previous to the water break. 
(Code 1971, § 29-3; Ord. No. 92-1700-456, 4-7-92) 
Sec. 25-11. - Unlawful use of or damage or injury to property of sewer plant or waterworks. 
    No person shall injure or deface the sewage disposal plant, pump station or any house, wall stopcock, fireplug or any other fixture connected with or pertaining to the sewer plant or waterworks. No person shall, without lawful authority, climb over or get through the enclosure around such plant and waterworks. No person shall place any building material or other things on the stopcock or other fixture of a street water main or other service pipe, so as to obstruct access thereto. No person shall remove or injure any pipe, fireplug, hydrant or stopcock. No person shall use water from city lines for any purpose for which he has neither paid nor obtained permission. 
(Code 1971, § 29-4) 
Sec. 25-12. - Correction of conditions in violation of certain provisions of chapter. 
(a)  If, upon any inspection, the health officer shall find any condition in violation of sections 25-2 through 25-6, or any provision of article III of this chapter, or any provision of a permit issued under such article, he shall direct, by written notice, the person responsible for the violation to make the necessary corrections within such reasonable time as shall be specified in such notice. 
(b)  No person shall neglect, fail or refuse to comply with the provisions of any written notice issued pursuant to this section within the time specified in such notice. 
(Code 1971, §§ 29-18, 29-20) 
Sec. 25-13. - Water conservation regulations. 
(a)  [City manager to declare emergency.] The city manager is hereby authorized to declare an emergency in any or all areas supplied by the city affecting the use of water during any period in which there is a water shortage as determined by the city manager at his discretion. 
(b)  [Written notice.] In declaring any emergency pursuant to this section, the city manager shall advise the governing body of the declaration by written notice, shall post a written notice at the entrance in city hall and on the city's cable-access channel, and shall advise by news release the news media which routinely cover the area in which the emergency has been declared. 
(c)  [Stages of conservation.] Based on the forecast of the continued water supply available to the city, the city manager may order the appropriate stage of water conservation: 
(1)  Stage I. In the event that water supplies are reduced, either voluntarily or involuntarily by the city's outside sources and or mild reductions in well production, the public works department will segregate portions of the city to be serviced water still available from outside sources. The remainder of the city will be serviced by the city's wells. The city will ask the residents to voluntarily conserve water and refrain from filling pools, washing vehicles, watering lawns, or washing sidewalks and driveways. 
(2)  Stage II. In the event that water supplies are very limited, i.e., outside supplies are excessively reduced or become nonexistent, one (1) or more wells become nonproductive, the city shall restrict or curtail less essential uses of water, including but not limited to, the following: 
a.  Watering of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, plants or any other vegetation to include plant nurseries, golf course greens and commercial agricultural activities; 
b.  Washing of automobiles, trucks, trailers or any other type of mobile equipment except in facilities operating with a water recycling system approved by the city or except for safety or emergency purposes; provided, however, that any facility operating with a water recycling system must prominently display in public view a sign stating that such a recycling system is in operation; 
c.  Washing of streets, driveways, parking lots, service station aprons, office buildings, exteriors of homes or apartments or other outdoor surfaces, except for emergency or safety purposes or to remove a hazard; 
d.  The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure making a similar use of water; 
e.  The filling of swimming and/or wading pools, or the refilling of swimming and/or wading pools which were drained after the effective date of the order to restrict water usage or any other use of water supply for outdoor recreation; 
f.  The operation of any industrial or commercial activity or process, including construction activity, which uses water beyond the sanitary and drinking needs of employees, customers and visitors; 
g.  The use of water from fire hydrants for any purpose other than fire suppression; 
h.  The operation of any water-cooled comfort air conditioning which does not have water-conserving equipment in operation where interior temperature is less than seventy-eight (78) degrees Fahrenheit. 
(3)  Stage III. In the event that supplies of water are available are critically limited, the city manager is authorized to restrict use of water to purposes which are essential to the preservation of life, health and safety. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person violating any provision of this section or any order or regulation promulgated by the city manager implementing this section shall upon conviction, be deemed guilty of a class 3 misdemeanor. In addition, the governing body may seek suspension of water service to any violator, by injunction, abatement or other appropriate legal remedy. 
(e)  Appeals. Whenever the city manager shall issue an order directing restriction of water or curtailment of the use of water as provided herein, or shall seek suspension of water service as a result of a violation of provisions of this section, the subject of the order of suspension shall have the right to appeal the decision of the city manager to the governing body. The governing body may appoint a temporary board of appeals consisting of three (3) or more members of the governing body, or any other designated parties, to act in its place on this matter. The governing body or board of appeals shall grant an appellant a reasonable opportunity to present in writing, or at the option of the governing body or board of appeals in a public meeting, arguments against such decision of the city manager. The decision of the appropriate panel shall be final. 
(f)  Termination of emergency. Based upon receipt of information from water system operators and other pertinent sources, and upon his determination that sufficient water supplies exist to warrant termination of emergency restrictions or curtailments on water usage, in whole or in part, the city manager shall declare the water supply emergency to be ended. The city manager shall notify the governing body and the public of such termination, as prescribed in paragraph (b) above within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 01-1700-681, § 1, 4-16-02) 
Secs. 25-14-25-23. - Reserved.

Sec. 25-25. - New connect, reconnect and transfer fees. 
(a)  All requests to have water and sewer service connected, reconnected or transferred shall be made in writing by the owner of the real property to be served by the water and sewer connection (the "property owner"). The written request must be on a form provided by the city's department of public works. 
(b)  In the case of rental property, the tenant may request that the water and sewer account be transferred into the tenant's name and that water and sewer service be connected or reconnected to the rental property if all of the following requirements have been met at the time of each request for a transfer, connection or reconnection: 
(1)  The property owner has completed the form required by subsection (a). 
(2)  The property owner has provided written authorization for the water and sewer account to be transferred into the name of the tenant. The written authorization must be on a form provided by the city's department of public works and will require the property owner to acknowledge that a lien may be placed on the property if the tenant fails to pay any delinquent water and sewer charges. 
(3)  The tenant has provided a security deposit to the city in the amount of two hundred forty dollars ($240.00). 
a.  No security deposit will be required if the tenant presents to the city a landlord authorization letter which has attached documentation showing that the tenant receives need-based local, state, or federal rental assistance. 
b.  The absence of a security deposit as permitted by subparagraph a. above shall not prevent the city from exercising its lien rights as authorized by section 25-32. 
(4)  Water and sewer service must not have been disconnected or shut off prior to the requested date of transfer. Any disconnection of water and sewer service, including but not limited to a disconnection at the request of the property owner or a previous tenant, will require the reconnection of water and sewer service; the new tenant will not qualify for a transfer until after the reconnection has occurred. 
(c)  Any lien that has been recorded against the property owner for delinquent water and sewer fees and charges must be satisfied and all outstanding charges, fees, penalties and interest for water and sewer service must be paid prior to water and sewer service connections or reconnections being made to the subject property. 
(d)  The fee to have water and sewer service connected, reconnected or transferred is as follows: 
(1)  Monday through Friday (except holidays observed by the city) during the hours of 8:30 a.m. through 5:00 p.m.: Thirty dollars ($30.00). 
(2)  Outside the hours listed in paragraph (1) above: Ninety dollars ($90.00). 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 06-1700-808, § 1, 6-29-06; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14; Ord. No. 16-1700-987, § 1, 5-3-16) 
Sec. 25-26. - When service to be disconnected. 
    Water and sewer service will be disconnected when requested by the customers of record or by the property owner, when evidence of a court order is presented, or by order of the city manager for reason of customer nonpayment of applicable charges. 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14) 
Sec. 25-27. - When meters are to be read. 
    Water meters for all service customers will be read no sooner than the first day of the previous month of the billing month. Customers will be billed using an actual meter reading. Estimated readings based on past usage history will be billed to customers only when, in the judgment of the city manager, there is inclement weather or other circumstance which makes actual readings of those customers impossible to conduct in a timely manner. 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 2000-1700-619, § 1, 3-7-00; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14) 
Sec. 25-28. - When bills to be mailed to customers. 
    All bills for water and sewer service will be mailed by the seventh working day of the month. 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14) 
Sec. 25-29. - When bills are due for payment to city. 
    All charges as billed by the city will be due and payable by the last day of the month. In the event the last day of the month falls on a weekend or holiday, the billed charges will be due the next regular business day. 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14) 
Sec. 25-30. - Penalty for failure to pay water and sewer charges and fees when due. 
    Penalty for failure to pay water and sewer charges and fees when due for the January 2016 billing is extended to March 31, 2016. 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14; Ord. No. 16-1700-982, § 1, 2-2-16) 
Sec. 25-31. - Effect of failure to pay water and sewer charges and fees when due. 
(a)  If the fees and charges charged for water service or the use and services of the sewage disposal system by or in connection with any real estate are not paid when due, a penalty and interest shall at that time be owed as provided for by general law, and the owner or tenant, as the case may be, of such real estate shall, until the fees and charges are paid with the penalty and interest to the date of payment, cease to dispose of sewage or industrial waste originating from or on the real estate by discharge thereof directly or indirectly into the sewage disposal system. If the owner or tenant does not pay the full amount of charges, penalty and interest for water provided or cease the disposal within thirty (30) days thereafter, the city shall notify such owner or tenant of the delinquency. If such owner or tenant does not pay the full amount of charges, penalty, and interest for water provided or cease such disposal within sixty (60) days after the delinquent fees and charges charged for water or sewage disposal services are due, or enter into a payment extension plan pursuant to section 15-34 below, the city shall cease supplying water and sewage disposal services thereto unless the Health Director of the Prince William Health District certifies that shutting off the water will endanger the health of the occupants of the premises or the health of others. At least ten (10) business days prior to ceasing the supply of water or sewage disposal services, the city shall provide the owner or tenant with written notice of such cessation. 
(b)  When water service has been discontinued and disconnection made, there will be no reconnection until payment of the total bill, including penalties and interest and a reconnection fee, has been made. 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 93-170-482, 2-2-93; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14; Ord. No. 16-1700-987, § 1, 5-3-16) 
State Law reference- Authority for above provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.1-32.1. 
Sec. 25-32. - Lien for failure to pay water and sewer charges. 
(a)  Fees and charges prescribed by this chapter may be recovered by the city by an action at law or suit in equity, and shall constitute a lien against the property, ranking on a parity with liens for unpaid taxes. 
(b)  A lien may be placed on the property in the amount of up to three (3) months of delinquent water and sewer charges, plus any applicable penalties and interest on the delinquent charges, plus reasonable attorney fees and other costs of collection not exceeding twenty percent (20%) of the delinquent charges. In no case shall a lien for less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) be placed against the property. In the case of services to a tenant, unless water is required to be provided pursuant to subsection 25-31(a) above or other applicable law, or a payment extension plan has been entered into pursuant to section 25-34 below, if the city does not cease supplying water to the tenant within sixty (60) days after the bill becomes delinquent, there shall be no lien placed on the property for charges and collection costs beyond the 60-day period and no recourse against the property owner for service beyond the 60-day period. 
(c)  A lien may be placed on the property for water and sewer services used by a tenant only if the city has: 
(1)  Advised the property owner in writing that a lien may be placed on the property if the tenant fails to pay any delinquent water and sewer charges; 
(2)  Mailed by first-class mail to the property owner, or sent electronically if requested by the property owner, at the address listed in the written authorization from the property owner (or such other address as the owner may provide), a duplicate copy of the final bill sent to the tenant at the time of sending the final bill to the tenant; 
(3)  Applied the security deposit held by the city to the payment of the outstanding balance; 
(4)  Employed reasonable collection efforts and practices to collect amounts due from the tenant including filing for the Set-Off Debt Collection Program if the city is a participant; and 
(5)  Provided the property owner with thirty (30) days' written notice with a copy of the final bill to allow the property owner a reasonable opportunity to pay the amount of any outstanding balance and avoid the recordation of a lien against the property. 
If the property owner fails to pay the amount of the outstanding balance within the 30-day period, the city may record a lien in the amount of the outstanding balance against the property owner. Upon payment of the outstanding balance, or any portion thereof, or of any amounts of such fees and charges owed by the former tenant, the property owner shall be entitled to receive any refunds and shall be subrogated against the former tenant in place of the city in the amount paid by the property owner. The city shall execute all documents necessary to perfect such subrogation in favor of the property owner. 
(d)  Unless a lien has been recorded against the property owner, the city shall not deny service to a new tenant who is requesting service at a particular property address based upon the fact that a former tenant has not paid any outstanding fees and charges charged for the use and services in the name of the former tenant. The city shall provide information relative to a former tenant or current tenant to the property owner upon request of the property owner. If the property owner provides the city with a request to be notified of a tenant's delinquent water and sewer bill and provides an email address, the city shall send the property owner notice when a tenant's water and sewer bill has become fifteen (15) days delinquent. 
(e)  The lien shall not bind or affect a subsequent bona fide purchaser of the real estate for valuable consideration without actual notice of the lien until the amount of such delinquent charges is entered in the official records of the office of the clerk of the circuit court for the city. The clerk shall make and index the entries in the clerk's official records for a fee of five dollars ($5.00) per entry, to be paid by the locality and added to the amount of the lien. 
(f)  The lien on any real estate may be discharged by the payment to the city of the total lien amount and the interest which has accrued to the date of the payment. The city shall deliver a fully executed lien release to the person making the payment. The city shall provide the fully executed lien release to the person who made payment within ten (10) business days following the payment if the person who made the payment did not personally appear at the time of the payment. Upon presentation of the lien release, the clerk shall mark the lien satisfied. There will be no separate clerk's fee for the lien release. 
(Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14; Ord. No. 16-1700-987, § 1, 5-3-16) 
Sec. 25-33. - Relief to the elderly and disabled who qualify. 
    Water and sewer customers who qualify for real estate tax relief pursuant to division 2 of article II of chapter 22 of this Code shall be eligible for a reduction of the base service fee for water and sewer services to nineteen dollars and fifty cents ($19.50) per month. The commissioner of the revenue shall certify a listing of those residents who qualify under this program and submit it to the city's water and sewer billing representative by the first day of June of each year. Eligibility will run from July 1 of each year to June 30 of the following year. 
(Ord. No. 85-1700-277, 4-16-85; Ord. No. 91-170-446, 6-18-91; Ord. No. 92-1700-462, 4-21-92; Ord. No. 93-1700-486, 3-2-93; Ord. No. 94-1700-503, 4-19-94; Ord. No. 04-1700-738, § 1, 2-17-04; Ord. No. 14-1700-959, § 1, 10-21-14) 
Sec. 25-34. - Payment extension plan. 
(a)  Any water and sewer customer whose account is delinquent and who cannot pay the amount due prior to service being shut off may extend the due date for payment in accordance with this section by paying, no later than close of business on the day before the shut-off date, an administrative fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) plus thirty percent (30%) of the delinquent amount then due, including penalties and interest, to the city treasurer, and entering into a payment extension plan with the city treasurer for payment of the remaining delinquent amount, including interest that accrues during the payment extension plan period.
